TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers:

PETITION.TITLE: Health Care
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
We the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that,
Australia's population is ageing and most people require more health services as they grow older.
If open not-for-profit health Funds are to be able to meet the costs of providing benefits to their older members at affordable rates, they need to share these costs equitably.
Some health insurance organisations are being allowed to avoid meeting the health costs of sick and elderly people.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to take the necessary action to reverse rising cost trends and provide positive incentives to encourage all health funds to share the cost of health care for sick and elderly Australians.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Adermann (from 350 citizens), Mr Aldred (from 151 citizens), Mr Beale (from 61 citizens), Mr Lionel Bowen (from 55 citizens), Mr Braithwaite (from 180 citizens), Mr Donald Cameron (from 211 citizens), Mr Ewen Cameron (from 83 citizens), Mr Cleeland (from 75 citizens), Mr Courtice (from 714 citizens), Mr Cross (from 932 citizens), Mr Duffy (from 375 citizens), Mr Peter Fisher (from 39 citizens), Mr Fitzgibbon (from 138 citizens), Mr Free (from 25 citizens), Mr Griffiths (from 198 citizens), Mr Halverson (from 51 citizens), Dr Hewson (from 132 citizens), Mr Hollis (from 64 citizens), Mr Jull (from 695 citizens), Dr Klugman (from 74 citizens), Mr Langmore (from 591 citizens), Mr Lloyd (from 62 citizens), Mr McGauran (from 192 citizens), Mr Macphee (from 187 citizens), Mr Milton (from 88 citizens), Mr Moore (from 790 citizens), Mr Peter Morris (from 78 citizens), Mr Peacock (from 194 citizens), Mr Simmons (from 193 citizens), Mr Sinclair (from 223 citizens), Mr Spender (from 104 citizens), Dr Theophanous (from 48 citizens) and Mr White (from 628 citizens).

PETITION.PRESENTERS: CAMERON; CROSS; CUNNINGHAM; FISHER; MILES; MOUNTFORD; PROSSER; TICKNER; TUCKEY; WILSON

PETITION.TITLE: Importation of Pornography
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker, and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.

The petition of citizens of Australia points out that the community deplores the persistent refusal to ban pornography in X and NVE Videos, Films and Publications, and deplores the resulting escalation of crime and sexual crime in the Australian community.
Because Parliament has direct and heavy obligation to ensure the safety of women and child-victims, your petitioners therefore request the House:
to ban the importation, and availability of pornography in Videos, Films and Publications,
to prevent black-market trading by banning the possession of X and NVE material,
vote against any recommendation to extend Video and Theatre Film Classifications and Guidelines into television standards,
ensure that Pay Television does not exceed the programme limits of Television standards,
control all censorship criteria and guidelines by substantive legislation,

give earnest consideration to these matters, in order that no Attorney-General shall ever again have the power to change our social and home environment for generations to come, without thorough and full debate in both Houses of Parliament.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Donald Cameron (from 35 citizens), Mr Cross (from 85 citizens), Mr Cunningham (from 45 citizens), Mr Peter Fisher (from 50 citizens), Mr Miles (from 186 citizens), Mr Mountford (from 18 citizens), Mr Prosser (from 48 citizens), Mr Tickner (from 174 citizens), Mr Tuckey (from 3,435 citizens) and Mr Wilson (from 168 citizens).

PETITION.PRESENTERS: BLEWETT; CAMERON; CLEELAND; COWAN; CUNNINGHAM; MOORE
PETITION.TITLE: `Authority Required' Prescriptions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled; the humble petition of the undersigned citizens showeth:

that your petitioners deplore the Federal Government's decision to remove 53 Pharmaceutical drugs from the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme including the best available for the treatment of high blood pressure, cancer, epilepsy, high cholesterol and uneven heartbeat-and place them for cost saving reasons only on a special list requiring Authority from a Canberra bureaucrat, and;

that we believe a patient's doctor is clearly the best judge for medication needed for their particular illness and that it is therefore wrong and unfair to force that doctor to seek permission from a bureaucrat in Canberra who has no personal knowledge of that case.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled will call on the Government to immediately abandon the proposal and keep its election promise of high quality and universal health care for all Australians.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Dr Blewett (from 34 citizens), Mr Ewen Cameron (from 151 citizens), Mr Cleeland (from 108 citizens), Mr Cowan (from 18 citizens), Mr Cunningham (from 143 citizens) and Mr Moore (from 50 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: the humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:
That your petitioners request that major reforms be made to Australia's Retirement Income System. These reforms are earnestly sought by retired Australians and those facing retirement.
The reforms are:
that the pension be increased to 30% of average weekly earnings (i.e. increasing the basic pension to $146 p.w.).
that the pension become tax exempt.
that the pension be adjusted so that it keeps pace with price rises rather than falling up to 12 months behind.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray that your House/Parliament will see that our requested reforms are implemented.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Braithwaite (from 73 citizens), Mr Peter Fisher (from 22 citizens), Mr Griffiths (from 172 citizens), Mr Barry Jones (from 21 citizens) and Mr White (from 934 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that whereas:
1. They are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian National Flag.
2. They are aware it properly reflects the immutable characteristics of Australia, namely:
(a) The Union Jack, itself the creation of three Christian Crosses, represents the Nation's historical origin and the source of its language and law;
(b) The Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its geographical location on this planet Earth;
(c) The large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901.
3. They know the Flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
4. They recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
5. They are certain that any change to the Flag will produce division in the Australian community.
Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will:
Propose and pass a motion that ``the existing Australian National Flag be changed only with the approval of the Nation as expressed in a Referendum''.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Cleeland (from 32 citizens), Mr Duffy (from 17 citizens) and Mr O'Keefe (from 42 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Honourable Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that whereas:
They are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian National Flag.

Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will give a speedy passage to the Flags Act Amendment Bill which provides that the Australian National Flag can only be changed by a Referendum.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Woodchipping
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament. The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of this House that we are concerned at the threats caused by logging to the integrity and continued existence of what remains of the forests of south eastern Australia.
Your petitioners therefore request the House to direct the Prime Minister and his government.
(1) to phase out woodchipping for export;
(2) not to renew a long-term export licence to Harris Daishowa;

(3) to ensure that sensitive environmental areas, and specifically the proposed national park and wilderness areas of Coolangubra, Cathcart, Egan Peaks and the Tantawangalo catchment, are protected and excluded from the proposed woodchip export licence; and
(4) to promote ecologically sound and sustainable forestry practices including:
re-afforestation and plantation of native hardwoods and already cleared land to reduce pressure on native forests; and
minimisation of wasteful uses of forest products.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Baldwin (from 426 citizens) and Ms McHugh (from 12,796 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Human Rights: Romania
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker, and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament Assembled.

Romania, whose Human Rights Record had been worse than that of South Africa's even before she embarked on a diabolic village destruction program, deservedly attracts worldwide condemnation. The systematic cultural genocide of the peoples affected must be prevented.
Therefore your petitioners humbly pray that:
1. The Australian Parliament establish whether or not Romania has satisfied fully her obligations under the Treaty of Trianon (1920) and the Peace Treaty of Paris (1947),
2. If found that Romania violates these agreements, the signatures representing Australia jointly or singularly be withdrawn from the thus invalidated documents,
3. Australia tables her findings at the appropriate forums of the United Nations.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Beale (from 38 citizens) and Mr N.A. Brown (from 88 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Interest Rates
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:-
Recent huge rises in mortgage interest rates have pushed the cost of buying their own home beyond the reach of most Australian families.

Those Australians already paying off home mortgages are now suffering severely and unfairly through increased mortgage payments or longer repayment times so that many will never pay off their mortgage and go further and further into debt unless interest rates fall substantially.

Now, therefore, your petitioners request that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled require the Hawke-Keating government to cease its excessive reliance on high interest rates as its major economic policy weapon and instead to use other measures which would allow interest rates to return to levels that do not force Australians out of their homes-so that the traditional right of home ownership is returned to average Australian families.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Ewen Cameron (from 37 citizens) and Mr Jull (from 120 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Pharmaceutical Benefits
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Madam Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws the attention of the House to the continued government interference in the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme which has severely affected the viability of our community pharmacies and their ability to provide the quality and quantity of services to which we as Australians have a right.

Your petitioners therefore request the House to guarantee the provision of an adequately funded Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme which ensures that the availability of pharmaceutical benefits through local community pharmacies.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mrs Kelly (from 3,528 citizens) and Mr Smith (from 473 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Pharmaceutical Benefits
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Madam Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws the attention of the House to the continued Government interference in the Pharmaceutical benefits scheme which is causing hardship and confusion amongst the sick and elderly.

Your petitioners therefore request the House to guarantee the provision of an adequately funded pharmaceutical benefits scheme which is free from Government tampering and provides for the public of Australia a comprehensive range of modern therapeutic products.

PETITION.TITLE: International Earth Repair Action Decade
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. This petition of concerned Australian citizens respectfully points out that:
our total global environment is rapidly deteriorating;
important natural resources vital to human life and livelihood such as ozone, trees, soil and water are being depleted at an increasing and alarming rate;
there is an urgent need to educate all people in conservation skills and the responsible use and maintenance of natural resources;
the United Nations Association of Australia (the peoples' arm of the UN), has proclaimed an Australian ERA (Earth Repair Action) Decade from 1988;
Earth Repair Action will unite people, communities, religions and nations in the productive purpose of greening and repairing our Earth for a safer and more peaceful future.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament will:

Propose that an International Earth Repair Action (ERA) Decade begin on World Environment Day, June 5, 1990 with FIERY, the First International Earth Repair Year, and that this be proclaimed by the United Nations General Assembly. This ten-year plan will ignite the spirit of local and global co-operation to hygienically compost all presently wasted bio-degradable material into humus to revitalise soils; grow billions of trees to replace forests lost and replenish the atmosphere; establish sustainable, economic and agricultural growth internationally and end world hunger.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Mountford (from 10 citizens) and Mr Webster (from 35 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: National Acoustics Laboratory
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
The petition of certain residents of the state of Queensland draws to the attention of the House our support for the National Acoustics Laboratory (NAL).
Your petitioners therefore ask the House to ensure that the NAL will not be adversely affected by staff cuts and structural changes.

PETITION.TITLE: Home Loan Interest Rates
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House that the manipulation of the economy by way of Home Loan Interest Rate adjustments has resulted in an unjust burden to Australian families.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House act to bring about the following:
1. The immediate reduction in Home Loan Interest Rate.
2. The stabilisation of Home Loan Interest Rates at a manageable level.
3. The introduction of Taxation Rebates for citizens paying Home loans on owner occupied homes.

PETITION.TITLE: Advertising of Alcohol on Radio and Television
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament: The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House that:
Alcohol is recognised as Australia's number one drug problem which is responsible for at least 50% of all road fatalities; a high percentage of serious crime and vandalism.
Hospital beds are filled with sufferers of the many alcohol related diseases including: cirrhosis of the liver; heart disease; stomach ulcers; various forms of cancer and mental illness.
Alcohol causes much family unhappiness and marriage breakdown as well as being involved in some cases of child abuse and molestation.
Television and radio have a persuasive effect on children and young people.
Your petitioners therefore request the House to ban all advertising of alcohol on television and radio.

PETITION.TITLE: Road Funding
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
The petition of certain electors of the Division of Indi.

Draws to the attention of the House the current inadequate level of funding for road construction and maintenance and express concern that the House may have placed before it, as part of the government economic strategy, options to further reduce such expenditure, and in so doing placing an increased financial burden upon local government ratepayers.

Your petitioners therefore respectfully call upon the House to ensure an increase over current road funding levels through a clear dedication of a proportion of fuel excise collected, indexed for inflation, towards roadworks and that such funding arrangements provide for a clear and reliable method of distribution to local government.

PETITION.TITLE: Private Enterprise: Taxation
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth: Introduction of any additional capital gains taxes, wealth taxes or death duties is opposed on the grounds that:
they adversely affect the small and medium size businesses in Australia, including farms, destroying incentive and discouraging investment in this important area of the economy;
the Australian economy, and employment in particular, is heavily reliant on growth in small businesses;

any capital gains that might result when owners of small enterprises finally sell these assets are not ``windfall gains'', but the result of many hard years of work and sacrifice, with very little being taken out of the business or farm by way of salaries so that the maximum amount of money can be ploughed back into the business or farm to create growth and jobs;
the owners of small businesses and farms often depend on a capital gain-which are simply deferred salaries-when they eventually sell these assets to sustain them in retirement.

Your petitioners request that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, will protect the rights of private enterprise and reject any inequitable additional taxation, and, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: `Authority Required' Prescriptions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled. The humble petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That whilst acknowledging the Government's desire to contain the growth in health costs, the introduction of 61 new drugs to the `Authority Required' listing will result in potentially serious delays in patients receiving medication prescribed by their doctors.
Your petitioners request the House to immediately reverse the Government's decision and withdraw these drugs from the `Authorities Required' list.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Road Funding
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the Indi electorate respectfully showeth that:
Australians living in rural and non-urban areas rely to a great degree on the local road network for all facets of their lives.
Funding for roads is an essential part of the Commonwealth's responsibilities for the maintenance of the transport infrastructure.
Road funding under the Hawke Government has decreased significantly in real terms and local government is particularly disadvantaged by this decline.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:

immediately address the serious problem of a rapidly deteriorating road network which is confronting local government by allocating more resources, along with State Governments, to local road funding.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Gold Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

We, the undersigned endorse the actions of Graeme Campbell, MP, in pursuing his stance against removing company tax exemptions for gold producers. We further commend the work of the Western Australian Government to have the Federal Government's decision on gold tax reversed.

Unlike the assistance provided to Australian manufacturing industry, the taxation arrangement applying to gold is transparent and therefore an easy target. Moreover, because of the concentration of the industry in remote areas of Western Australia, far from Canberra, the legitimate voice of the industry is drowned out by special interest groups close to the capital.

The proposed change to the gold taxation regime has already produced substantial distortions in exploration drilling activity and development plans of gold mines. Exploration drilling has declined and there is a real risk that some mines could begin the high grading of their orebodies which will shorten the life of the mine.
The Western Australian Government has strongly opposed the proposed tax changes because of these distorting effects.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that you will give this matter earnest consideration and your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Manufacture and Sale of War and Victim Toys
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled:

The undersigned citizens of Australia ask that the manufacture and sale of war and victim toys be banned in Australia and that there be legislation to control violent cartoons and video games and violence on television generally.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Crime and Violence on Television
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Lyne electorate respectfully showeth that:
There is too much crime and violence on TV and this is breaking down the standards and codes of behaviour in our society.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
Urge TV stations to clean up their act and improve the standards of shows, news and current affairs programs by reducing the incidence of crime and violence broadcast every day into people's homes.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Crime and Violence on Television
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament: The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House:
There is too much crime and violence on TV and this is breaking down the standards and codes of behaviour in our society.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the House compel TV stations to improve the standards of shows, news and current affairs programs by reducing the incidence of crime and violence broadcast every day into people's homes, by fifty per cent.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Tim Fischer (from six citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Fuel Excise
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament. The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House that:
Federal fuel excise taxation has reached record levels resulting in high costs for fuel and causing severe hardship particularly for people in country areas.
At the same time there has been a considerable reduction in the amount of Federal fuel excise taxation spent on roads, reduced from 66 per cent in 1983 to 20 per cent in 1989.

Your Petitioners therefore pray that the House call on the Federal Government to take heed of the crisis situation facing small business, large fuel users and the crisis situation in relation to road infrastructure and-
1. Reduce by half the CPI Federal fuel tax increases
2. Increase by half the proportion of Federal fuel taxation being spent on roads.

PETITION.TITLE: HMAS Nirimba and HMAS Cerberus
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth-

That HMAS Nirimba is a vital training facility for Navy apprentices with training expertise that does not and cannot exist at any other location. The expertise is not just the knowledge which is passed onto the Navy apprentices but the years of goodwill at the facility and the interaction with the community which enhances the education process.

If the proposal for collocation of the functions of HMAS Nirimba and HMAS Cerberus, at HMAS Cerberus, as outlined in the ``Review of Australia's Defence Facilities'' by Robert J. Cooksey, is realised, then not just the Navy, but Australia, will lose a vital centre for training in trade excellence.
Further HMAS Nirimba is vital to the local business community which services not just the base needs but those of the personnel and their families.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives will reject outright any proposal to the functions of HMAS Nirimba and HMAS Cerberus being combined.

PETITION.TITLE: Aged Care
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain citizens of Broken Hill in the State of New South Wales, points out to the House and calls on the Federal Government to accept its responsibility by providing sufficient suitable Nursing Home and Hostel accommodation for those Broken Hill citizens who are frail or aged.
Your petitioners therefore requests the House:

(a) Negotiates with the N.S.W. State Government to maintain sufficient long-stay beds at the Broken Hill Base Hospital until it, the Federal Government with whom the responsibility of care for the aged lies, provides the accommodation required.
(b) Also requests that increased funding be provided for support services that provide care for the frail and aged in their own homes in Broken Hill.

PETITION.TITLE: Importation of Radioactive Substances
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
That we most strongly oppose the process of `food irradiation' by Cobalt 60, cesium 137, cesium 134 or any machine sources.
That we oppose the introduction of regulations that will facilitate the food irradiation process being permitted by State Governments.

We call on the House to ban the importation of any radioactive substances, or machinery for the purposes of food irradiation; disallow regulations permitting the irradiation of food in this country; ban the irradiation of food in this country; and also ban the importation of food treated by irradiation.
We also call upon the House to request the Government to withdraw from the Asian Regional Co-operative Project on Food Irradiation and the International Consultative Group on Food Irradiation.

PETITION.TITLE: Civic Olympic Pool, Canberra
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
We the undersigned,
(1) are alarmed that developers are now lobbying for the redevelopment of this site
(2) call for the maintenance of recreational facilities within the city centre
(3) urge that all pressures to relocate the pool elsewhere be resisted.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Higher Education Contribution Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
The petition of certain citizens of Australia draw to the attention of the House our opposition to the Higher Education Contribution Scheme (HECS-graduate to tuition tax) on the grounds that:
1. it is a tax on education and not wealth,
2. it is a flat tax and so discriminates inequitably between students,

3. women and other groups with lower average incomes will be less likely to enter higher education and if they do so they will have to pay a greater proportion of their total life's income toward the debt,
4. students already pay for their education through general taxation,
5. all society benefits from higher education, all society should pay-through a fair and progressive taxation system.

Further your petitioners therefore request the House to withdraw the HECS and maintain the present 1% of GDP (gross domestic product) spent by the Commonwealth on higher education (which will itself pay for the expansion in higher education).

PETITION.TITLE: Incomes of World War II Veterans
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled,
The humble Petition of the undersigned electors of Australia respectfully showeth that-

The majority of World War II servicewomen, together with thousands of wartime servicemen who also did not hesitate to volunteer their services in the Defence Forces of Australia at a time when their country was at serious risk from an implacable enemy, did not serve in a theatre of war. This was not of their own choosing but as a result they are not eligible for a Service Pension under the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986.

Many receive a Disability Pension because of injuries or conditions resulting from or attributable to their wartime `home service' in Australia's Defence Forces and the fact that they did not serve in a theatre of war does not lessen their disabilities which have caused them considerable pain and frustration and spoilt their quality of life over a long period.

Any Disability Pension received by a Service Pensioner is not income for the assessment of basic Service Pension but is considered as income by the Department of Social Security, at times meaning the loss of fringe benefits as well as reducing the amount of Age Pension granted because of compensation for injuries or conditions accepted by determining authorities as war-caused. A Disability Pension is considered as combined income in the case of a married couple when the rate of Age pension entitlement is being assessed.
Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Parliament will determine that-

Social Security Legislation be amended to correct the anomaly which exists in the inclusion of a war veteran's Disability Pension in the assessment of income for the purposes of the Department of Social Security when it is not income for the purposes of the Department of Veterans' Affairs, this being an injustice which discriminates against the veterans of World War II who did not serve in a theatre of war.
And your petitioners will in duty bound ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Fuel Prices
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House:
That people throughout rural and regional Australia are being discriminated against by unjustly high fuel prices.

They believe the Government should legislate to require a uniform price discount to all wholesalers when this is offered by the oil companies, and thus remove the major component in the retail price differential of approximately ten cents per litre.
Your petitioners therefore request the House to amend the legislation to allow cheaper fuel price justice for country people.

PETITION.TITLE: Mr Don Bickett: Australian Citizenship
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.

The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Wollongong, New South Wales, Australia, respectfully draws the attention of the House to our request to obtain Australian citizenship for Mr Don Bickett, a very highly respected member of our community and a key player in the Illawarra Hawks basketball team.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House will take urgent steps to grant Don Bickett Australian citizenship.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Messrs Don Bickett and Alphonse Hammond: Australian Citizenship
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.

The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Wollongong, New South Wales, Australia, respectfully draws the attention of the House to our request to obtain Australian citizenship for Mr Don Bickett and Alphonse Hammond, two very highly respected members of our community and key players in the Illawarra Hawks basketball team.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House will take urgent steps to grant Don Bickett and Alphonse Hammond Australian citizenship.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Tax File Number System
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.
The petition of certain citizens of Australia who draw to the attention of the House that:

1. The Australian Taxation Office disregarded its privacy obligations to the citizens of Queensland, Western Australia and the Northern Territory in February by sending an admitted 55,000 to 77,000 tax file number letters to people who were either deceased or had changed address.

2. The Australian Taxation Office disregarded its privacy obligations to the citizens of New South Wales, Victoria, South Australia, Tasmania and the Australian Capital Territory in March by sending an admitted 29,000 to 58,000 tax file number letters to people who were either deceased or had changed address.
3. The Australian Taxation Office disregarded its privacy obligations by sending out a large number of tax file number letters during March in unsealed envelopes.

4. The Australian Taxation Office extended the deadline for employee declarations beyond the 31st March as defined by section 292c (4) (a) of the Taxation Laws Amendment (Tax File Numbers) Act 1988 but failed to obtain a Proclamation from the Governor-General for this extension as stipulated by section 202c (4) (b) of the Act.

5. The Australian Taxation Office, in its implementation of the tax file number system, has failed to abide by the provisions of both the Privacy Act 1988 and the Taxation Laws Amendment (Tax File Numbers) Act 1988.

Your petitioners therefore request the House to refer the matter to the Finance and Public Administration Committee of the House of Representatives for purposes of an investigation into the administration of the tax file number related legislation by the Taxation Office and the role of the Taxation Commissioner in the abovementioned administration.

PETITION.TITLE: Road Funding
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned shows:-

We are gravely concerned at the Government's failure to allocate revenue collected from motorists and transporters at the petrol pump to the adequate maintenance and development of our highway infrastructure.

Your petitioners request that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, amend existing legislation to increase immediately the level of spending on maintenance and development of our national road system.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully beseech that:
Parliament allow insurance for the gap between the Medicare rebate and the Scheduled fee.
That the unfair discrimination against private patients in hospital be withdrawn.

Your petitioners humbly request that all patients receive an equal Medicare rebate for services regardless of where they are provided, on the understanding that all patients pay the same compulsory Medicare Insurance levy.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport
PETITION.PARA: To the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens respectfully showeth that:
``Kingsford-Smith Airport is becoming increasingly congested and existing facilities are inadequate to handle the number of aircraft or their passengers.

The diversion of aircraft from Kingsford-Smith Airport to Bankstown and/or increase landing charged for peak period will do little to relieve congestion and will place enormous financial and other burdens on commuter airlines and their passengers.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
Give immediate approval for the construction of a third runway at Kingsford-Smith Airport, and upgrade the existing radar and traffic control facilities.''
And your petitioners as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Constitution Alteration (Electors Initiative) Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled; the humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectively showeth:

that while having some reservations on individual aspects of the Constitutional Initiative (Electors Initiative) 1987 your petitioners wish to express our strong support for the concept of people's democracy implied in that Bill.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled will

Refer the above mentioned Bill to the Joint Select Committee or Electoral Matters and will examine the operation of direct democracy procedures overseas with the intention of passing legislation granting such facilities to your petitioners during the Bicentennial year.
Your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Customs (Cinematograph Films) Regulations
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker, and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.
The petition of citizens of Australia points out to the House that the ACT Classification of Publications Ordinance 1983 has legalised the screening of blasphemy, indecency, and obscenity.
Because Parliament has traditionally respected the beliefs of its people, your petitioners therefore request that the House:
1. retain section 13 of the Customs (Cinematograph Films) Regulations as is;
2. control all censorship criteria and guidelines by substantive legislation;

3. give earnest consideration to these matters, in order that no Attorney-General shall ever again have the power to change our social and home environment for generations to come, without full and thorough debate in both Houses of Parliament.

PETITION.TITLE: Greenhouse Effect
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The Petition of certain Citizens of Australia respectfully sheweth:
That we are concerned at the threat to the environment that may result from an acceleration of the Greenhouse Effect.
Your petitioners therefore request the House to direct the Prime Minister and his Government:
1. To ban immediately both the exporting and the importing of Chlorofluorocarbons (CFC's) with the same exceptions as those specified in the Ozone Protection Bill.
2. To introduce tax deductibility of-
(a) cost and installation of solar heating systems; and
(b) cost and installation of home insulation.
3. To introduce tax incentives for-
(a) research and development of renewable energy alternatives;
(b) manufacturing and marketing of renewable energy alternatives; and
(c) development of new technology to reduce or avoid the use of environmental pollutants.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House will legislate to provide these facilities.
Your petitioners as in duty bound, will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In accordance with standing order 130, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the petition lodged by the honourable member for Kooyong relating to the administration of the tax file number system by the Australian Taxation Office be referred to the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration.
In accordance with sessional orders I am entitled to speak for 20 minutes, but I do not intend to do so by virtue of the fact that this is private members' time.
In moving for the referral of this petition to the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration I want to read the full text of it. The petition states:

1. The Australian Taxation Office disregarded its privacy obligations to the citizens of Queensland, Western Australia and the Northern Territory in February by sending an admitted 55,000 to 77,000 tax file number letters to people who were either deceased or had changed address.

2. The Australian Taxation Office disregarded its privacy obligations to the citizens of New South Wales, Victoria, South Australia, Tasmania and the Australian Capital Territory in March by sending an admitted 29,000 to 58,000 tax file number letters to people who were either deceased or had changed address.
3. The Australian Taxation Office disregarded its privacy obligations by sending out a large number of tax file number letters during March in unsealed envelopes.

4. The Australian Taxation Office extended the deadline for employee declarations beyond the 31st March as defined by section 202C (4) (a) of the Taxation Laws Amendment (Tax File Numbers) Act 1988 but failed to obtain a Proclamation from the Governor-General for this extension as stipulated by section 202C (4) (b) of the Act.

5. The Australian Taxation Office, in its implementation of the tax file number system, has failed to abide by the provisions of both the Privacy Act 1988 and the Taxation Laws Amendment (Tax File Numbers) Act 1988.

The petition that the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock) presented is the first such petition presented in Australia's history. Every member of the Opposition, except the honourable member for Franklin (Mr Goodluck), who was absent, signed that petition. That shows how we, on this side of the House, feel about the maladministration of the tax file number system. On this side of the House we agreed to its implementation in good faith, because of assurances which led us to believe that it would be administered properly, but this has not happened. I have just read out the saga of events during the last few weeks.

The Opposition believes that the tax file number system is so vital to the liberties of our fellow Australians that it is high time that the administration by the Australian Taxation Office came under the scrutiny of our Parliament-the members of which made this legislation and system possible. We put the system in place. It is not working. There has been bungle after bungle. We have now entered a new era of utter disregard by the Taxation Commissioner of the requirements of the Act, and the Opposition believes we have an obligation to examine what is going on. We need to remind the Taxation Office who is the master of legislation of the Parliament.

The Act very clearly states that if the Taxation Office were to go beyond 31 March 1989 in its preliminary introductory stages, it would be obliged to have the date extended by proclamation. I am told that the Taxation Commissioner has taken it unto himself to act under section 3a of the Taxation Administration Act, which states:
The Commissioner has the general administration of this Act.

For the Commissioner to use another Act makes an utter farce of the entire parliamentary system. As a result of deliberations between the Opposition and the Government in October a provision was inserted that extended by way of proclamation the date on which these procedures came into operation. It was not a flippant inclusion. The original legislation was changed. During Question Time on Wednesday, 5 April, I asked the Treasurer (Mr Keating) a question about this matter. I drew it to the attention of the Government. The Treasurer did not know anything about it. He did not even know the period had been extended, that people had been given beyond 31 March or 1 April to get their numbers to their employers. He was unaware of that, but he undertook to consult the Taxation Commissioner. Well, nothing has happened and today something is happening. The Opposition is no longer prepared to allow the Government blatantly to disregard the intentions of the Act. That is why I present this motion to the House.

It is interesting to compare the attitude of the Taxation Commissioner when dealing with his obligations with the way he treats John Citizen. No doubt at his behest and with his encouragement, the Government agreed to include penalties for non-compliance with the requirements of the Act. The first time that a person does such simple things as refuse to furnish a return or any information to the Commissioner or his representative; to give information to him in the manner in which it is required; to lodge an instrument with him or another person for assessment; to cause an instrument to be duly stamped; to produce a book, paper or record; or to appear before him or his representative, that is to be regarded as constituting a person guilty of an offence. The first time a person disregards his obligations to the Commissioner under the taxation laws he faces a $2,000 fine; the second time, a $4,000 fine; and the third time, a $5,000 fine and up to a year in prison. That is the treatment for little people in the community, the 16 million citizens of Australia, eight million of whom are taxpayers, if they do not follow the letter of the Act.

Yet in this situation the Taxation Commissioner's attitude is: `To hell with the Act. I am boss cocky. I will use this other Act. I will go over the top of all of them and I will do it my way'. He is certainly no Frank Sinatra and he has no entitlement to resort to that approach. He has an obligation to the Parliament, an obligation to the people and an obligation to the law. Never before have we on this side of the Parliament, in opposition, moved a petition like this. No one in Australia has so moved in 88 years. But we feel it is high time that the Taxation Commissioner and his Office were subjected to a reinforcement of the fact that the laws of this country are not made just for the people; they are made also to apply to them. Let it not be said that the Treasurer is unaware of it, for on 2 November he complimented the Opposition for being prepared to compromise some of its earlier views. We helped make it possible. I quote from page 2287 of Hansard. In relation to the proclamation the Treasurer said:
As a result-
meaning because of the delay in the legislation-

it became obvious that the commencement date of 1 November 1988 contained in the Bill for the first phase of the tax file number system could not be achieved. Accordingly an amendment of the Bill is moved to enable this commencement day to be set by proclamation.

Section 202c (4) of the Act refers to the phasing-in period and provides that the date will commence by proclamation, as the Treasurer told the Parliament. It goes further to say that it ends on `31 March 1989 or a later day fixed by Proclamation as the last day of the phasing-in period for this Division'. This entire issue caused the Senate some concern and on 3 April, when it had representatives of that Department before its Estimates committee, committee members pursued that matter. During that inquiry another aspect of the Tax Administration Act came to attention. The Taxation Office's Miss Hurditch, on being questioned by Senator Watson-a Liberal senator-about when the Taxation Office moves against people, said:
. . . typically the Tax Office allows a seven-day period of grace in terms of payment . . .

I put to you, Madam Speaker, that we have moved into an era of toughness. There is no quarter given to the taxpayer when he makes a mistake, whether inadvertently or deliberately. I contend that the Parliament sets the tune and the Taxation Office has no right to bring discretion to the very Acts that it operates under. If it feels that the original legislation is in any respect too tough, it has a duty to go to the Treasurer and ask for amendments. That is the law of the land. It is the Parliament that sets the laws, not the government instrumentalities. We do so. We are the people's representatives. The people can take those of us who sit on this side of the House and place us on the other side. They can change every individual in this Parliament. It is the people's will that counts. It is not the right of some bureaucrat to make decisions on his or her own. They have to follow the law. I am very grateful to the Commissioner of Taxation for making us so acutely aware in the last two or three years of the fact that in this day and age there is no quarter for anybody. If there is no quarter for the people, there is no quarter for him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mountford Mr J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Standing Committee on Procedure I present the Committee's report entitled Committee Procedures for Dealing with Witnesses, together with the minutes of proceedings.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —In this, its fourth report for the Thirty-fifth Parliament, the Standing Committee on Procedure proposes that the House adopt a common set of procedures for committees to observe in their dealings with witnesses. Parliamentary committees take the House to the people and perform many tasks that the House itself is not well fitted to perform, such as the examination of witnesses and the assessment of evidence. They are the only form of contact that many electors have with the House and it is through committees that the House does much of its best work. Currently House of Representatives committees alone are conducting over 20 separate inquiries.

SPEECH.PARA: For some time, however, there have been proposals advanced for committees to have a clear and common set of procedures to follow in their dealings with witnesses. If committees were to become too intensely inquisitorial or to display continuing disregard for the reasonable expectations of witnesses, their standing as microcosms of the House, and consequently the standing of the House itself would be devalued. Their actions could become the subject of public scrutiny and criticism and members will be aware of recent comment on the operations of certain parliamentary committees.

In its final report of October 1984 the Joint Select Committee on Parliamentary Privilege recommended that Parliament enact a witnesses protection Act and proposed the adoption of a set of procedures for investigatory committees to observe in their dealings with witnesses. It is committee procedures for dealing with witnesses that is the subject of this Committee's report. At the commencement of its deliberations the Committee had before it the procedures proposed by the Joint Select Committee, a further set of procedures that was presented to the House in May 1987 by the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) during debate on the Parliamentary Privileges Bill, and a set of proposals that had been circulated by the Clerk to House committee chairmen in December 1986.

In the course of its inquiry the Procedure Committee considered the procedures proposed and those adopted by the Senate in February 1988, as well as current standing orders and current committee practices. The Committee also considered submissions from committee chairmen on the proposals. The report recommends to the House for adoption a set of procedures which it believes strikes a balance between the need to give House committees appropriate powers and discretions to conduct their inquiries, whilst ensuring that the rights of witnesses who appear before committees are protected.

The procedures recommended are largely self-explanatory. There are two particular aspects that the report comments on and which I will now draw to the attention of the House. These are the provisions concerning the disclosure of in camera evidence and the expunging of material from the transcript of committee evidence. Paragraphs 6 and 7 of the proposed resolution deal with applications by witnesses for their evidence to be heard in camera, procedures to be followed by committees in dealing with that evidence and its possible publication at a later date.

In camera evidence is taken by committees for a variety of reasons and I will not canvass the wider issues here. The Committee has noted, however, a recent precedent where evidence taken at a private meeting of the Senate Standing Committee on the Environment, Recreation and the Arts was disclosed in a dissent to that Committee's report. I understand there was an earlier precedent relating to the 1984 report of the Senate Select Committee on the Conduct of a Judge. The matter was raised in the Senate on the presentation of the Standing Committee's report last November. During discussion on the matter advice was incorporated that concluded that while the Senate had not explicitly determined the matter, by accepting the report of the 1984 Select Committee and perhaps other reports, the Senate may be said to have tacitly accepted disclosure in certain circumstances. It was stated that a definite contrary decision would have the effect of overturning the precedent.

Members will agree that this is a serious matter and one which could have far reaching repercussions on the relationships between committees and witnesses and the willingness of witnesses to be frank and open in giving evidence. The Procedure Committee has therefore included in the proposed procedures a prohibition on the disclosure, in a protest or a dissent to a report, any evidence taken in camera, unless that disclosure has been authorised by the Committee. The House always has the power to order the production and publication of undisclosed evidence. This matter will be further considered by this Committee in its forthcoming review of the Standing Orders.

The second matter I will comment on is whether there should be a provision included in the procedures that would give a committee the option to expunge evidence from the transcript and forbid its publication. The 1984 recommendation of the Joint Select Committee on Parliamentary Privilege contained such a provision-as did the proposed resolution tabled by the Attorney-General. The paragraph was excluded from the draft circulated by the Clerk. The Committee considered the proposals and the views advanced in submissions it received and has concluded that it is preferable not to include such a provision.

Committees have used this procedure in the past. However, the practice is one that could lead to a situation where some very delicate and important questions of law could arise. The reality could be that, where a person publishes evidence that is subject to an order that it be expunged, neither the committee nor the House would have much control over the situation. This would be especially so if a journalist were to publish evidence either prior to, or in ignorance of, an order of a committee that the evidence be expunged. The Procedure Committee has concluded that, where it is felt that evidence being given is of such a nature that immediate publication may not be appropriate, the Committee should give consideration to taking further evidence in private.

The recommendations contained in this report apply to House committees only. As many honourable members are aware, joint statutory committees have, to varying degrees, their own provisions covering the rights of, and protection of, witnesses. As joint Standing Orders and House Standing Orders make no specific provisions for the treatment of witnesses before joint standing and select committees, and as there are differences between the procedures recommended and those adopted by the Senate, this Committee has concluded that it would be preferable that either a joint resolution be agreed to covering joint committees, or that relevant joint Standing Orders be adopted. An alternative would be to include in resolutions appointing joint committees a direction to follow the procedures agreed to by one or other of the Houses. Let me also remind honourable members that separate procedures will be proposed for the operation of Privilege Committee inquiries.
I would like to thank members of the Committee, the secretariat staff-Mark McRae, and Julia Flynn-and Mr Jim Pender for their assistance on this inquiry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I speak in the capacity of Deputy Chairman of the Standing Committee on Procedure. I wish to thank the House for accepting the Committee's report in the manner in which it has. I also wish to support our Chairman, the honourable member for Banks (Mr Mountford), in his remarks.

SPEECH.PARA: The growth in the committee system in this Parliament over recent years is probably not generally understood by the general public. Between 1901 and the year I arrived in this place, in the late 1960s, there had been an average of some eight reports presented by committees to the Parliament each year. However, between 1976 and 1982 that figure rose to some 76 reports. Currently the committees of the House of Representatives alone are conducting 24 separate inquiries into a diverse range of subjects, sometimes in sensitive and controversial areas. I think it is timely that the House of Representatives, through the Standing Committee on Procedure, has come out with recommendations in the report being presented today regarding the protection of witnesses, the obligation of witnesses and the whole range of matters touched upon by the honourable member for Banks in his capacity as Chairman.

In keeping with my undertaking that this segment would not go beyond 10 minutes, I conclude my remarks. I have no hesitation in thanking the Chairman of the Committee, despite the fact that he belongs to a different political party-in fact, a terribly different party. In the committee system people are able to bury their differences and work together for the betterment of the Parliament and the people of Australia. The Parliament is most supreme in another issue I raised earlier today. I am utterly committed to the rights of the people and of the Parliament. That explains why I get so uptight when sections of the bureaucracy violate their obligations.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT SELECT COMMITTEE ON CORPORATIONS LEGISLATION

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Joint Select Committee on Corporations Legislation, together with the evidence received by the Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the motion of Senator Michael Macklin, the Parliament set up a joint select committee to look at the corporations legislation. It is important that I very briefly sketch the background. The corporate package put before this Parliament was the largest legislative package ever introduced into the Australian Parliament. A committee was set up to examine the impact of that legislation and to receive submissions from around Australia. We have completed that process.

SPEECH.PARA: The process began last year with the call for submissions and we began hearings just after Australia Day of this year. We concluded our deliberations yesterday, so people will appreciate it has been an exercise involving great time pressures and evaluating competing interests: Let me encapsulate it this way: the Joint Select Committee on Corporations Legislation has tried to weigh up the benefits of investor protection and efficiency of the capital market; those two poles have determined the way in which we have considered the legislation.

At the outset I need to compliment my colleagues on the Committee. The Deputy Chairman, Senator Jim Short, through his sensible approach to the Committee, has made it possible for us to work very effectively. In fact, the need to have votes on matters arose only at the latter stage of proceedings and did not trouble us very often at all. My other colleagues were Senator Michael Macklin, Senator Richard Alston, Senator Bob McMullan and Senator Barney Cooney. I also need to recognise my colleagues in this chamber: the honourable member for Denison (Mr Kerr), the honourable member for Herbert (Mr Lindsay), the honourable member for Mallee (Mr Peter Fisher) and the honourable member for Bass (Mr Smith), who will shortly be following me. I thank them very much for their work.

We have completed an enormous task, to which the members have made a major commitment. I often wish people in the electorates could see the hard work and the long hours put in by members. The commitment to the task was enormous. Importantly, members approached their task in a disinterested manner-on the benefits and merits of the case. That manner of approach was what marked the whole proceedings, in my view. We were very ably assisted, under great pressure, by the secretariat: I thank Andrew Snedden, Peter Short, John O'Donovan and Annette Fisher. Their work was very well done and of high standard. They were always there to back us up. Their work has resulted in our now having some documentation to put before the House.

Honourable members will see, from the supporting documents, that we received substantial submissions. We attracted many comments from the Australian business community. Interestingly, in this exercise, a consultation process had been entered into by the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) which was a very far-sighted and intelligent move, for which I compliment him most warmly. That process tended to set up a discussion base which we then had to pick up. The Committee continued that process of consultation. People who felt that they had not had a chance to make an input, did so to the Committee. We have heard many voices. In this game one often hears many voices. We have today, for the Parliament is the summation of those voices.

I do not wish to spend very much time on content because we have an arrangement and I wish to honour that obligation. In essence the Committee has said that there is a need for a national scheme. Australia is a single economy; it is a 24-hour market; Australia is moving rapidly into an international arena. This legislation is very necessary to reflect that change in Australia's status. The notion that we are separate States, in terms of our markets and corporate regulations, is a notion that is in the past. The Committee is talking about today and the future. This fact has to be emphasised.

What also needs to be emphasised is that if we are to have a marketplace which works properly we must have corporate regulations which enable the good players-and the majority of them are-to operate effectively. At the same time, we must provide investor protection. Anyone who looks at the daily share quotations would see that investors at this stage are not very confident in the marketplace. This is not because the marketplace is pervaded by malpractice, but because some people have had their fingers burned, not only in the events of October 1987 but also in other ways. The Committee's view was that it wanted a well-regulated, properly conducted capital market that would work efficiently while at the same time giving guarantees of investor protection. That summarises where the Committee was at.

There are many other related matters I could talk about. Let me list them very briefly. We have come down in favour of minority shareholders in relation to takeovers; we believe they should be protected. We have also suggested that pre-vetting should remain. Why? Because, essentially, we could not find anyone in the professional world who would say, `I will take responsibility for what I put in a prospectus'. As a result of discussions, we said, `If no-one takes responsibility for the content of prospectuses then maybe we should ensure that that responsibility still lies with the regulatory authority'. We have also made recommendations covering a wide range. We have referred to insider trading, but we have suggested that more careful deliberation lies with the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs chaired by the honourable member for Maribyrnong (Mr Griffiths). That deliberation is occurring. We have talked about questions such as business names and company names. We have also referred to fund raising and resources. We have also referred to the shield of the Crown and recommended that that matter be referred to a parliamentary committee for further examination.

In closing, I want to re-emphasise that my colleagues on the Committee, in my view, provided an enormous resource. All of the Committee's work took place in a corporate climate which is changing every day as new events and pressures develop and competing interests have to be evaluated. We have come down with a sensible proposition which says, `Yes, we recognise that there are competing interests in the marketplace. We believe that the time has come for national corporate regulation, which should occur through the Australian Securities Commission. We believe that the Australian Securities Commission needs considerable power and authority, which explains why we have stuck with the unacceptable conduct power resting with the Australian Securities Commission as one of our recommendations. However, the main essence of our recommendations is that we go for an arrangement whereby the NCSC has appropriate powers.

I conclude by again thanking my colleagues. This has been a most demanding exercise, but one which has been productive, and I believe that the Australian Parliament and the business community will benefit from the opportunity we have had to further those discussions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith Mr W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have only a few moments to speak because of the requirements of other speakers in later debates. I first compliment the honourable member for Stirling (Mr Ronald Edwards) on his chairmanship of the Joint Select Committee on Corporations Legislation. He alluded to the fact that this is the biggest legislative package that has ever been brought to this Parliament. This Committee, within a very short time frame, was asked to undertake a massive task which required a great deal of goodwill among all of us. Strong views were expressed, and there were national hearings around the country. To produce the report in the time frame we had and in such detail is a compliment to everyone involved, particularly the Chairman and the staff led by Andrew Snedden, who did a magnificent job.

SPEECH.PARA: The major recommendations of this report have been alluded to by the Chairman. Some of those recommendations go against the Australian Securities Commission Bill that was proposed by the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen), notably those concerning pre-vetting and some aspects of the panel system with regard to the declaratory power. But at the end of the day, in broad principle, what we were looking for was to develop further investor protection, because well-informed markets are the very basic requirement to ensure that we encourage investors to be involved with confidence in those markets. Brief reference was made to insider trading in the report, but there is now another committee, of which I am a member, which will look at insider trading in far more detail.

There is one point I should make before I sit down, and that is that there is a major dissenting report included in this report. The major issue is whether we accept the proposal in this legislation for a full-blown national securities and companies system, with the authority reposed here in Canberra and reject the existing cooperative companies system which is controlled by the Ministerial Council.

In our dissent we went into considerable detail. At the end of the day, we recommend a total rejection of the national scheme that is enshrined in this legislation, and an enhancement of the existing cooperative companies scheme. It is our view that this legislation was conceived in haste. It ignores the federal system. All States, regardless of their political persuasion, made statements to us calling into question this scheme, as it is proposed by the Attorney-General. There are extreme doubts about the constitutional underpinnings that will need to be tested. There have been indications that there will be constitutional challenges to this legislation, which will greatly add to uncertainty in companies and capital and security markets in this country. We believe that ought not to be tolerated. We believe that the Attorney-General is embarking on a legislative process that does not draw to it, given that this is such a central issue in the commercial life of this country, the broad support of the States and, particularly, relevant areas within the markets. For example, the Confederation of Australian Industry, representing 100,000 businesses, is against this scheme. That is to be regretted.

Other proposals which were put forward and discussed need to be rejected. At the end of the day our dissent affirms that the cooperative scheme has served Australia well since its inception nine years ago. In particular, the NCSC has built up an impressive record, and is widely regarded and respected both in Australia and overseas. We recognise that there need to be improvements to and enhancements of the scheme, but we believe that at the end of the day that is a far better direction to take, given that we have the broadest support of all the key players and States in this nation, than to embark on what I have described as a legislative path which will lead to great uncertainty and can be described only as a monumental folly.

It is with regret that we have reached this position, but I felt I should draw that point to the House's attention. The Committee worked well and addressed itself in great detail to all the sections of all the Acts and made recommendations regardless of the fundamental differences of opinion among its members on the key question. It is important to note that. If this legislation is passed it will have benefited from a very detailed scrutiny by a committee which has very diligently addressed itself to very complex issues. The business community may have confidence in the competence of the Parliament to do this type of work, and we have done it well.
Motion (by Mr Ronald Edwards) proposed:
That the House take note of the report.
