DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT COMMITTEE ON FOREIGN AFFAIRS, DEFENCE AND TRADE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charles Mr D.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, I present the Committee's report on Australia's relations with the South Pacific, including the report of the Parliamentary delegation to the South Pacific region during June 1988, together with the minutes of proceedings and evidence received by the Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —The South Pacific region has increasingly been in the headlines over recent times and has thus become the focus of Australian attention as never before. Regional countries, small areas of land in a huge expanse of ocean, have diverse cultural and political structures, but until quite recently the Australian public had a very romanticised view of the region and its people. Successive Australian Governments for many years adopted a benign, paternalistic attitude to the region. Events since the early 1980s have forced a reappraisal of policy towards a region that many people consider `Pacific' no more.

SPEECH.PARA: In early 1988, after reviewing the evidence received at that time, it became apparent that while we had much on Australian perceptions of the region and the relationship, we had little that gave a South Pacific perspective on the relationship. The Committee approached the Hawke Government and received approval to undertake a tour of eight South Pacific countries in June 1988. A report of that delegation, which I had the pleasure of leading, is included at the end of the report.

While I will not be commenting on that trip in great detail here today, I would like to make one or two comments about it. Firstly, the Committee was warmly welcomed in each country visited, and had access to the top political leaders, government officials, business people and academics. The visit provided the Committee with the opportunity not only to participate in candid and detailed discussions with these individuals and groups, but also to visit various Australian aid projects and discuss the needs of the region with those most vitally involved, that is, the people themselves. As we noted in our report:
Although facing a range of geographically-based constraints to their development, many of the South Pacific nations have great potential.
Despite all of the difficulties facing the region, the delegation was struck with the optimism and enthusiasm of the people and their leaders about the future.

The delegation was also struck with the great amount of goodwill and friendliness demonstrated towards Australia. Although difficulties arise in every relationship, the delegation was left with the impression that essentially the Pacific islanders welcomed Australia's interest in the South Pacific and supported Australia's desire to become more closely involved in the development process in the region.

Finally, the visit reinforced the Committee's strongly held belief that personal contacts with the region are vital if the relationship is to grow and mature. There has, unfortunately, been much exaggerated reporting in the Australian press concerning the South Pacific. Therefore, increased contact, and hence a more informed level of debate, is one method of putting the actual situation before the people of Australia.

Accordingly, the Committee has recommended, because of the importance of personal contacts, the appointment of a junior Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade with responsibility for Australia's relations with the South Pacific. The creation of such a position would send a strong signal to South Pacific nations on the level of importance Australia places on the region and our involvement in it.

Before returning to the main report, on behalf of those who travelled might I thank all of those who facilitated our visit to each country, to regional government officials who assisted with local arrangements, Australian diplomatic and aid personnel throughout the region for their assistance, and to 34 Squadron and the crew of the RAAF VIP aircraft who took such excellent care of us during our 14,000-kilometre journey.

The report Australia's Relations with the South Pacific is divided into two main sections. The first, dealing with economic issues, provides an overview of the economic situation of the South Pacific states and the economic relationship with Australia. There is also a section on Australian development assistance to the region, currently some $388m per year, including Papua New Guinea, and identification of a number of areas where Australia has the expertise and experience to assist-in particular in the fields of education, communications, transport, and health. The economic section concludes with a chapter on migration, which I will say more about shortly.

The second section of the report deals with political and security issues and examines such areas as the strategic environment of the region; regional defence and security interests and capabilities; the possible role Australia might take in the region; a number of developments and trends in the region, including the activities of non-South Pacific nations; and recent problems in Melanesian states. It concludes with some remarks about the future of the relationship as we move towards the twenty-first century. The report makes in total 46 specific recommendations across the whole range of Australia-South Pacific relations. These, together with a summary of the major conclusions reached by the Committee, are in a separate section at the front of the report.

I would now like to turn to a number of specific areas that I believe merit special mention here today. Economic security is predominant in the concerns of the countries of the region, reflecting their awareness of the fragility of their economies and vulnerability to outside influences. Economic independence-that is, independence from development assistance-may never be achieved by some of these countries. The region has experienced a decline in general standards of living since the early 1970s, despite high aid flows and privileged access to industrial country markets. Although South Pacific people are not poor by international standards, they are unable to achieve and maintain a standard of living comparable to many Western countries. Most have a poor trade balance and rely on remittances from citizens working overseas and foreign aid as sources of foreign exchange.

The South Pacific nations, to varying degrees, all face constraints to development arising from their geography. With limited resource bases they rely on a small number of agricultural products for export earnings. A lack of sufficiently trained personnel in both the public and private sectors is one of the region's most pressing problems, and is an area where Australia has been making a valuable contribution. However, much remains to be done. There are deficiencies not only in the technical and vocational levels of education, for both the public and the private sector, but also at the primary and secondary levels of education. Common difficulties in the region include acute shortages of textbooks and other learning materials, a shortage of schools and underqualified teachers.

The Committee makes a number of specific recommendations in the field of education, including a separate training allocation for technical education aimed exclusively at the private sectors of these countries, and the introduction of an Australian teacher volunteer program. A number of large infrastructural projects, some in the educational field, have been undertaken under Australian development assistance. Whilst these projects have generally been of immense value to the recipient country, they have at times had a negative effect on their economies because of their associated high recurrent costs. The impact of these recurrent costs must be assessed by donor and recipient countries prior to a decision being taken to proceed with the project. If the project is given sufficiently high priority by both Australia and the recipient country, the Australian Government should consider sharing the responsibility of these costs with that country. The Committee has recommended that the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau (AIDAB) provide part of the recurrent costs of its aid projects as part of the aid budget for some regional countries.

I would like to mention one area that was often brought to the attention of the Committee, not only in submissions but also during the visit to the region. That area is migration. Although the number of migrants to Australia drawn from the South Pacific region has increased over recent years, it still represents only 2.5 per cent of the global intake of settlers annually. There have been calls from regional countries for many years for a liberalisation of Australia's immigration policy, not only for permanent migration but also for a guest worker scheme similar to that operated by New Zealand. After much investigation the Committee rejected the suggestion that Australia follow New Zealand's lead and institute such a scheme. The Australian Government has rejected requests for liberalisation of the migration policy to date because it held such action to be inconsistent with the non-discriminatory nature of Australia's immigration policy. The Committee has no argument with this policy. However, there are various arguments about the economic benefits of migration and in particular the importance of remittances from South Pacific islanders residing overseas as a source of foreign exchange for their countries.

The Committee is sympathetic to the aspirations of Pacific island nations that their citizens gain access to the labour markets of the more developed nations in the region and has recommended that the Australian Government, in conjunction with private enterprise, establish a work experience program for South Pacific countries, with the responsibility of the program being with the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. The program would fund a specific number of South Pacific islanders from both the private and public sectors to work in Australia and receive training in basic technical and management skills over a maximum period of two years. The skills the trainees develop must be able to be transposed back into their society on return. Training should concentrate on developing skills in areas such as the electrical trades, mechanics, plumbing, public works, and basic trade skills and administration.

The Committee envisages each country being given a quota. In consideration of the special circumstances of Kiribati and Tuvalu, as discussed in our report, the Committee strongly believes these two countries should be given a larger quota of trainees than would otherwise be determined if criteria such as population levels were to be used. Given the limited prospects of improvement in the economic situation of the smaller Pacific island countries in particular, I commend this recommendation to the Government on strong foreign policy and humanitarian grounds and, as recommended, the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans), and not the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, should have carriage of and responsibility for this program.

Any discussion on the South Pacific over the last two years would be incomplete without reference to events in Fiji, one of the most important South Pacific states. (Extension of time granted) I believe it is important to note that in Fiji we are facing an evolving situation; one that is not static, but is continuing to develop and change. When members of the Committee visited Fiji in June 1988 we had extensive discussions with the interim Government, members of the deposed coalition and trade union and business figures. We visited at a time when the discovery of an arms cache was uppermost in the minds of the Government and security forces, and the internal security decree had just been announced-indeed, on the very day we arrived. The delegation put very forcefully to the interim Government its total opposition to this decree and attempts to restrict the basic human rights of all Fijian citizens, be they of Indian or Fijian origin. In our discussions the interim Government was at pains to stress that it saw itself as having two basic aims-repair of the economy and reform of the Constitution. It was the second of these aims that occupied much of the Committee's attention during and following the visit.

A draft Constitution was released in September 1988 and the Committee has commented on that draft in some detail in the report. Progress in finalising the Constitution has not been as rapid as hoped, and the timetable of elections in the latter half of 1989, spelled out by Prime Minister Ratu Mara, appears to be in some doubt.

The military coups in Fiji in 1987 presented the Australian Government with its biggest dilemma in the history of regional relations. The Committee rejected outright the idea that Australia should have intervened militarily on behalf of the deposed Government. Such action would have set a dangerous precedent and irrevocably damaged our relations not only with Fiji but with other South Pacific countries. There are obvious limits to the extent to which Australia can exert influence in the region in support of the democratic and humanitarian values that Australia espouses.

In early 1988 Australia sought to normalise relations with Fiji and reinstitute the civil aid program that was in place before the coups. The Committee had no problems with this. However, the promised provision of an additional $10m linked to `political, constitutional, economic and social developments in Fiji, including human rights' was most unfortunate for a number of reasons. By giving such a major increase to Fiji over and above its usual annual allocation, our aid program in the South Pacific has been distorted. It has also sent an unintentional message to those democratic South Pacific nations who only received their usual moderate increase in aid in that financial year. Of course, what must also be remembered is that Australia, in making the aid conditional on improvements in the internal situation in Fiji, is asking of that country far more than it does from a number of recipients of Australian aid beyond our immediate region. Australia has continued to give official development assistance to some countries around the world despite evidence of human rights abuses and non-democratic practices.

In concluding my remarks on Fiji, may I say that it was significant that the Committee was able to meet with the full Cabinet for some two and a half hours. The fact that we were able to discuss many important and difficult subjects was in itself an important step forward and showed the maturity of the relationship between our two countries. Time does not permit me to go into the many other areas of the report-transport and communications, the role of Radio Australia in the region, health, environmental problems such as the greenhouse effect, the political and strategic circumstances of the region, and so on. For anyone interested in Australia-South Pacific relations, I refer them to the report and the wealth of information it contains.

It remains for me, as Chairman of the South Pacific Subcommittee, to record my appreciation of the efforts of members of the Subcommittee who worked extremely hard over a long period of time on what proved to be a most interesting and topical inquiry. On behalf of the Subcommittee, might I also express our thanks to all who presented evidence and submissions to the inquiry. Over 4,000 pages of evidence were collected and a vast amount of information regarding the many facets of Australian-South Pacific relations.

Finally, I thank the Committee secretariat including the main Committee secretary, Mr Peter Gibson, Mrs Margaret Gibson and Mrs Marlene Lyons for their support throughout the inquiry, and, in particular, the secretary to the Subcommittee, Mrs Joanne Towner, whose work for the Committee throughout the inquiry and myself as Chairman was invaluable. I commend this report to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the Chairman of the Subcommittee on the South Pacific, the honourable member for Isaacs (Mr Charles), has said, the report entitled Australia's Relations with the South Pacific is important to the Australian Parliament. It is in the great tradition of the reports from the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade. When we have a look at the regions around Australia, obviously this area is of particular importance to this nation simply because it is so close and, again, because in relative terms Australia is so important to the small nations of the South Pacific. We tend to think of them as being roughly equivalent. But, of course, they are not. One only has to read the report to see the differences which are apparent between the various nations of the South Pacific. There are differences in development, potential, political organisations and political development.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not want to go into the details of the report itself except to say that it is a very comprehensive report. Not only does it put forward some realistic recommendations, 46 of them-I do not propose to rank them in order of priority for a moment because I believe that they are all important-but the report stands on its own as a significant source document for the future. It is important that more and more Australians understand more fully the region surrounding this country because, as I have already said, Australia's influence in that region is most significant.

I mention a couple of the impressions that one gets from travelling around the region which make it unique. Firstly, the influence of the Christian religion on the development and in the future development of the various nations is without comparison anywhere else in the world. There is a very strong influence through organised religion in the South Pacific nations. Too many people do not take that into consideration in their analysis of events that take place in these various countries.

The other element I found-this was also mentioned by the Chairman of the Subcommittee in his remarks-was the influence of the Australian media in reporting in Australia on events in the region. Those reports have a massive effect in those countries being reported upon. As in so many instances, the Australian media overseas is viewed, in many cases, with some distaste. These countries do not understand the element of press freedom which operates in Australia. They cannot understand how the government of the day, no matter of which political complexion it may be, allows some of the things which are written and broadcast to be written or broadcast. It is important that members of the Australia media understand and, I hope, accept more responsibility in some of the statements that they make about events within the various countries of the South Pacific region. What they say has a profound effect and, in many cases, an adverse effect on Australia's relations with those countries.

The other factor which came to me during the trip, particularly around the South Pacific, was the changing relationship due to some of the costs of living in Australia which have escalated very rapidly in recent times. I am thinking particularly of the students from the South Pacific countries who have traditionally, in many cases, been educated within Australia at Australian boarding schools, particularly along our east coast. What a number of people are finding in Australia and in the South Pacific countries is that it is simply too expensive for students to be boarded in Australia and sent to Australian schools. This may be a minor matter but it has a great deal of importance because the personal relationships built up between young Australians and young Pacific islanders during those formative years have been of enormous significance in our relationships with the countries concerned when the individuals come to positions of prominence within their own countries. That aspect needs to be addressed with more sensitivity than has been the case in the past. I hope that Australian schools which have the capacity to offer scholarships or bursaries to Pacific island residents should contemplate doing that and providing places for students from these countries as part of Australia's continuing relationships with the various countries.

One of the interesting aspects of the development of the political independence of the nations of the South Pacific has been the difficulty which is usually associated with the movement or transfer of power from that significant political individual who was responsible in a very large sense for the attaining of independence to his or her successors. It seems that there has been quite a constant difficulty in countries when, having got through that first difficult stage of the move to independence-the continuing process of political development-they find that in that first transfer of power from that initial leadership there seems to be present in many cases some real causes for difficulties. We have seen that occurring in a number of countries within the South Pacific area.

Overall, the main impression that one receives is the very warm welcome that individuals get from the citizens of the South Pacific countries as individuals and the very real reliance that they place on personal contact and a continuity of personal contact. If there is one thing that I, as a member of this Parliament, would like to see, it is that individual members of this Parliament should not fly over the South Pacific on their way to other countries in other parts of the world; they really should get to know their own region first or get to know it at the same time as they are travelling to other parts of the world. We need continuing contact between members of this Parliament and the significant political and economic leaders in the countries of the South Pacific. That personal contact is enormously important to them. It can only be developed not just by a fleeting once only visit but by a continuing friendly contact.

As the Chairman has said, it is an important report. The members of the Committee worked hard. We had a most interesting trip. We were extremely well received which augurs well for Australia's future relationships with the region. We need that greater amount of education and understanding of the individuals and personalities involved in each of the countries. We need to recognise the diversity of the countries and to make sure that we have that continuing contact.

DEBATE.TITLE: SALES TAX (EXEMPTIONS AND CLASSIFICATIONS) AMENDMENT BILL 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Prosser.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prosser Mr G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I remind the House that this is not the first time the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill has been presented. It is almost 12 months since I first introduced the Bill, to allow sales tax exemptions on four-wheel drive vehicles and some motorcycles used by professional fishermen. I repeat that this legislation is a long overdue reform of the sales tax law to give fishermen a small but significant concession on equipment that is an integral part of their industry.

SPEECH.PARA: There should not be any need to explain further the background of the Bill. The merit of sales tax exemption on four-wheel drive vehicles used by commercial fishermen has been widely documented. In fact, honourable members will recall that, in addition to my own briefing papers, they have been lobbied extensively by individual fishermen as well as industry groups from around Australia. So why is the Bill being reintroduced today? We do not have to look any further than the Government benches to find the answer. The Government has treated the fishing industry with contempt over this important issue. The Government gave the impression that it supported the legislation by allowing it to progress to the second reading stage. But just when the fishing industry believed there was a real chance of success the Government scuttled the Bill.

Using its numbers on the Selection Committee, the Government stopped the Bill from being voted on in the House before it lapsed. That saved a number of Government members the embarrassment of voting against legislation that was justified and sensible and would have been of tremendous benefit to the Australian fishing industry. The honourable member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Snow) represents a significant sector of the fishing industry in New South Wales and he actually supported the Bill during the second reading debate.

The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) has a responsibility to consider seriously the needs of the fishing industry. Yet, when asked to support the amendment, the Minister trotted out the standard, completely inadequate reply prepared by the office of the Treasurer (Mr Keating). Part of the Minister's response is worth repeating here. He wrote:
It is not apparent how such vehicles are necessary in commercial fishing activities.

The Minister either knows nothing about modern fishing operations or has not taken any interest in this Bill at all. In any case, if the Minister had thoughts of supporting the Bill they would have been squashed by the Treasurer.

It is widely known that the Treasurer opposed the legislation from the beginning, forcing his colleagues into a similar view. But there was no immediate attempt to reject the Bill. The decision to allow debate, but not a vote, was a cruel hoax on the fishing industry. The Government finally showed its hand on 2 March when the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) advised me that the Bill was not a Government initiative and the Government would not support it.

The Government's underhanded attitude is not surprising in view of its record of broken promises. On this very point of sales tax exemption on four-wheel drive vehicles, the Government has broken a promise it made to the fishing industry in 1982. At that time, just before the 1983 election, it was part of the Australian Labor Party platform to treat the fishing industry as a primary industry in existing and future legislation. Yet the agricultural sector is still the only primary industry to enjoy sales tax exemption on four-wheel drive vehicles. This low cost tax concession would have given commercial fishermen a real boost and provided the Government with an opportunity to recognise the value of their industry. Instead, the Government has effectively told fishermen that it has no commitment to their future.
Bill read a first time.

DEBATE.TITLE: CANBERRA AND SOUTH EASTERN REGIONAL ADVISORY COUNCIL

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snow Mr J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock) will second this motion. At his instigation, I ask leave of the House to amend the motion standing in my name on the Notice Paper by omitting the word `form' and substituting the word `encourage'.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House acknowledges that Canberra-Queanbeyan is a natural regional centre and that Canberra and the South Eastern Region of NSW are interdependent, calls on the first ACT Government to encourage a Canberra and South Eastern Regional Advisory Council composed of federal, State, territory and local council representatives with the aim of co-ordinating planning and development within the region.

The Australian Capital Territory has grown from a Public Service appendage to Queanbeyan to a natural regional centre, with Queanbeyan, towns such as Yass and villages such as Sutton, Murrumbateman, Bungendore and Captain's Flat. True, Canberra is the nation's capital. The people of south-eastern New South Wales have, with their cars, their money, their feet and their desires, also chosen Canberra and Queanbeyan as a centre for shopping, health, education, welfare and many other services.

Great things and confusing things are happening in the region. Combined, these pressures point to the need for a body to coordinate planning infrastructure, development and services in Canberra and the south-eastern region of New South Wales. There has been cooperation, tolerance and understanding across the border. Canberra and Queanbeyan have a good liaison on a Public Service level. The pressures now mean that unofficial liaison is not good enough. The first pressure is population. In New South Wales we ask whether Gungahlin will be Canberra's last large-scale housing development. We ask whether Canberra will need, once more, to talk about a Y plan expanding to the north-east and the north-west.

Successive New South Wales governments have refused to entertain the idea of handing land over to the Australian Capital Territory. There are other alternatives which I believe the Australian Capital Territory ought to be considering. There is no reason why State and local authorities on our side of the border cannot talk with Canberra about a coordinated population expansion outside the Territory and discuss all those infrastructure, development and social needs at an official level.

Queanbeyan is changing as Canberra changes from a company town, a Public Service town, to a centre for Australia's business groups and national associations. In recent years new buildings have been erected for organisations such as the National Farmers Federation and the Salvation Army and a wide range of businesses which are now settling in Canberra and Queanbeyan. We have enterprising families in Queanbeyan such as the Macks and the Jamiesons with their outdoor gear being in demand around the world. We have award winning advertising firms, such as Ideas and Images, computer hardware and software firms and a wide range of other firms in Queanbeyan and Canberra.

Tourism has brought changes. Well over one million tourists visited Parliament House in its first few months. We have other attractions in Canberra. Tralee of Queanbeyan, the Snowy Mountains and the south-east coast have overseas and local tourists thronging to them daily. The Public Service itself has had profound effects on the region, both beneficial and dubious, as always happens with large industries. Public servants use the region's roads, hospitals, resorts, homes and other people who are providing services in the region. Public servants form a major part of the region's economy. Some of them have a problem with their psychological attitudes about working over the border in New South Wales. But the city of Queanbeyan now houses hundreds of State, Federal, local and private sector personnel in its offices after they were largely empty between 1977 and 1983. These great changes-the development towards a stronger private sector, more tourism and a growing Public Service presence outside Canberra-are bringing pressures.

Infrastructure pressures have been subject to decades of buck passing. Who is responsible for the Kings Highway from Canberra-Queanbeyan to Bateman's Bay? I will not go into the argument now, but the Australian Capital Territory, New South Wales and local councils have been embroiled in the controversy since Robert G. Menzies provided for surfacing of the road about 30 years ago with a stipulation that the State maintain it. Canberra people are the main users of the Kings Highway. Roads in the region need to be dealt with by an official cross-border advisory coordinating body.

New South Wales residents have been worried by the likely closure of a road into the Australian Capital Territory at Gungahlin. Links between the coast and the mountains need to be developed, such as the Nowra-Braidwood-Cooma link and the Pambula-Bombala link. I have a wide range of representations putting forward strong evidence that Canberra will benefit from a strengthening of those links. The present link between Braidwood and Nowra is, at times, impassable; yet it would be a great and important contact between Canberra and the coast. It would provide an alternative to the Kings Highway for people who need to get to the coast. Its gradient is better and it would be an excellent alternative route for transporting goods from areas such as Goulburn, farming areas, to the port of Kembla. The Pambula-Bombala link will be a very important link if the very fast train project eventuates, which is becoming more and more likely, and provide an excellent alternative access to the present Brown Mountain connection.

It is interesting that an electorate of about 30,000 square kilometres is not all that easy to service. Commercial travellers and business people do not find it easy to service because there are only two satisfactory links between the high areas of Canberra-Queanbeyan and Cooma, and the coast. Alternative Braidwood-Nowra and Bombala-Pambula links would remove the need to drastically alter the Brown Mountain and Clyde Mountain connections.

With the inevitable population pressures outside Canberra, we need an official body to deal with water, sewerage and other development requirements. State, local and ACT representation is essential. Federal representation is essential because of the problems Queanbeyan people are having with air flight paths and the other effects of Canberra's role as a national capital. Already there have been development problems across the border. Canberra queried Queanbeyan's Jerrabomberra development after its announcement. Queanbeyan queried a major accommodation, shopping and petrol retailing development which would draw tourists from Queanbeyan. Queanbeyan queried the development after its announcement. An official coordinating body is plainly needed so that planning proposals can be placed before it at the appropriate time.

I suggest, without trying to dictate the structure, that as a part of the ongoing debate we should be thinking about a combined New South Wales, Federal and local government committee. The New South Wales and Federal governments produced a south-east region strategy plan in the 1970s and recently the New South Wales Department of Environment and Planning reported on relationships and planning issues between the Australian Capital Territory and the region. It seems to me that we need to get away from the ad hoc, unofficial contact of the past and set up a body which could be summarised as a Canberra and south-eastern regional advisory council.

Whether the membership should consist just of elected people, or of servants as well, needs to be worked out and discussed by the various bodies involved. Certainly, it should have representation from local government, the State government, the ACT Government and the Federal Government because of the issues and problems which I have raised. Servants as well as those elected should be on either the same tier or second tier, and a relationship should be established with the New South Wales government body, the South East Industry Development Board. The organisation needs to be able to call in people from businesses, business organisations, chambers of commerce and unions as appropriate.

It is appropriate for the ACT Legislative Assembly, as a new legislature, to initiate my suggestion. I believe that such a body is absolutely essential because Canberra-Queanbeyan and the region around Canberra form a natural regional centre, servicing right down to the Victorian border, west to areas such as Wagga, and as far north as Young, Crookwell and Goulburn. I ask the House to support the motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion. I thank the honourable member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Snow) for clarifying the role of the first Australian Capital Territory Government. Undoubtedly it should play a role in calling for the establishment of such an advisory body as suggested by the honourable member but, clearly, if it is to utilise the services of the Federal Government and involve State government and local council representatives, the Australian Capital Territory Legislative Assembly could not establish such a body of its volition.

SPEECH.PARA: In speaking to the motion and supporting it, I want to make a number of points not to contradict in any way what the honourable member said, but rather to indicate that the nature of the problems we face is very much a product of our history. All too often arrangements for government have to be looked at in the context of the decisions that have been taken by our forebears. There is something unique about Canberra and the Australian Capital Territory. Few places in the world have national capitals where the responsibility for all the decision-making has rested largely in the hands of a national government. It is only in recent times that we have seen the first attempt at devolution of much of the decision-making for Canberra from the national Parliament to a new local government body in the Australian Capital Territory. The experiment, in that sense, has not been without its own trauma and difficulties.

The only other national capital in a federation whose national government takes responsibility for the national capital is Washington, DC. There was no attempt to form a provincial government for the District of Columbia; rather a city government was established for Washington. Australia went for a different model. We went for a territorial government in the Australian Capital Territory, where a greater range of decision-making responsibilities have been devolved. Washington has faced the problem which the Australian Capital Territory will face. The growth of the City of Washington has been such that people who work in the city and see it as their home have not been able to be accommodated in it. That situation will arise in the Australian Capital Territory in the not too distant future. A large number of people who work in Washington live in the nearby State of Maryland. People commute to the District of Columbia from outlying States. The outlying States have a substantial portion of their activities centred on the extension of the national capital, but the decisions are not made by the national government.

Such a situation will arise in the Australian Capital Territory in the not too distant future because so much of the Australian Capital Territory is not suitable for land development. Once the Gungahlin development has been largely completed we will have to look at development in New South Wales to accommodate Canberra's growth. Queanbeyan has been doing that rather naturally. Over time we have seen the development of hobby farms in the areas surrounding Canberra and much of Canberra's growth impacts upon New South Wales. We have not been able to take up the model of, say, Canada. The capital, Ottawa city, falls within two provinces or states of Canada. The provision of most of the services, the normal planning functions and the like, is assumed by the two provinces into which the capital is divided-Quebec and Ontario. To carry out the national capital functions Canada has had to develop a national capital commission which has the responsibility of providing the infrastructure for the capital itself, but Ottawa has its own mayor and the mayor's responsibilities are to the province. So we do see different models which may have been more appropriate for Canberra as it grows in the future.

But that is not the situation we have in Canberra today. Canberra is growing within a territory that will not be able to accommodate its needs. We have to develop new relationships with both New South Wales and the local government authorities to take into account Canberra's growth. I think it will be particularly important that an advisory council be established with each of the bodies mentioned-the Federal government participating because of its overall responsibilities, the Australian Capital Territory new legislature, when established, participating in it with its government and the local councils that we have in this region. For that reason the honourable member is to be commended for involving this Parliament in suggesting to the various New South Wales authorities and to the new Australian Capital Territory Government that there is a positive role for it to play in this planning function.

I also commend the honourable member for raising particularly the question of the Kings Highway. It is a road which is of the utmost importance to the people of the Australian Capital Territory. While there may have been expectations when earlier Commonwealth governments played a role in the development of that highway, it is a fact that we have seen the inability of various governments in New South Wales to provide the resources for the development of the Kings Highway. It is a road that has fallen into substantial disrepair. I think it is a disgrace that that road has deteriorated to that extent. It is a risk to the lives of many people who have to travel on it frequently, and people in the Australian Capital Territory do. I think that there is a need for discussions and for the Commonwealth that does provide moneys for roads to ensure that some of the resources that are available are provided for the restoration of this particular roadway. It has been a fact that the roads to Canberra in one form or another have not matched the development of Canberra itself and the people who come by road frequently are at risk. In this context I think that the advisory council that is established ought to take upon itself the role of being a spur to those who have the responsibility of providing the resources to ensure that this road is restored to its proper role for the people of the Australian Capital Territory.
I commend the honourable member for raising this matter at this time. I hope that the new Government of the Australian Cappital Territory will play a positive role in this advisory body.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shipton Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House:
(1) notes the serious deterioration in relations between Australia and Portugal; and
(2) calls on the Government to devise and implement a diplomatic strategy to improve our political and economic links with Portugal.

As the motion I have put before the House states, there has been a serious deterioration in relations between Australia and Portugal. I call on the Australian Government to devise and implement a diplomatic strategy to improve particularly our political and economic links with Portugal.

The Australian Government is guilty of neglect. It has neglected our foreign relationship with Portugal, a member of the European Economic Community and an important European power. I believe that it is a foreign policy failure of some significance by the Australian Government which, basically, Australians are unaware of. Portugal is a long way away-15,000 kilometres. The history of our relationship is that we are really unaware of each other in the world, but that does not make any less serious what is happening in international forums or the decline and deterioration in relations between our two countries. Relations with Portugal are at an all-time low. I believe that this has important political, economic and diplomatic implications for Australia.

The Portuguese deliberately ignored and snubbed our bicentenary year. Honourable members might remember that we had visits by many Prime Ministers and Presidents. The King and Queen of Spain which is on the Iberian Peninsula, the country next door to Portugal, visited Australia but there was not a word from Portugal; it ignored us. Its tall ship was conveniently being repaired somewhere.

Portugal will not allow senior government officials to visit Australia and it certainly will not allow senior Australian Government officials to visit Portugal. A ministerial visit either way certainly could not be contemplated. The cause of this deterioration in relations with Portugal is Australia's relations with Indonesia, particularly over East Timor. The Portuguese still claim to have a moral, administrative and legal responsibility for East Timor, 14 years after the Indonesian annexation of that territory.

As the House knows, Australia formally recognises Indonesia's sovereignty over the former Portuguese colony. Portugal chooses to punish Australia for this and has no understanding of the Australian-Indonesian relationship. It does not make any attempt to understand that relationship, nor do members of the Portuguese Parliament attempt to understand the relationship that Australia has with Indonesia. The relationship has its difficulties from time to time and is based on geography.

The Indonesian-Australian relationship is very important. We have just had a very successful ministerial visit from Minister Alatas of Indonesia. Portugal chooses not to understand our relations and punishes us for them. The centre of the current difficulties with Portugal is the negotiations between Australia and Indonesia concerning the so-called Timor Gap boundary between Indonesia and Australia, the relations between those two countries and the negotiations that are occurring concerning the Timor Gap boundary. The negotiations are well developed between officials of the two countries to develop a unique concept, zone of cooperation in that so-called Timor Gap. Portugal is upset about this because, as I said, it still claims to have moral, administrative and legal responsibility, 14 years after the Indonesian annexation.

The Australian Government does not seem to be aware of, or even slightly concerned about-it is totally oblivious-this serious state of affairs with Portugal, a European power, a member of the European Community with members in the European Parliament. Any agreement between Indonesia and Australia could end up in the International Court of Justice. Portugal may well take Australia to that forum if there is not a settlement beforehand between Portugal and Indonesia. Portuguese-Indonesian relations are very strained indeed.

As I have stated, the Portuguese Government is critical of Australia in international forums. Just as important is the fact that all political parties in Portugal are critical of Australia. Parliamentarians of all parties in Portugal, in Lisbon, use Australia's relations with Indonesia as a domestic political football. Because we in Australia are unaware of what is happening in Portugal-we do not read Portuguese daily newspapers-it is fun for the Portuguese to play politics at our expense. But it is a very dangerous game. It has the potential to damage Australia in the forums of Europe at a time when it is important for Australia to achieve breakthroughs on the trade front in Europe. We do not want to be damaged and badmouthed by a country such as Portugal in those forums at this very important time of trying to break down the world's trade barriers and get access to European markets.

Portugal is actively campaigning against Indonesia in international forums. Not only are we getting caught in the cross-fire but we are being fired at ourselves. The Portuguese are using their membership of the Community to push their point of view against Indonesia. In doing that they are critical of Australia. The Portuguese members of the European Parliament are using their membership of that Parliament to pass resolutions critical of Indonesia.

I think the Portuguese Government is adopting a cynical and hypocritical approach in its criticism of Australia, in its treatment of Australia in international relations. The United States Government has exactly the same policy towards Indonesia as Australia has, yet relations between Portugal and the United States are very good indeed. It just goes to show that, because the Australian Government has ignored the question, has failed to do anything about it and to protest to Lisbon, to develop and devise the strategy I have talked about to improve relations between Australia and Portugal, the Portuguese Government has got away with it for many years.

Now is the time for the Australian Government to do something. We need to upgrade relations with Portugal. A massive diplomatic effort is needed. In the short term we need to upgrade and reinforce the resources available to our ambassador in Lisbon. A new Australian Ambassador has been appointed. He has just arrived in Lisbon. I am sure that he will do a good job for Australia. But he needs assistance because the Australian Government proposes that he be the only diplomatic officer in that post to handle every matter-relations with the Government and relations with the Parliament. He needs diplomatic support. At least two diplomatic officers need to be posted to Lisbon in the immediate short term to support the new Australian Ambassador as part of a strategy to upgrade relations with Lisbon.

Additionally, I believe that our ambassador in Brussels needs to lobby hard for Australia in the European Community. As part of the strategy the matter also needs to be taken up by our ambassador at the United Nations. It needs to be taken up directly with the Portuguese ambassador there. We need to lobby other European powers and non-European powers to make them aware of the situation and Australia's interests. A major diplomatic effort is needed, as I have stated in my motion, to upgrade relations in Portugal. Basically there is goodwill between the two countries, as there should be. But the Portuguese Government is cynical, as are the parliamentarians of that country. I repeat: a major diplomatic effort is needed as part of a strategy to upgrade and improve diplomatic relations between Australia and Portugal.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I second the motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lamb Mr A.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased that the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Shipton) has raised this matter in the Parliament, as it gives us an opportunity to discuss it. I congratulate him. I am sure that his concern about this issue is not shared by John Elliott or Mr Costello. They would not see this issue as their top priority. The relationship between two countries is not based around a sole issue. Matters of common interest between countries would be the law of the sea, trade relationships, human rights, decolonisation and so on.

SPEECH.PARA: Australia has a relatively healthy relationship with Portugal, as evidenced by the fact that Portugal has an embassy in Canberra and Australia has an embassy in Lisbon. So we have the top level of diplomatic relationships. In fact, we have had an ambassador to Portugal since 1969 with diplomatic representation resident since 1970. We have had several visits by Australian Ministers. Mr Hayden visited Portugal in 1984; the former Minister for Trade and present Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) visited that country in 1986; and the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) and the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones) visited there in 1987.

Our relations with Portugal are friendly, if not particularly extensive, but they are improving. We share common views on the maintenance of Western security and on many other international issues. Our two countries have a history of cooperation, both internationally and bilaterally. In May 1988 the two countries completed a round of successful negotiations with the initialling of a bilateral agreement on reciprocal health care. The extradition treaty came into force on 29 August last year. In November last year talks in Canberra on a bilateral social security agreement led to the initialling of a draft text. This will be further developed into a working agreement in due course, a particularly important matter for the 40,000 Portuguese resident in Australia-not an insignificant number to come from a small European country.

Our trade with Portugal is modest but it is growing. Portugal presents a number of advantages for Australian entrepreneurs which are yet to be exploited. The Australian Embassy has identified opportunities for the expansion of Australia-Portugal relations in the field of commodity exports. I understand that Portugal's energy requirements are supplied almost totally by imports and that Portugal wishes to increase its coal usage from 6 per cent to over 25 per cent of energy sources by the year 2000. This gives Australia a great opportunity to increase its exports of steaming coal in the future. Grain and meat exports could expand in spite of European Economic Community (EEC) restrictions. Portugal will remain a major food importer and much of its requirements could be met by non-EEC suppliers, such as Australia. The current balance of trade between the countries could not be more even. In 1987-88, exports to Portugal were worth $46.3m. Imports were worth $47m, consisting mainly of cork and cork products, pulp and waste paper and so on. So we have an even balance of trade.

Australians are great admirers of Portugal's sporting prowess. We have much in common in this area, particularly in long distance running. In the marathon in particular we have respect for record holder Carlos Lopez and for Rosa Mota, who beat our own Lisa Martin in Seoul. We could develop our relations more in the sporting area. I suggest that the Australian Government invite those long distance runners from Portugal to compete in Australia against our best.

I had the opportunity, as did the honourable member for Higgins to visit Lisbon in the middle of last year. I was impressed by the people, their colour and their friendliness and by the determination of their elected representatives to see Portugal emerge and develop under democracy since the rejection of the dictatorship by the people in 1974. Australia has welcomed that jump from what was initially a fragile transition period to what has now turned into a more settled democracy. Australia and Portugal share many common views internationally, including the maintenance of Western security. We appreciate Portugal's cooperation in disarmament matters and would like to encourage Portuguese efforts in the introduction of chemical weapons export precursor controls.

Portugal has been a member of the European Economic Community for two or three years. Australia maintains very detailed negotiations with the EEC on a whole range of trade related matters. We reject the actual charge in this motion that there has been a serious deterioration in relations between Portugal and Australia. All of what I have said indicates that Australia, on a wide front, has formed the basis of a solid, continuing and vibrant relationship. That is not to say that there are not ups and downs within that relationship. This occurs between any two countries and if it did not occur one could say that the relationship was somewhat less than real.

There are great opportunities for the Portugal-Australian relationship to grow further. The honourable member for Higgins has correctly pointed to some of those opportunities. Australia and Portugal have only one significant negotiatory problem at the moment: the question of East Timor and the Timor Gap. It is a major area of difference, but it is bridgeable. I would go so far as to suggest that this question actually offers an opportunity for Australia to forge closer political links with Portugal. That is a line which the honourable member for Higgins has also put forward.

The Australian Government, in common with the Opposition, recognises the sovereign authority of Indonesia over East Timor-I hold major differences with that attitude. But the Government's attitude was made clear and indisputable in this House in an answer by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to a question by the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock) on 22 August 1985. The Prime Minister said that Australia recognised the incorporation of East Timor by and the sovereignty over East Timor of Indonesia. Just as importantly, he pointed out that the Australian Government had worked very closely with the Portuguese Government and the United Nations to see a negotiated settlement of the problem. Australia can contribute more, I believe, in acting as a broker, go-between, or communicator, between Portugal and Indonesia, so that the United Nations General Assembly Resolution 37/30 is successfully brought to a conclusion. That resolution seeks a comprehensive settlement, through negotiations, to the East Timor question. To do that successfully, Australia must, however, acknowledge the Portuguese position-perhaps not agree with it, but acknowledge it. Portugal has a constitutional requirement to decolonisation.

When I was in Lisbon, I met with the President of Portugal, Dr Mario Soares. He sees it as his constitutional obligation to see successful decolonisation of East Timor. I met with the parliamentary commission on East Timor, an all-parliamentary commission, which seeks an answer to the question. All its members emphasised the same constitutional responsibility of the Parliament. This Government should also give some recognition to the Portuguese position, under the decision of the United Nations Security Council, that Portugal is still the administrator of East Timor. We have here a clash of the practical view of Indonesian occupation of East Timor held by Australia and the view that is held internationally. However, I believe that Portugal and Australia must work out their differences so that they, in turn, can negotiate more successfully with Indonesia to implement the United Nations General Assembly Resolution 37/30.

On Timor Gap itself there are certain legal questions. While the Australian Government maintains that there has been no breach of international law, in negotiating with Indonesia, Portugal contests that view and has indicated that it may well take the matter to the International Court of Justice. As the honourable member for Higgins suggested, there should be far more serious talks on this international legal question and the question should be resolved before we get that far.

I also believe that Australia might well support a visit to East Timor by an Australian parliamentary delegation. I would be willing, as would the honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Snowdon) and the honourable member for Hughes (Mr Tickner), to be a member of that delegation. I suggest that it be an all-party delegation. I am awaiting a response, through Mr Roesman, the Indonesian Ambassador to Australia, to the request to visit East Timor I made to Mr Alatas, the Foreign Minister of Indonesia, when he visited Australia.

There are several opportunities open to the Australian Government, not only to resolve this lingering question of difference between Portugal and us, but also to improve relationships generally in trade, sport and international legal questions between the two countries.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time allotted for the debate has expired. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scholes The Hon G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That:

(1) the disposal of glass products in any public area in the ACT and Territories under the direct control of the Commonwealth, other than in an appropriate authorised collection or dumping area, shall be a serious offence;

(2) persons convicted of such an offence shall be liable to a penalty of not less than 8 hours of supervised rubbish clearing in public areas in the Territory, not including time taken to travel to the site;
(3) where the offence includes the deliberate breakage of glass products, the sentence shall be a minimum of 24 hours actual time;
(4) recurring offences after the initial conviction will attract a doubling of the penalty on each occasion; and
(5) this House recommends that the self-governing Territories and the States enact similar legislation.

The motion which is on the Notice Paper reflects a very serious concern for me and for many Australians; that is, the amount of broken glass products accumulating throughout almost all public areas and many private areas of Australia. The motion calls for the Commonwealth to legislate in respect of its Territories. The ACT, which is included in this motion, would now be a matter for legislation by the assembly which is being elected. The motion also calls for the Commonwealth to raise the substance of the motion at Commonwealth-State meetings on the environment in order to put in place uniform legislation.

I do not think there is anyone in Australia who is not horrified to find almost every one of our natural areas-beaches, parks, country areas, wilderness areas-littered with bottles, broken glass and other forms of litter. I deal specifically with glass products in this motion because they are dangerous and they do not fade away with time. If one walks along any beach, one will find the results of someone's carelessness and complete contempt for the rights of others. One will find litter, both in the water and out of the water. Children and other persons walking in those areas are at risk at all times.

In fact, the problem is such that those honourable members who have visited some of our island territories will have found similar problems there. On the rocks joining two of the islands of the Cocos (Keeling) group, which is 700 kilometres out in the Indian Ocean, there are broken beer bottles which were not put there by the islanders. They are the product of recreation yachtsmen and others who stop off at Direction Island for a few weeks on their way around the world and leave their non-disposable garbage and the products of their enjoyment for others to clean up.

What I propose in this motion is that there be a punishment which befits the crime. Those people who are responsible for this dangerous form of littering, should be required to spend some time cleaning up the mess they have made. Those local government bodies and authorities which are unfortunate enough-and fortunate enough-to have areas within their communities which are available for, used by and enjoyed by the public are regularly faced with very high levels of expenditure to clean up the mess of the stupid clowns who, in their enjoyment, have to break bottles. They cannot avoid breaking bottles and leaving them behind.

Other products are picked up because they have some economic worth. Others eventually will degenerate. None of those are acceptable practices. In the case of glass-especially broken glass-a small child riding a bicycle along a path beside a river, such as that where I regularly go for exercise, who happens to fall off is likely to have his body or limbs maimed for life because of the stupid, careless thoughtlessness of a person who, for some reason, enjoys hearing the sound of tinkling glass falling to the ground. That seems to be one of the fashions of our society.

I propose in this motion, and I hope the House will accept it, that those persons, when they are caught, be required to attend for a period of time-and I have specified, for first offenders, eight hours-and physically clean up some of the mess that has been left behind. That is not a bad form of punishment, and will not make heroes out of the dills who do this sort of thing. If such people are caught breaking glass they should be required to spend a much longer period cleaning up the mess, and should do so at their own expense.

It has recently been established, in a totally different forum, that in many instances the person who is responsible is the owner of glass products. It may be that we will have to place an obligation on those persons to pay for cleaning up the mess and maintaining the state of our environment. In my view, the dumping of glass in our society, together with the manner in which it has accumulated on our beaches and in public places, parks and even wilderness areas, is a serious threat which we as a nation should not accept.

The motion is explicit. It asks for specific action to be taken and does not deal with other areas of littering. I found, when I attempted to have some administrative action taken on this matter, that there are more subjects that can be raised to delay action than I could have imagined. If we try to solve all of the problems in the community in one go, we create the circumstances in which none is solved. This problem is dangerous. It is dangerous to people and to our environment. Certainly those people who use our beaches are in physical danger at all times because of the morons who cannot rise above their need to hear, for enjoyment, the tinkling of glass-probably having consumed the contents.

I am happy to move this motion. I am sorry that at the time I was in a position of administration I was unable to get regulations finalised which would have applied this particular set of circumstances in the Commonwealth Territories which are under the control of this Parliament. I commend the motion, and I hope that it will be acted on.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lamb Mr A.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion. I also wish to put on record that this House in 1973-74 examined the matter of the disposal of glass products. Whilst the House did not make the recommendation which the honourable member for Corio (Mr Scholes) has put forward, it did put forward a recommendation that there be a compulsory deposit on containers for beverages, including glass. I refer to the recommendation contained in a report presented to this House by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation, of which I was a member, and later Chairman for a brief period. We investigated this matter and found that the problems raised by the honourable member for Corio regarding the dangers of bottles and broken glass were evident then. Broken glass could be found on the beaches, underneath the sand, or hidden in long grass. There seems to be a proclivity on the part of less responsible members of the public to hide their vandalism, which is all it can be called.

SPEECH.PARA: Since 1973-74 only one State has taken the opportunity of putting a compulsory deposit on glass containers and that is South Australia. I would like to see the fifth point in the honourable member for Corio's motion taken up as a matter of urgency by the Australian Environment Council, the various Ministers-State and Federal-responsible for the environment. Despite changing technology, and changing packaging by manufacturers, we still see the use of glass as a necessity. There has been an increase in the use of plastic containers for milk. I doubt whether one can get milk bottles filled or replaced in Melbourne, for instance. I have not seen any for some time. Milk is now packaged in waxed cartons or plastic. While such methods do not present an immediate problem, as they do not cut individuals, and so on, the use of plastic packaging as a replacement for glass cannot be total because of the unique properties of glass which allow, as does aluminium, a chill factor to take place. In other words, glass allows for rapid heating or chilling of the contents. Australians prefer cold beer and prefer aluminium cans or glass bottles for that beverage. The same applies to soft drinks, although plastic bottles are coming into vogue because they are unbreakable. We will continue to see the use of bottles for beverages and their disposal must be controlled.

The other unique property of glass is that it is readily recyclable. Some great efforts have been made by local government and voluntary organisations in this regard. I have seen recycling centres in operation in Canberra, so that glass products can be used time and time again in two forms. First of all, the container itself can be refilled. That is not called recyclable; it is called a refillable bottle. We found that milk bottles, and beer bottles before the age of cans, were used 20 or 25 times. That was a very economical use of resources.

Of course, aluminium cans are recyclable and, of course, glass can be recycled-remelted and reused. There are energy and resource economies in recycling. There has to be an incentive for local government to collect the glass that is littered around our beaches, foreshores and countryside. The report in 1973-74 said that such an incentive would come about if there was a compulsory deposit, and that deposit was paid directly to local government. A formula was to be established through the Environment Council that those tourist areas which bear the greatest impost of the collection of rubbish and broken glass and whole bottles would get the lion's share of the revenue from the deposits. I would like to see the fifth proposition put forward by the honourable member raised in the Environment Council, and the example of South Australia followed.

I would also like to compliment the honourable member for Corio for his suggested penalty for offenders. I know it is extremely difficult to apprehend people who litter, because they are very careful not to be seen. Litterers are not proud of their achievements; they are very ashamed. However, having been caught, such people should have to undertake a period of community service rather than pay a fine. Anyone can dip into his pocket and pull out $20 or $40-particularly after the speech last night of the Treasurer (Mr Keating). It is more difficult to put in many hours cleaning up the vandalism to which he has contributed.

I compliment the honourable member for Corio, and join him in requesting the Minister for the Arts and Territories (Mr Holding), first, to examine very carefully his suggestions so that they may be applied in the Australian Capital Territory and the Northern Territory and, secondly, to take his suggestions to the Environment Council at one of the earliest opportunities so that the vandalism of glass being scattered around the country will be well and truly checked.
