SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aldred Mr K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My constituents are hurting. They have been hurting for six long years and last night's economic statement gives them no long term hope that their suffering will end. For six years the residents of my electorate of Bruce have borne the brunt of the Hawke Labor Government's protracted campaign to crush the living standards of middle Australia, as have other electorates of a similar nature.

SPEECH.PARA: Despite the tax cuts and the yet to be finalised wages deal announced by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) last night, a taxpayer on average weekly earnings with a dependent spouse and two children will still be about $50 a week worse off in June 1989 than when the Government was elected in March 1983. The entire wage-tax deal is simply giving back to workers a little of what the Government has taken from them over the last six years. It will not deliver any significant increase in real disposable income.

In the true fashion of the Hawke Government, the average $24 a week tax cut is nothing more than another sleight of hand, cynically designed by the Government and the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) to deceive middle Australia in the run-up to the next Federal election. The truth of the matter, however, is that the Treasurer will grab back part of the tax cut when he taxes the wage increases that will flow through as a result of the second part of the total wage-tax deal he announced last night.

As well as conniving with the ACTU to grab back part of the tax cut, prices will inevitably rise over the next 12 months, further eroding the benefits of the wage-tax deal. Two factors will ensure this. Firstly, industry will inevitably pass on its increased wages costs and, secondly, our galloping inflation rate, already estimated at 7.7 per cent on an annual basis, will do the rest. So within 12 months the tax cut and wage increase will be wiped out, leaving middle Australia no better off.

As I mentioned earlier, sometime in the coming year the Hawke Government will take the country to the polls. It will be a general election in which the Government will rely almost totally on the wage-tax bribe to ensure its survival. However, its contemptuous attempt to play middle Australia as fools will fail because the families of middle Australia are not stupid. They know better than anyone just how tough times have been, and they know just who has been responsible for that.

If substantiation of this claim is needed, the Government need look no further than the recent media polls on the economy, which have indicated a pessimism never before shown by the electorate. It is a pessimism underscored by a rising anger, a fact the Government has only just woken up to. For middle Australia six years of hard Labor has meant the highest interest rates ever, record levels of home loan repayments, a 10 per cent drop in real disposable income and the biggest tax grab in Australian history. Indeed, gross PAYE collections rose by nearly $4 billion, or 17 per cent, during the first eight months of this year. This huge increase can in no way be represented as a result of stronger wage and employment growth.

It is, however, partly due to the Treasurer's irresponsible and obsessive dependence on monetary policy alone, an approach that has seen the salaries and wages of middle Australia savaged by bracket creep as inflation continues to blow out well beyond his prediction of 4.5 per cent for the year. The wage-tax deal forced on the Treasurer by the ACTU will further fuel inflation, which in turn will provide him with more increases in tax revenue as bracket creep yet again strikes at middle Australia.

Adding to the enormous financial burden of Australian families is the skyrocketing rate of home loan interest rates, a further result of our galloping inflation rate. Since December 1988 mortgage rates have risen to a massive 16 per cent, adding nearly $100 a month to the average home loan repayment. As if this was not enough, it now appears more than likely that mortgage rates will rise even higher as a result of the Treasurer's wage-tax deal with the ACTU.

As late as yesterday the Chief Economist of the National Australia Bank Ltd, Mr Terry Budge, said that the tax cuts and wage rises would add to demand and put more pressure on interest rates. He said:
There's possibly some rise in housing rates by perhaps half a per cent over the next four to six weeks.

So we can expect further rises in mortgage rates before the effects of the tax cuts and wage rises even flow through to the taxpayer. With this happening, on top of the increasing inflation problem, it really means that in the medium to long term the whole wage-tax deal is worthless to Australia's struggling families, the very group the Government would have us believe it is trying to assist. The whole economic band-aid approach of the Hawke Government is leading middle Australia and our country down the road to economic ruin.

The Treasurer's latest wage-tax deal is not backed up by any policies on micro-economic reform to boost productivity. This is despite the fact that the third term of the Hawke Government was supposed to be concentrating on those very policy areas. As my colleague the shadow treasurer, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), pointed out only the other day, what Australia really requires is a coherent set of economic policies. We need, among other things, tighter fiscal policy and an industrial relations system focusing on the enterprise or industry level where wage increases are related to productivity improvements. Once this is achieved a more balanced monetary policy can be pursued to gradually reduce inflation.

The coalition has already published detailed policy documents for reform in transport, aviation, communications, industrial relations and the science area. We also have a comprehensive policy on privatisation, the details of which will be made public by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) in the very near future. When implemented in government, the coalition's policies will make Australia more productive and far more competitive in both the domestic and international marketplaces. The obvious result is that a coalition government will be able to deliver significant and sustainable improvements in living standards, particularly to Australia's families.

We, the coalition parties, do represent the great bulk of middle Australia-unlike the Hawke Labor Government, which is on bondage to sectional interests such as its dubious corporate mates and the ACTU. At the next Federal election, it will be the coalition's responsible economic policies and our vision of what this country and its people can be that will consign the Labor Party to the Opposition benches. This nation faces enormous economic and other challenges in the years ahead. The Government is turning away from those challenges. In marked contrast, I and my colleagues from the Liberal and National parties look forward to facing those challenges head on.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Free Mr R.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I will resist the temptation to rebut some of the remarks of the honourable member for Bruce (Mr Aldred), except to express the hope, at least for the Opposition, that when its Leader, the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), replies this evening to the economic statement by the Treasurer (Mr Keating), his remarks will contain more substance than we have heard from the honourable member for Bruce this morning.

SPEECH.PARA: I join the grievance debate this afternoon to make some observations about public holidays and, in particular, to express some concern that this year, the first year of our third century of European settlement, the Australian States have been unable to agree to celebrate our national day with a public holiday on the same day. Australia Day this year was celebrated with a public holiday on Thursday, 26 January, in New South Wales, the Australian Capital Territory and the Northern Territory. The other five States-Victoria, Queensland, Western Australia, South Australia and Tasmania-had a public holiday on Monday, 30 January. Last year New South Wales celebrated Australia Day on 26 January; the other States had public holidays on 25 and 26 January. This prompted some remarks from our Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and from the Premier of New South Wales, which were reported in the Sydney Morning Herald of 27 January. Mr Greiner said that it was `a national joke' and `a national disgrace' that Australia Day was being celebrated only in New South Wales and the Territories. He went on:
We don't move Christmas; we don't move our birthdays. It is a sign of national immaturity of just shameful proportions . . .

He added that he would be raising the issue at the next Premiers Conference. The Prime Minister, who was at the Opera House for the Australian of the Year awards, said that the Federal Government also supported calls to have 26 January declared the official holiday and that he would be enlisting the help of the Leader of the Opposition to reach a solution.

A Saulwick poll published in the Sydney Morning Herald on 6 February confirmed that most people preferred the holiday to be taken on the day itself. In response to the question `When do you think the Australia Day holiday should be held?', 49 per cent of people said, `On 26 January, on the day', while 32 per cent said, `Always on the following Monday', Men divided on the question, 45 in favour of 26 January as against 34 for the following Monday; women, 53 : 30. Respondents from Sydney divided 53 : 30 on the question; respondents from Melbourne, 41 : 39, which may explain Mr Cain's reluctance to move the holiday to 26 January. But in this rare case I agree with Mr Greiner on the question of the public holiday. It is a joke. But in addition, with one celebration spread over two public holidays in different States, there is, in many cases, an additional loss of productivity because communication between business and government is essentially out of action on both the 26th and the 30th in this case. A reading of the Australian Leave and Holidays Practice Manual shows other examples of the need for rationalisation of some public holidays celebrated at different times in different States. Labour Day, or its equivalent, is celebrated on five different days in Australia this year. Bank Holiday, where it is taken, is also taken on two different days. While a number of holidays such as cup days, show days and Exhibition Day in Queensland, are specific to States and a case for rationalisation does not exist, it should still be possible to bring the States into line in respect of Australia Day, Labour Day and Bank Holiday, where they are celebrated.

A different problem arises with the Easter public holidays. Although they all fall on the same days in all States, at least within Australia, they do, of course, move from year to year. Easter Day, this year, fell on 26 March. It can be as early as 22 March or as late as 25 April. A problem arises following the introduction a couple of years ago of the four-term school year. Ideally, school terms should be about 10 or 11 weeks long. However, with the linkage of the first school term break with the Easter public holidays, the first term can be as short as seven weeks and the second term as long as 13 weeks. This year, for example, the first term was eight weeks and the second term will be 12 weeks. This obviously produces difficulties in programming work cycles and can result in student and teacher fatigue and illness and absenteeism during that long second term. It even creates problems with school uniforms, where some schools require the winter uniform to be worn during the second term, even though second term started very early this year.

The whole story of the development of the means of fixing the dates for Easter is a very fascinating one. The crucifixion took place during the period of the Passover, so, naturally, the first Christian calendar was derived from the Hebrew calendar. The problem arose during the early part of the Christian era when many congregations developed their own separate calendars. It was not until the Council of Nicaea in 325AD that the Julian calendar was accepted as the basis of fixing ecclesiastical dates. That meeting of the Council decreed that Easter Day should be celebrated on the Sunday immediately following the first full moon, after the vernal equinox, which it took as 21 March. The method of determination of Easter, therefore, is regulated by the movement of the sun and of the noon. A fascinating variety of systems was developed by chronologists during the Middle Ages and in the period following to determine the date on which Easter would fall in any particular year.

Inaccuracies in the Julian calendar resulted in the promulgation of the Gregorian calendar by Pope Gregory in the year 1582. But the acceptance of this calendar was remarkably slow. It took England and Germany almost 200 years to adopt the new calendar. Japan waited until 1873 and it was not until this century that the Soviet Union and Greece adopted the calendar that we accept today. I read that when the change was made in Britain there was a difference of 11 days between the old and new style calendars and the lag was made up by naming the day after 2 September 1752 as 14 September. So nobody in that year in Britain was born in the period 3 September to 13 September.

It is interesting that the orthodox churches today still use the old style Julian calendar. So this year, while the Western churches celebrate Easter on 26 March, the Orthodox churches celebrate it on 30 April. The Passover falls on 20 April, so it is evident that both christian calendars these days appear to have broken the nexus with the Passover. I understand that calendar reform is still the subject of negotiation between the Western and the Orthodox churches. At the moment, the eminently sensible proposal to set a date for Easter on a permanent and specific Sunday is being looked at. Ideally, it should be in the middle of the period 22 March to 25 April. Such an outcome would remove some of the problems to which I have referred this afternoon and would end some 2000 years of confusion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrew Mr J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —In 1989 people are more aware than they have ever been of that finite resource that we call land. Centuries ago, people, believing in some form of flat earth policy, had no idea of what land resources were available. In 1989 we know without a doubt what land is available and what land has been exploited. In all of the concern that we have about the resources that are available to us, there has been a great deal of focus in the past five years on what we are currently doing to those finite resources, particularly in the fuel and water areas, and too little focus on what we, as a civilisation, are doing to the equally finite resource that we call land.

SPEECH.PARA: Historically, people, even when they were not aware of how finite our land resource is, were nonetheless prepared to fight for another inch of it. They were prepared to give their lives in order to capture a little more of it or to claim sovereignty over it for one reason or another. In 1989 we are conscious, not of people fighting wars over it but of the sort of demand for it by, for example, our Aboriginal population. As the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand), who is at the table, is well aware, they have an affection for and an attachment to the land.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you going to support me when I give them some land?

—It is highly unlikely that I will, on the law of averages, find myself supporting the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. But I do not detract in any way from the attachment that the Aboriginal people have to the land. I would simply say in my remarks to the House today in this grievance debate, that an attachment to the land is also felt by all Australians-by farmers and even by urban dwellers who take a particular pride in that quarter acre on which they happen to have the Hills hoist, of which the Treasurer (Mr Keating) has been so critical.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact is that we can scarcely be proud of what we have done to land during white settlement. In the 200 years that Australians have occupied this nation, 41 million hectares have been cleared. It has been estimated that 90 per cent of that cleared land has been exposed to erosion in some form or another. It is calculated that it will cost $2.3 billion to correct Australia's land degradation problems. The Minister at the table will be aware, because of his Victorian identity, of the disastrous dust storm that hit Melbourne in 1983 which is estimated to have stripped 250,000 tonnes of top soil from north-west Victoria.

One of the major areas of concern to everyone in this House is the change that is occurring in the Murray-Darling Basin as a result of increased salinity; caused by irrigation and the salinisation that is occurring in dryland areas because we have removed trees. None of us is proud of what has happened to our land under our stewardship.

So concerned have Australians been about the question of land degradation that two parties which do not normally always see things from the same point of view-the National Farmers Federation and the Australian Conservation Foundation-have combined and produced for the Government a report on what they believe ought to happen; which they have called The Australian Land Management Program. They have determined that a national soil conservation strategy ought to be endorsed by both the Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology and the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts. The House of Representatives Standing Committee is under the chairmanship the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Milton). Last Tuesday evening the honourable member set up a seminar in Parliament House which was addressed by Mr Phillip Toyne from the Australian Conservation Foundation and Dr Smiles from the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation. They announced to those of us who were present at that seminar that 1990 would be nominated as the Year of Soil Conservation. Not surprisingly, consistent with most other reports available to us, they indicated that what has happened to soil in Australia should be seen as a national disgrace; as a cancer, spreading across Australia; as an ecological disaster; as a level of soil degradation on a scale previously unknown on this continent. These are sentiments with which we would all agree, and today I rise, not to dispute what they were saying, but to inject an element or two of hope into what has been a very dismal and bleak debate.

In my short experience with farmers I have found that there is an awareness of the problems of soil degradation and erosion that we have not seen in preceding generations. In the past 30 years there has been a change in farming practice of which every farmer should be proud-a change which Mr Milton's Environment Committee should recognise, as it determines how best to address the problem that faces Australia as a result of soil degradation. I mention this because the former member for Wakefield, Mr Bert Kelly, was one of those who pioneered what was to be modern farming practice and the techniques used to minimise soil erosion. Bert Kelly-known at that time as `the modest member' who later wrote under the pseudonym of `the modest farmer'-set up what were called contour banks, to ensure that any rain falling on land, and inevitably making its way downhill, would be intercepted by these contour banks and gradually moved sideways in order to minimise any possible erosion that could occur. The water that had been collected on the contour banks was subsequently run into dams, so that it could be stored for future use. As a result of his work, soil conservation boards have been set up all around my State, and these boards are responsible for the most effective use of government resources made available to them.

Mr Kelly was not on his own. I noted that in the Sydney Morning Herald last year there was an article paying tribute to the work of Mr Robin King, who had introduced what was called the `Yeomans practice' of soil conservation, largely reflecting what Mr Kelly had been doing-using contour banks in order to minimise the soil erosion. As a Parliament, we must be aware of how much farmers are currently doing to minimise the conspicuous damage done by soil erosion to the Australian landscape. In my own area of South Australia, in the Mallee area, soil erosion-particularly wind erosion-was a major problem until 20 years ago when the Wanbi research station found techniques for sowing oats and barley, but particularly oats and rye, on drifting sandhills, thus keeping those sandhills in place. In an area of the River Murray irrigation area, for example, the whole question of salinity has largely been checked-not controlled but checked-by the astute use of water, and by ensuring that each plant has apportioned to it the water it needs by sprinkler irrigation, instead of the flood irrigation that was once characteristic of the area.

As a result of these practices, not only have we minimised salinity, but we have also reduced the amount of water used by each property holder, increased production and reduced the consequent drainage outflow. Thus, the salinity situation has been improved from both the perspective of the water used and the water wasted in drainage. I would plead with the Government, in the interests of River Murray irrigators, to consider introducing the sort of write-off that once existed under the heading `water conveyancing'. This tax write-off encouraged riverland irrigators, desperate to do something about soil erosion, to ensure that they moved out of flat irrigation into a more efficient form of water use.

As we look at the awful problem of soil erosion, much will be made of the need for some sort of major body to look at what is happening around Australia. In fact, I put to the House that we need not macro-changes, but micro-changes. We need to encourage each farmer to get on with doing what he does best-that is, making his property productive. We should encourage him by taxation incentives to do the things on his farm that will be in the interests of future generations. That may well be the most productive direction the Government can take, as it tries to address the problem of soil erosion. It is easy to imagine that from Canberra we can dictate the terms to farmers. The truth is that on each of their properties, as stewards of that piece of land, they know what is happening, they know what should happen to minimise soil erosion. Some form of tax incentive may well be the best way to ensure that we are able to pass on to future generations of Australians properties that are even better than the properties we inherited.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snowdon Mr W.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to acknowledge the contribution of the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew) because I think he has brought a thoughtful analysis to the problems of soil degradation and soil erosion. I compliment him on his contribution. I do not always agree with the honourable member for Wakefield, as he well knows, but on this occasion I think he has made a valid contribution to what is a very important public debate.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to comment on the contribution of the honourable member for Bruce (Mr Aldred), who decided that the best method of defence was attack. So he attacked, in what I think was a fairly dishonest manner, the economic statement made last night by the Treasurer (Mr Keating). I made a speech in this House yesterday in which I discussed what I thought was this Government's vision-particularly in respect of social justice. During that speech I said that in his last policy speech prior to the last Federal election, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) had set benchmarks for child payments. He said:
We have set benchmarks and we will reach those benchmarks this year and we will lock the real value of payments in.

It gave me great pride, Mr Deputy Speaker, to see that happen last night. Last night we saw, historically in my view, a commitment by a Federal government to the implementation of a social justice strategy which will be very difficult to repeal. It gives Australian families a measure of hope and a measure of recognition that has hitherto been lacking in contributions from this place. It is a very significant step.

In our policy commitments at the last election we promised that during Labor's third term an adequate living standard for children would be achieved.

Significantly, Mr Deputy Speaker, what we saw yesterday was a promise delivered because, as the Minister said--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I remind the honourable member that later today there will be a debate on the Treasurer's economic statement and standing order 82 prevents him from speaking about these issues. He may speak about the economy; that is quite in order but he must not anticipate the debate on the financial statement.

—With respect, Mr Deputy Speaker, I am not relating to the debate that might take place later today. I am relating to the discussion I had in this place yesterday about social justice and to comments made last night by the Minister for Social Security in tabling a document about our social justice strategy. I do not intend to debate the merits or demerits of the arguments put forward by the Treasurer or those which might be put forward by the shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), in this place. But I would point out that the honourable member for Bruce addressed those very questions in his contribution to today's grievance debate. My comments relate specifically to the social justice strategy which this Government promised at the last Federal election, and which was delivered by this Government last night in speeches made by the Treasurer and the Minister for Social Security. I am proud to acknowledge that because I think it is a first. In contrast to the Opposition, which takes vicarious delight in talking up interest rates, this Government has demonstrated its commitment to Australian families and to alleviating poverty traps. I, for one, am extremely proud of that achievement.

SPEECH.PARA: As I have said on a number of occasions, when the history books are written this Government will be seen as a government of vision because of what it has done and what it will continue to do for Australian families in the area of social justice. Far be it from me to steal the thunder of members of the Opposition in case they might want to debate these facts-and I do not think they can. But the point remains that there are people in this House who attempt to talk up opposition to the Government's strategies, just as there are people in other places who take similar delight in trying to undermine public confidence in the Government's economic strategies.

In my own electorate, unfortunately, there are those who question this Government's commitment to capital expenditure in northern Australia. Indeed, over recent months we have seen a campaign, assisted by people who have interests which are hard to fathom, to try to undermine the confidence of the business community in projects which have been announced by this Government. In the first instance, we saw an attempt by sections of the business community to undermine the confidence of the general community in this Government's commitment to establishing and rebuilding airports in Alice Springs and Darwin. This is, again, a promise which has been delivered by this Government.

In August of last year the Government said that new airports would be built at Darwin and Alice Springs. On 1 April this year those airports were transferred to the Federal Airports Corporation, which has in train a process to ensure that construction starts on the new work by the beginning of November. The construction project in Darwin will amount to the tune of $65m and the construction project in Alice Springs will amount to some $20m. Yet there are still people in the community, some of whom belong to the Northern Territory Government, who are trying to undermine the confidence of the business sector and, indeed, the general community, by saying that this Government is not committed to those projects. The facts are that the Government has been and is committed to those projects and the runs are on the board. Those airports will be built.

But the criticism does not stop there. I notice that the shadow Minister for defence, the honourable member for McPherson (Mr White), is sitting at the table. He has made some statements about the defence White Paper and the Government's capital works exercise in northern Australia. Indeed, he questioned the removal of 2nd Cavalry Regiment from Holsworthy in New South Wales to Darwin. He has also questioned the merits of holding Kangaroo 89 this year. Not only has that questioning taken place after the announcements were made, but it has again raised the issue of whether the Opposition is really concerned about the development of northern Australia. The impact on the Northern Territory economy of Kangaroo 89, which will cost in excess of $95m, is extremely significant and some $10m will be directly spent, I understand, in the Northern Territory.

The Opposition may not want 2nd Cavalry Regiment moved to northern Australia, it may not want it moved to Darwin, but in fact that will happen and this Government is committed to doing it. If members of the Opposition had been listening they would have heard the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr West) say that this Government has made a commitment in respect of the Tindal base. They will see within a short time a commitment to some $65m of work for the establishment of 2nd Cavalry Regiment in the Northern Territory. That $65m is important work. It is important for the Northern Territory economy.

I might suggest to the honourable member for McPherson that when he makes statements about what we should or should not do in the areas of defence policy and defence related construction in northern Australia, he should take account of public confidence. The Northern Territory community is after a degree of commitment by this Government and by the Opposition, I would think, to northern Australian and to northern development. The honourable member would know-and if he does not, he ought to-that northern Australia is vital to Australia's defence needs. He would know, as he ought to know, that the sorts of programs which this Government has implemented at Tindal, in Darwin and around Darwin, in terms of 2nd Cavalry Regiment, Tindal and HMAS Coonawarra, are extremely important not only in terms of this Government's defence policy but also for the development of the Northern Territory economy. I am sure that some of the honourable member's friends in the Northern Territory community, who would on other occasions support his Party, recognise the importance of this commitment. They have said and affirmed that the commitment by this Government in the area of defence expenditure is extremely important to them as consumers of labour and as business people in northern Australia. Indeed, it is acknowledged as being of extreme importance to the Northern Territory Government. It is extremely important that members of the Opposition should also recognise this commitment. Members of the Opposition who take a vicarious delight in trying to undermine public confidence in the strategies of this Government ought to think again because what they are doing is not appreciated by the general community and certainly not by the community of northern Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr I.M.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —My grievance today is the lack of road funding in my electorate of Maranoa, which is related to the Government's proposed changes to the wheat industry that are contained in legislation which will be introduced into this House this afternoon. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) will introduce seven Bills which are concerned with the so-called deregulation of the wheat market. But I would like to put it to the House that, until the Government is prepared to give adequate funding to our road system in Australia, it is an absolute nonsense for it to start talking about freeing up and deregulating the wheat market. Up to 20 million tonnes of grain is grown in this country each year. It is beyond my imagination how this massive tonnage can be shipped to ports without using road transport.

SPEECH.PARA: Even last night we saw another cut in road funding. This Labor Government has cut general purpose grants to local authorities across Australia by $20m. We have also seen a cut of $360m in the general purpose grants to the States. So once again the States are being put in the invidious position of not being able to help local authorities in their funding arrangements. As well, the local authorities themselves are not able to put some more funds towards building of our road system. We are down to the stage now where local authorities are flat out maintaining our roads, let alone building new ones.

The Commonwealth allocates to our road system 4.95c out of the 22.39c a litre that it collects by way of duty. Of course, this amount is indexed to inflation. It is a great pity the Treasurer (Mr Keating) does not index personal tax rates to inflation. If he did, we would not see the charade that we had to go through last night. Every couple of years, the Treasurer comes in and fiddles the tax scales so that he can return some of the money that he has ripped off taxpayers. That is what happened last night. Half of the so-called wage increase will be paid back through taxation. In addition, the wage earner has already paid by way of tax the amount that is now being given back to him through the adjustment of the tax scales. We have a surplus of $5 1/2 billion--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I ask the member for Maranoa--

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I will get back to road funding. We already have a surplus of $5 1/2 billion. I would have thought that, if the Government were fair dinkum about de-regulating the rail system across this country, it would divert more funds to road building and road maintenance. We note that 17.44c out of every 22.39c a litre collected, or roughly $6 billion, goes into Consolidated Revenue. I have mentioned that wheat legislation is to be introduced this afternoon. I am totally opposed to the way in which the Labor Government is using deregulation of the wheat industry to attack the Queensland Government. I just want to put down a few facts and figures that even some of the commentators do not wish to know about or understand. I want to say to Alan Mitchell, a columnist in the Sydney Morning Herald, that I do not know how he can print the fact that $13 per tonne can be saved by deregulating the wheat transport system, that the Queensland Government is ripping off the wheatgrower in the electorate of Maranoa to the tune of $13 per tonne. My electorate contains a lot of Queensland wheatgrowers. I do not know how he can say that the Queensland Government is ripping wheatgrowers off by $13 a tonne. I am charged $16.08 a tonne at the little rail siding that I deliver my grain to. Does he believe that the grower pays only $3 a tonne for transport?

SPEECH.PARA: I would also like to point out to Alan Mitchell that we are paid in accordance with the quality of our wheat. Wheat is segregated into a whole range of different classifications. We have to mix the grain because every market around the world wants a different standard of wheat. We have six or seven different types of grain which are put in different heaps and mixed. We are also paid a protein premium. Of course, Australians are very lucky; we eat some of the highest protein wheat bread in the world. As growers, we receive a sliding scale of protein payments. That scale starts at 12 per cent and goes up to 18 per cent, and growers can be paid from $10 a tonne to $40 a tonne over and above the standard payment, which is roughly $150 a tonne. That protein premium is added to our payment, so there is enormous encouragement for us to produce the best quality, highest protein wheat we possibly can because we are adequately compensated for it.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I also want to draw to the attention of honourable members the nonsense that the Government is going on about in relation to the Queensland rail system. It is important to understand, first of all, that the new outloading facility at Fisherman's Island is capable of storing only 60,000 tonnes. It has been built by the wheat growers of Queensland. At this point I mention-as I have previously-that the State Wheat Board has borrowed $80m and it has to pay interest and redemption on that and, of course, the more growers leave the system in Queensland the higher the interest and redemption payments to those who are left in it. As I was saying, we can load a ship only up to 60,000 tonnes at the port. The trains actually pick up different qualities of grain-up to 10 different qualities of grain will be picked up from an outlying depot. The grain is mixed on the way down to Brisbane and is delivered to the port. That wheat has a particular average protein and quality mix by the time it is ready to be loaded on to the ship that is waiting there for the order. It is absolute nonsense to suggest that more can be loaded. We cannot physically cart more grain down to the port of Brisbane, from which most of our wheat is shipped out, because there is just not the facility there to hold it. Obviously grain can be carted by road transport, but while we are doing that we are wrecking our crumbling road system. We all know that the large transporters, the tri-axle tippers that roar past us these days with their big 500 horsepower engines up front, do a great deal of damage to our roads-far more than the ordinary family sedan does.

With the sort of funding that this Government gives us, it is just not possible for councils to keep up the road system on which we have to send our grain. Last night the Treasurer announced cuts in funding for the State Government and cuts in general purpose grants. We now have the absurdity of the Government telling us that we must take the 15 million to 20 million tonnes of grain that is carted in this country off the rail system. That will, of course, force the closure of branch lines. This is already happening in Queensland with my own branch line, the Glenmorgan branch line. We have been asked to look at closing the end of the line from Glenmorgan to Meandarra, where there is a wheat depot. The Bell branch line also looks like being closed and if no grain is carted on this rail way line there will not be any line into those areas.

I put to the Federal Government that the first thing it should do is to give back the taxes on fuel that it has knocked out of the railway system in this country. We have seen the absurdity of the Federal Government charging the railways an indexed excise tax on diesel. Tax is now being paid on the diesel consumed by trains used throughout this nation in State governments' railway systems. So here is one government taxing another government-it is an absurdity. If the Federal Government is fair dinkum about helping the wheat producers of this country and cutting some costs, I suggest that that is the first area it should tackle. In a simple, one-off operation, it could just knock out the excise taxes that it charges the railways. This would represent an immediate saving to both the grain growers and the railways. This debate is all about saving costs.

Unless this Labor Government does something about our road system it will not be able to cope with increased traffic. If we are to have more grain carried on our road system we will need to have a lot more money spent on it than is the case at present. I would suggest that the figure of 4.95c in excise which goes to roads needs to be doubled immediately if we are to catch up because there was a $30m decrease in road funding last financial year. There have been an overall 40 per cent drop in real terms in funding for our road system and if we are to catch up and keep ahead of a deregulated rail system we must at least double the amount of excise tax that goes to our roads.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charlesworth Dr R.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to read from a letter which appeared in the Sydney Morning Herald earlier this week under the title of `Public prudery'. The letter says:

SPEECH.PARA: The Herald's latest AIDS editorial (April 8) is ill-informed and ill-considered.
You suggest AIDS education should concentrate on ``high-risk groups'' and be ``closely targeted . . . to the homosexual community''.
That is precisely what has been happening, with and without government support, for six years.
Perhaps because it is ``closely targeted'' neither the Herald, nor even some central medicos, are aware of it.
It is closely targeted partly because peer group education is the most successful.
But, in part, it has to be because of widespread public prudery.

Homosexuality, anal intercourse et al do not feature in public campaigns because TV stations won't run advertisements referring to those matters . . . politicians get upset . . . and parents and clergy object . . .
This foolish and dangerous censorship was not so as ``not to upset homosexual power groups'' as you assert.
These groups, in fact, protested the omissions.
How convenient for your polemic that you and a small handful of medicos persistently forget these facts and seek to rewrite history.
Whether people want to deny it or not, AIDS, is becoming a fact of heterosexual life in Australia.

That is a very sensible and sobering letter, I must say. It continued, but I will not read the full text. But it is a response to a campaign, which seems to be gaining momentum, which attacks the Government's response to the AIDS epidemic and, in particular, to the public education campaign. The letter correctly points out, of course, that the response and the campaign of the Government have been targeted and it also points out very correctly-and this is something that many people seek to deny-that this is everybody's problem.

I suppose we expect from the honourable member for Parkes (Mr Cobb) the sort of hyperbolic raving we heard last Thursday because that is his trademark. We anticipate that medical scientists who are involved in research will have a bias towards a curative approach and will expect more money to be directed their way. We understand that sort of bias; but surely it must be the first responsibility of a government to provide all its citizens with the knowledge and therefore the ability to avoid infection in respect of this massive problem.

But what of the campaign? The suggestion has been made in many places that it is not targeted, but clearly the majority of the money is being put towards community groups and community projects, thereby influencing peer groups to change. Those pro- jects have been specifically targeted towards the homosexual and bisexual community, towards intravenous drug users and towards prostitutes who are seen as being high risk. Indeed, there is clear and widespread evidence of success. There has been a significant decrease in the incidence of sexually transmitted diseases amongst those groups, there has been a shift in sexual practices amongst those groups. The Sydney AIDS project study, which interviewed more than 1,000 homosexuals and bisexuals, showed that the rate of new infections between 1985 and 1988 had fallen from 4 per cent to one per cent. In the Sydney detoxification hospital the practice of needle sharing by intravenous drug users has been shown to have fallen from 70 per cent to 40 per cent. Indeed, the use of condoms by prostitutes in Sydney has increased significantly and there has been a significant decrease in sexually transmitted diseases and gonorrhoea amongst that group.

But what concerns the Government is the transmission of this disease more and more into the heterosexual community. I quote from a Western Australian study and report on it in the West Australian newspaper of last week. The report said:
The study found that women made up 7.5 per cent of reported cases in 1987 and heterosexuals 5.4 per cent. In 1984, no cases in either group were reported.
The newspaper article then quoted Michelle Kosky, who is the Executive Director of the Western Australian AIDS Council. Miss Kosky said:
`The women at most risk are not prostitutes. They're young single women experimenting with their sexuality, a group I refer to as enthusiastic amateurs'.
The article continued:
Miss Kosky said that prostitutes tended to have a more professional attitude towards the HIV infection and looked after their sexual health.

Honourable members may or may not agree with what has been said by Miss Kosky, but it is clear from the other evidence that I have outlined and from a great deal of evidence all over the place that those groups that have been targeted are changing their behaviour in a significant way.

Of course not enough has been done yet, but campaigns directed towards changing people's behaviour take time and it is very difficult. We have had a significant anti-smoking campaign in this country for many years. Yet we still find about four million Australians addicted to nicotine. So that is a difficult process. But in those areas where the Government has been working hardest the process has been most successful. Of course, what concerns us when we think about this epidemic is what will happen in the future and it is very important that we try to anticipate events. The immediate concern of those involved in the area is the incidence of intravenous drug using. The sharing of needles is a very good, efficient way of transferring this virus from one person to another and indeed the fact that many IV drug users-within the stereotype of IV drug users, I suppose-support the habit with prostitution gives another portal for the spread of this disease into the heterosexual community. The fact that IV users are covert in their habits and, because of the illegality of their activity, need to hide their behaviour, means they are a difficult group to get at. Indeed, the potential for an explosion in our society is very significant.

I illustrate this by pointing out that in the United States of America more than half of the women who have the HIV virus are intravenous drug users and of the rest of them, 22 per cent have intravenous drug users as partners. The horrifying statistic in New York is that 80 per cent of children born with AIDS have mothers who are either intravenous drug users or have partners who are intravenous drug users. That is a frightening statistic, I must say. In Australia there is an incidence within the female population which is significantly less than that in other countries and it is important at this stage for us to make very clear to those out there in the heterosexual community that they are at risk. It is very important that they should understand that.

The speed and the ease with which transmission occurs amongst the heterosexual population is controversial but clear, and the fourth international conference on AIDS in Stockholm last year came up with the unanimous finding that transfer of the disease occurs with normal heterosexual contact. So it would be a dereliction of duty by the Government if it did not inform those in the community who are sexually active that it is possible for there to be heterosexual transmission. Indeed, the belief put around that this disease is in fact not transferred in that way is erroneous and very dangerous. The clinical evidence is clear; the epidemiological evidence is appearing more and more and it is necessary for us to take action. I suppose it is necessary for the Government to ride out this criticism. If in 10 years' time, in 1999, there are a few cases around and we have had to wear the criticism, that is a preferable situation to there being thousands of cases around in 1999. Then the charge would be that we were negligent in not informing the public of the nature of this disease and its means of transmission.

HIV virus has taken hundreds of lives and indeed it has damaged thousands of others. It has touched the lives of hundreds of thousands of Australians and I would suggest it is in the consciousness of almost every Australian. The social, moral and economic issues are very significant. For instance, it is suggested that in 1990-AIDS will cost taxpayers about $150m in direct costs. The disease challenges our prejudices and it challenges the comfortable, cosy belief that we have had in the past. But for the Government not to arm all Australians with the knowledge and thereby the power to avoid the infection would be indefensible. The present campaign uses expert medical, scientific and social science data and I believe the priorities are appropriate in the wide range of responses. But we must understand that this is not just a problem for certain sections of the community-it is one for the whole community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woods Dr R. L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to address the House on two issues which have been raised previously but about which I believe there can never be enough said whilst the world community continues to ignore them. I speak firstly about a matter which has to join the ranks of Hitler's massacre of the Jews in Nazi Germany and Europe as one of the greatest instances of man's inhumanity to man that has been perpetrated in this century-the invasion, occupation and violation of the peaceful, neutral, independent country of Tibet by the People's Republic of China. While I am aware of our relationship with the People's Republic of China, I believe we would be breaching our responsibility to our fellow members of mankind if we do not make known our indignation at the breach of human and civil rights which occur regularly in Tibet. The holocaust of Tibet's peoples, the degradation of its religion, traditions and culture, all result from China's seemingly insatiable and remorseless lust for dominance, which is well documented. While many nations around the world appear unanimous in their condemnation, flagrant violation of the Tibetan's rights continues.

SPEECH.PARA: Tibet is a country with a very long and rich past. Throughout its history it has been intermittently occupied by the Chinese, who apparently saw an advantage in the occupation of Tibet as a means of access to the Indian subcontinent. In 1949, with the argument that it was an inalienable part of its territory, the People's Republic of China again invaded Tibet and in 1959, in protest at the economic and social reforms introduced by the Chinese, there was an uprising. The spiritual leader of Tibet, the Dalai Lama, and several thousand of his supporters, fearing arrest, were forced to flee and seek exile in neighbouring India, whilst back in Tibet, within a fortnight of the revolt occurring it had been crushed and an estimated 65,000 Tibetans were reported killed. Prior to this event Tibet had essentially been a peace-abiding, non-violent, gentle Buddhist society with a unique culture, history, spiritual following and language. Its people, perhaps by nature of their isolation and their spiritual associations, were dedicated to a non-confrontationist, peaceful coexistence with others. The fact that they were driven to take part in an uprising is an indication of the terrible oppressions which they did, and do suffer, under a communist regime.

After the 1959 uprising, which the People's Republic of China calls a rebellion, land reform was introduced and peasant associations were set up for collectives and the establishment of communes. There was a deliberate policy to destroy the four `olds'-that is, old ideas, old culture, old customs and old habits. This was done by the ethnic Chinese Red Guards who savaged-and I think that is not too strong a word to use-Tibetan culture and religion. More than 6,000 monasteries, many of which were built prior to the birth of Christ, were callously ransacked and destroyed and the number of monks and nuns was reduced by more than two-thirds. Centuries of priceless treasures and artefacts were ravaged and have disappeared, perhaps forever. The important point of this is that Tibet's religion and culture are a fundamental part of its national identity and in the light of this the devastation and suffering, and the rampant unwarranted destruction of the monasteries and the religious culture must have caused all the more damage to Tibet than it would to some other countries in the same situation.

Again, in the past few years there have been more demonstrations which resulted in the imposition of martial law in March this year. The most serious abuses perpetrated by the People's Republic of China against the nation of Tibet, have been the continued physical abuse of the people of Tibet themselves. Gross atrocities have been committed-mass genocide, beatings, torture, often with electric batons and other items of torture. Some allegations have been made that more than one million Tibetans have died under the People's Republic regime. Estimates of political prisoners range from 3,000 to 4,000, many of whom have been adopted by Amnesty International as prisoners of conscience. In the long run, one of the most demoralising policies adopted for the Tibetans by the People's Republic has been the Chinese transfer policy. This basically results in more Chinese in Tibet than Tibetans in many areas and it gives preference in schooling, medical care and housing facilities to these Chinese. Such Tibetans as have survived are reduced to second class citizens in their own country.

The International Commission of Jurists has acknowledged the genocide practised by the Chinese on the Tibetans. The United Nations General Assembly has passed three motions condemning the Chinese for their abuse of human rights. But despite these and a similar motion passed by the American Congress and Senate, Chinese dominance in Tibet continues. The confidence of the People's Republic that countries such as Australia will not meddle in international affairs extended so far recently that the Chinese Embassy here in Canberra even sought intervention by the Australian Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade to stop the Special Broadcasting Service from airing a report that documented these abuses of human rights. Whilst Australia and other countries continue to hide behind the skirts of international trade agreements, or other equally unconvincing excuses, we are, in effect, condoning the abuse of civil rights in Tibet. The Chinese Republic's indignation that other countries of the world should comment on and be outraged by these abuses would be comical if it were not so tragic. We just cannot be indifferent to the oppression and suffering that has resulted from the desire of the People's Republic of China to colonise Tibet.

The Dalai Lama has recently announced a five-point peace plan which is addressed to the People's Republic. He proposes a transformation of the whole of Tibet into a peace zone; an end to the Chinese people transfer policy; respect of the civil human rights and freedom of the Tibetans; the restoration and protection of Tibet's natural environment; an end to the use of Tibet by China for the production of nuclear weapons and dumping of nuclear waste; and the start of serious discussions on the future of Tibet and of relations between the Tibetans and the Chinese. I believe our country and our Government must support these requests.

There is another instance of gross human rights abuse that I wish to raise, which continues unchallenged and which is, in many ways, equally astounding. It is the bizarre redevelopment and modernisation scheme that Romanian President, Nicolae Ceausescu, is promoting under which millions of residents are being evacuated and relocated whilst some 7,000 villages are literally being razed by bulldozers to be replaced with modern agro-industrial complexes. The alleged objective of the bulldozing is to bridge the gap between the town and country life of Romanians and to establish nearly 800,000 acres of arable land. But the result has been that hundreds of years of social and religious history has been eradicated. Homes, schools and churches have been bulldozed, and millions of Romanian people herded into urban ghettos.

Hungarians believe that there is a systematic discrimination, particularly against ethnic Hungarians living in the north-western Transylvanian region, and that this is an attempt to destroy centuries of rich and ancient Hungarian culture and national identity. There appears to be a definite policy to absorb all cultures into the one and to remove all vestiges of the individual nationalities. It seems, however, that it is not just the ethnic Hungarians but, indeed, the Romanians as a whole who are bearing the brunt of Ceausescu's obsession with the development of his own particular form of communism. In an attempt to repay a $10 billion debt he has adopted a policy of such austerity that basic requirements such as food and heating are rationed as if it were war-time and thousands are starving and suffering from severe malnutrition. During winter, heating in homes is limited to times when the temperature is below 14 degrees centigrade; there are shortages of basic medical requirements; there are even food rations of half a quart of cooking oil and between one and two pounds of meat per month. Even though these commodities are rationed, they are often not available.

Aside from these inhumanities, Romania is guilty of even more horrific human rights violations. Amnesty International, as in Tibet, has taken up the cause of a number of political prisoners arrested often for exercising nothing more than internationally accepted human rights, such as the right to freedom of speech. There are many cases of psychiatric imprisonment for no other reason than punishment for criticism of the President's regime. Cases of torture, disappearance, house arrest, harassment and forced migration are innumerable. The repressions of religious and cultural freedoms of the 1980s, against the Hungarians in particular, seem to be just as serious as those against the Jews by Hitler in the 1930s. As I speak, the picturesque towns, castles and villages and beautifully embroidered costumes so often used in the travel brochures to advertise Romania are being annihilated. As with Tibet, I believe that Australia's failure to condemn the cultural genocide which is taking place in Romania makes us a conspirator to the crimes. This Government must, for once, do the right thing and not the pragmatic thing, and take a stand in the international community on behalf of these two countries and their inhabitants.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Philip Island Motor Cycle Grant Prix-Radioactive Contamination: CSIRO Centre, Fishermens Bend-Availability of Reference Material for Members of Parliament-Extreme Disability Adjustment Allowance-Tasmania: Newspaper Article-Acacia Ridge Social Security Office-Drought: Eyre Peninsula-Australian Rugby League-Road Funding-Greensborough By-Election-Science Funding

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pratt Mr M.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last weekend the eyes of Australia and the world were upon Philip Island in Victoria. The emotion and euphoria that erupted as one of Australia's sporting legends, Wayne Gardner, crossed the line at Australia's first motor cycle grant prix were reflected around Australia. It was a lifelong dream of Wayne Gardner to create, compete and win his own country's grand prix. Wayne Gardner has brought a new dimension to motor cycling and to the petrol heads, I guess, whether they have cycles like my 75cc farm Yamaha or the big 1,000cc BMW roadies.

SPEECH.PARA: I would also like to pay tribute to two Adelaide-based South Australians who played a major role in this event. I refer to an engineering genius by the name of Mr Bob Barnard. He and his Barnard Corporation were behind the logistics and the manufacture and creation of the infrastructure that allowed several hundred thousand people to view live this significant sporting event, along with the hundreds of millions in Australia and overseas who saw it on the Nine Network. Bob Barnard was also responsible for the track and support logistics at the world famous Adelaide Grand Prix, as well as creating the Carrara complex for the Brisbane Bears, which is a football team, not a public zoo.

The merchandising and apparel clothing supporting Philip Island and the Adelaide Grand Prix were predominantly picked up by an enterprising company from Adelaide called Good Sports Manufacturing and its principal, Mr David Eckert, is to be congratulated on his entrepreneurial skills. On behalf of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), who normally grants a free holiday for these efforts, I salute Wayne Gardner, Bob Barnard and David Eckert-three great Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to express my concern about a report which appeared in the Age today, 13 April. The report refers to workers who were evacuated from a Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation centre at Fishermens Bend when tests there found radioactive contamination up to 50 times the acceptable level. The Australian Radiation Laboratory has made a report on this matter to the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones), and it indicated that the levels of radiation at the five contaminated sites were significant and in one area the level was 50 times the amount considered acceptable for the public. Apparently this resulted from research projects in the 1950s that involved the separation and concentration of radioactive ores. The presence of radioactive nuclides in the soil was consistent with uranium ore processing. I wonder, Mr Deputy Speaker, how many other research projects have been conducted all around the country. I believe the Government should investigate all these sites to find out whether there are any more radioactive problems which could affect the public to such a significant extent.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday the Clerk of the House circulated advice to honourable members that only one copy of the economic statement by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the accompanying information paper would be made available to each member of this place. That limit was imposed as a result of a decision by someone in the Treasury Department and was not in accordance with the requirements of the parliamentary departments. On an earlier occasion the Australian Electoral Commissioner laid down that I-and presumably this applied to all members-was entitled to only one bound copy of the electoral roll which we use for reference when carrying out our responsibilities to our respective electorates. In this context, I register the strongest possible objection to being deprived of my minimum needs-apparently at the whim of some bureaucrat.

SPEECH.PARA: Like most honourable members, I work out of four offices located at my home, my electorate office, the party divisional office and in the Parliament itself. Therefore, four copies of basic reference works, such as those instanced, are needed in the normal course of my duties. It is high time that the reasonable needs of elected representatives were not determined by some nameless, unaccountable public servant. Until this trend is reversed and until all members' requirements for printed material are given top priority, criticism of those responsible will be increased. I would like you, Mr Deputy Speaker, to draw my comments to the attention of Madam Speaker.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lee Mr M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This afternoon I wish to draw to the House's attention the fact that last month the Minister for Veteran's Affairs (Mr Humphreys) visited my electorate of Dobell on the New South Wales central coast. The Minister was able to address a meeting of more than 300 local veterans and war widows at the Toukley Returned Services League sub-branch. One of the issues raised by many of the veterans present was the fact that the Repatriation Commission is using very strict guidelines when considering applications for the extreme disability adjustment allowance. Under this allowance, the Government pays $130 per week to those veterans over the age of 65 who may not be eligible for the totally and permanently incapacitated pension.

SPEECH.PARA: The difficulty is that under the guidelines veterans have to obtain a rating of six out of seven in relation to their particular circumstances. It is very difficult for veterans to reach that target. In fact, one veteran at the public meeting said that one would not only have to be dead to get a six out of seven rating; one would have to be dead for four days! I would certainly encourage the Minister to review as soon as possible this requirement that veterans have to rate at least six out of seven to obtain the extreme disability allowance. This is something which the Minister has agreed to examine and I can assure him that my constituents will be very grateful if he is able to lower the necessary rating. I would like to suggest that perhaps a rating of five out of seven would be more reasonable.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why does everybody hate Tasmania? I can understand their hating me; that is no worry. The worry is an article about Tasmania written by a fellow called Barry Lowe. I do not know him; he is probably a very good bloke. He is a journalist from the Australian and he is probably a left wing socialist. I cannot understand his article; when I read it in last Saturday's Weekend Australian I nearly died. Where he got his quotes from and how he reached his conclusions I will never know. He even quoted Father Julian Punch. As all honourable members know, I am a Catholic but I take Father Punch with a grain of salt-probably epsom salts! He also referred to `one of the State's true visionaries, industrialist-turned-winemaker Mr Claudio Alcorso'. Well, he earned his money. The Labor Government in Tasmania gave him a loan at about one per cent. As a result he made so much money and caused so much pollution in Tasmania that now he is a `visionary'. Mr Alcorso is against everything, every little development in Tasmania. The article quotes another so-called independent, Dr Gerry Bates. I hate this word `independent'. Independents in Tasmania care about only one thing; they do not care about the poor, elderly people around the town, they do not care about the homeless and all the others with problems. Dr Bates is quoted as saying that we want cottage industries in Tasmania in order to survive. Are we supposed to sit and weep and knit and spin all day? How would I be? Crikey, I would be dead in a month! Also Father Julian Punch talked about homelessness in Tasmania-youth down the drain, living in the sewers of Tasmania. What a lot of rot! I will not go to confession again--
—Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

—I rise to thank the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) on behalf of the good citizens of Acacia Ridge. As some people will know, we as a Government are committed to caring for people and also ensuring that their needs are met. So, after quite a long period in which this group of people in this suburb have been disadvantaged by two levels of government, I am delighted to say that our Minister for Social Security has seen fit to meet their needs and to open an office in their shopping centre. The need was admirably illustrated yesterday at the opening of that office because people went there in their numbers to seek advice and help. I think that shows very definitely that our Minister cares about people and about the service they have. He has also ensured that those people who are in need and who have been totally disregarded by the other tiers of government are cared for. I thank him.

—Last night's statement by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) was grim news for the people of the Eyre Peninsula in South Australia, which has been ravaged by drought for eight years. In that time the people have unsuccessfully sought a drought declaration from the State Government and the consequent Commonwealth intervention. As of last night, Commonwealth intervention is no longer an option. Instead, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) has set up a drought aid task force. The question might well be asked: Why has Commonwealth drought aid gone before the task force has met or reported? If the task force recommends-as well we can imagine it will-widespread changes to the way we administer drought aid, the people of Eyre Peninsula will have every reason to be indignant. Most indignant of all will be those who have been forced off their farms. Why? Because the task force will be recommending changes to drought aid, changes that the Eyre Peninsual people will have been denied, and in the meantime these same people will have had no access to drought aid at all simply because the Government is determined, if you will pardon the pun, to dry up Commonwealth intervention in drought aid. Every Eyre Peninsula farmer forced off a farm, every Eyre Peninsula farmer forced to change the priorities he would have given to his family, has every reason to be indignant at the statement made by the Treasurer last night.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Mr R.F.

I would like to commend the Australian and New South Wales Rugby League on the quality of their office bearers and the conduct of the competition. The New South Wales and Australian Rugby League, however, is setting the scene--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cowan Mr D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Recent rains that have occurred throughout the Commonwealth, and certainly in the eastern part of Australia, have seriously affected the condition of the roads in New South Wales, particularly. Once again, I wish to bring to the attention of the Government the urgent need for more finance for roads. All the categories of roads, from the national highways down to the rural and local urban roads, are vitally affected. These are the roads that are serving Australia and its people. Local government generally is now being stretched to the limit on the funds that it has available to maintain and build the necessary roads.

SPEECH.PARA: At the weekend I attended a meeting at Coomba Park, in the Great Lakes shire, where 120 people brought to my notice the urgent need for funding for rural local roads. If one lives in a local community it is so important that one should be able to get one's product to market. School buses must be able to take children to school. Overall, the roads in this country are in very bad condition. The people look to the Commonwealth, because the Federal Government collects the taxes. More of the money that rightfully belongs to these country people must be allocated to the roads that are severely in need of maintenance.

TALK.START.PARA: —At 8 a.m. on Saturday next, 15 April, eight polling booths will open their doors in the shires of Diamond Valley and Eltham. At 8 a.m. the voters of the State electorate of Greensborough will start voting, and that vote will end the leadership of Jeff Kennett, the Liberal leader in Victoria. It will spell doom for the Liberals and in the next fortnight I will come back here with a great smile on my face to explain quite happily to this House why the Australian Labor Party won the State seat of Greensborough, and why the conservatives of this country have, yet again, proved themselves incompetent in campaigning and in putting forward candidates who have the support of the local community. Sherryl Garbutt, a fine person, a Labor candidate, will win the election; she will win it with a margin of between 51 and 52 per cent in two-party preferred terms. Last week in the Herald Jeff Kennett admitted that the Liberals have lost the by-election-and they have.

—Madam Speaker, the long awaited Smith report has been delivered to the Government, that being, of course, the committee of inquiry, headed by Professor Bob Smith, into the funding needs of higher education and other research institutions. It has concluded that unless $180m is urgently invested in science and research effort in this country, Australia's economic performance will continue to suffer as it has under the past neglect of science by this Government. The tragedy in all of this is that the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones) has not yet responded, and he is becoming increasingly more irrelevant to this whole science debate. The Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation is now reporting almost exclusively to the senior Minister, Senator John Button, who is the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, whilst the Minister for Science is relegated to the office boy role of running the day-to-day operations at CSIRO. At best, he has no influence in policy formulation. We await some declaration of leadership, some decisive decisions on his part, so that CSIRO's disintegration is halted and reversed, and it once again becomes the flagship of Australian science.
