QUESTION.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Prime Minister whether he is aware of the views of the Australian Catholic Social Welfare Commission, which said only a short time ago:

QUESTION.PARA: For the vast majority of families, last night's changes do not compensate for their loss in disposable earnings under this government.

Is it a fact, as the Commission says, that, after allowing for last night's changes, an Australian family of a father, mother and two children on average weekly earnings would still be $26 a week worse off than it was in January 1983?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The figures that have been used by the Leader of the Opposition, whatever their source, are not accurate.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members-Ha, ha!

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable members opposite can have their giggle; I am simply saying that the figures are not accurate. The fact is that, under this Government, the real disposable incomes of households have been increased.
—Ha, ha!

—I suggest that the honourable member read attachment A to the speech of the Treasurer, if he is capable of doing so. In case he cannot find his way through the document, I refer him to page 29. There he will see the facts as I have put them.
—Is the Minister for Social Security aware of claims that the benefits to families provided by the Government will melt away under the heat of inflation?

—I am aware of such claims having been made last night, as I understand it, by the Leader of the Opposition. In fact, I saw him on television saying something very much like that. I guess that the problem was that he had learnt his lines earlier in the day and did not have the opportunity last night to study the actual document or to think through a position. After all, members of the Opposition are notable for their very slow thinking in the area of families. They are very slow thinkers. They are fine when it comes to making vague statements of attitude but we know their record in terms of action. I have referred to that record. The Leader of the Opposition has been extraordinarily uncomfortable when I have made the point that, in six out of seven Budgets, he, as Treasurer for a number of those Budgets, could not find a dollar for low income families. In terms of the family allowance, which the Leader of the Opposition says he supports--

—Madam Speaker, I take a point of order. It concerns the matter of relevance and the responsibility of the Minister to answer a question from his own back bench. As I heard it, he was asked whether social security benefits would melt away under the effects of inflation. I am sure that many people would like that question answered.
—Order! The Minister will answer the question.

—As I was pointing out, there was a fair bit of melting away under seven Budgets. There was only one increase in the family allowance after its introduction in 1976. Even when the family allowance was introduced the Opposition discounted the rebate to pay for it. The Leader of the Opposition has talked about the melting away of family allowance payments. I will explain why the historic reforms we announced last night will not melt away. They will not melt away because they are indexed. This Government is the only government--
—Madam Speaker, I take a point of order. The comment which was referred to suggested--
—That is not a point of order; that is a personal explanation.
—Order! The Leader of the House will allow the Chair to hear the point of order. I call the Leader of the Opposition.
—I take a point of order on relevance. My comment, to which the questioner referred, was that the tax benefits would melt away under the heat of both interest rates--
—Order! The honourable member is making a personal explanation; he does not have a point of order.
—Will the Minister promise to index against interest rates?
—Order! The honourable member will resume his seat. He does not have a point of order.

—I was simply making the point that the new rates for family allowance-$6 for the first three children and $9 for the fourth and additional children-will not melt away because the allowance will be indexed. Neither will any other child payment in the social security system melt away because it will be either indexed or adjusted to maintain the benchmark. That is historic because we are the first Government in the history of Federation to do this. We are not preoccupied with some mythical family of the 1950s, the favourite family of the Leader of the Opposition.
—Madam Speaker, I raise a point of order. On the question of relevance and accuracy, the Minister has just given us the figures. He said that the figures are $6 and $9.
—Order! The honourable member does not have a point of order.
—Madam Speaker, on a point of order--
—Do you want to talk about Kristine?
—Order! The Minister will resume his seat. The Chair warns the honourable member for O'Connor.
—Madam Speaker, on a point of order: How many questions are to be disrupted by phoney points of order which are disorderly?
—Order! The Treasurer will resume his seat. He is quite out of order.
—Madam Speaker, I am not out of order; they are disorderly.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Treasurer will not--

INTERJECT.PARA: Opposition members-Warn him!

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Treasurer will not take on the Chair. He will withdraw.
—Madam Speaker, I withdraw.

—One can understand a certain sense of frustration on the part of the Opposition. I was pointing out that the Government has indexed not only the family allowance and other remaining child payments but also the dependent spouse rebate and the sole parent rebate. So, rather than benefits melting away, we as a Government have made decisions that honourable members opposite had seven years to make but could not make, despite their concern about families. The previous question referred to the Australian Catholic Social Welfare Commission--
—But that is not--
—Order! The Leader of the Opposition will not interject.
—He is not--
—Order! The Leader of the Opposition will not defy the Chair. He will not interject.

—The Australian Catholic Social Welfare Commission made some comment on whether the tax cuts and the family assistance package restored people's situations. I suggest that the Leader of the Opposition, who was very keen several weeks ago to quote the Australian Institute of Family Studies, should have a close look at what the Institute of Family Studies said. It said that it welcomed the attention given to families with children, particularly those on low and middle incomes. On the Institute's analysis of the Government's package, 70 per cent of families will gain more than $1,000 per annum. One-income families on average weekly earnings will receive an average gain of $24 a week, not including wage increases. The Institute, with its authority, says that the package appears to redress the erosion of income since 1976. The indexation of family benefits is an historically significant feature which will ensure that these payments will not be eroded in the future.

—I refer the Treasurer to today's prediction by Mr Nobby Clark, the Managing Director of the National Australia Bank Ltd. Has the Treasurer received advice from his Department that accords with his advice that mortgage interest rates will move higher?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have made the point about Mr Clark and the National Bank that his book is vulnerable to higher cost deposits and he is out talking his book all the time. I do not blame him for that, but let us understand what he is doing. The Commonwealth Bank has a different book: it has a greater level of savings bank accounts; it has a greater bank and storehouse of mortgages with repayment income each week to the bank, just as Westpac has. That is not true of the National Australia Bank. In 1986 it went out on a wing and a prayer lending for housing, got embarrassed and we had to bring in the bank subsidy to get it out of trouble. It is doing the same again. It has been taking deposits off the market and in those conditions it feels the stress. That is why Mr Clark talks about this every day.

ANSWER.PARA: However, the same Mr Clark argues that there should be no tax cuts. He believes that there should be a larger Budget surplus and no tax cuts. I ask Mr Clark to make available details of his income and to put his wage restraint against the income of the work force. I ask Mr Clark whether his executive staff would wear wage restraint through a period in which they could exploit the market.

The bank's profitability went up this year because we reduced the statutory reserve deposits. The chief deposits which came back to the banking system after October 1987 were all part and parcel of the high profits which the banks have enjoyed. As soon as they see some of that profit growth being threatened, they are out there on television squealing like stuck pigs every time they get a chance to do so. The public should understand that the interests of bankers are not their interests.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Prime Minister inform the House of the Budget strategies which have been adopted by the Government in relation to families?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Following the Social Security Review on income support for families with children, my Government introduced the family allowance supplement in 1987 to direct substantial additional assistance to low income families. That major reform was an integral part of Labor's commitment that by 1990 no child need live in poverty.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members-Will! Will! Will!

TALK.START.PARA: —I will disregard the noise from the other side and go to the facts. The facts concern the Australian people and they are substantial. The first is that, for the first time in Australia's history, relevant standards of adequacy were set for family payments. Madam Speaker, you will recall, as no doubt the House will recall, what those targets and standards were. They were 15 per cent of the combined married rate of pension for children under 13 years and 20 per cent for children between the age of 13 and 15 years. Those targets were set in 1987. The payments that should be made for each child in that age range were 15 or 20 per cent, respectively, of the combined married pension rate. It was agreed that as a result of that study, if those financial payments could be made by meeting those percentages of the married pension rate, it would deliver on the promise and the commitment that there be no financial need for children to live in poverty.

ANSWER.PARA: Against that background it is interesting to understand what happened last night. Last night's increase in family payments meets those benchmarks. We promised to meet them by 1990. In fact, we have met them by 1989. The increase recognises the additional costs incurred by Australian families with children, the costs of larger families and the costs of older children.

As a result of what was done last night a two-child family will receive from the family allowance payments alone an additional non-taxable $5.25 a week in assistance or, in other words, a 41 per cent increase. I give the aggregate impact of that on this country. In total it means that two million families-3.8 million Australian children-will benefit from last night's family allowance increases. The comprehensive package of measures announced last night, while benefiting all Australians, was targeted primarily towards low and middle income earners in this country.

Let us look at the statistics. Seventy-five per cent of Australian households earn less than $35,000 a year. It follows that those households are, and deserve to be, the major beneficiaries of last night's package, as indeed they are. This contrasts with the preoccupation in `Futile Diversions' with single income families. That category makes up only 18 per cent of Australian households. The difference between what is said and done by us and those opposite in their parade of prejudice and platitudes is that we deal with the realities. I am proud to say that I lead a government which has not waited until 1990 to deliver on its promises. In 1989 we have delivered on that promise to the benefit of 3.8 million Australian children.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Treasurer. In view of the Treasurer's dislike of the National Australia Bank, I refer him to yesterday's prediction by the Chief Economist for the Australia and New Zealand Bank that ANZ's reference interest rate would rise from 18 1/2 per cent to 20 per cent by the end of the year. Will the Treasurer spell out the effects of a rise in the reference rate on mortgage interest rates?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is an entirely different rate to the housing rate: the shadow Treasurer is speaking of the prime indicator rate. Most banks have a formula which shifts the rate up when there are movements in cash rates in the system and a general tightening of policy. I have said that I see no particular reason why, in a discretionary sense, we would tighten policy further. Therefore, if there is to be a change in that rate it will be at the discretion of the banks. The rate goes up regularly and, as we have seen in more moderate monetary conditions, it abates regularly. In other words, it moves more regularly. The stock of deposits which govern the housing rate is an entirely different proposition.

ANSWER.PARA: What prompts the question is the notion that the Opposition would have a different policy mix. I remind the Opposition that under its Leader in 1981 the rate for bills was 22 per cent; it is now 17.8 per cent. The Opposition should bear that in mind. It had fixed housing interest rates but no loans-that is, it had a rate of 13 1/2 per cent but there were no loans to be had. In other words, it was phoney. Before deregulation there were quantitative restrictions on loans and there was no money. When someone asked a bank whose housing rate was 13.5 per cent for a loan he was told, `Oh, there's no money'. The system was totally fictitious. That is how the monetary system used to operate in the days of regulation. The fact that the banks can borrow on the market and lend profitably at variable rates for housing has changed all that.

The shadow Treasurer made it clear in this House two days ago during a discussion on a matter of public importance that he would have a tight monetary policy. That is because he has no wages policy. That means that in current conditions, with the labour market as it is and demand as strong as it is, a coalition government, if it were in office now, would have much higher interest rates than the Government would have. Need I say, members of the Opposition shed crocodile tears about interest rates, when for most of the years up to 1983 they denied the work force a wage increase which is now worth 34 per cent of average weekly earnings. But they now say that they would pay wages in relation to the increase in productivity, which the shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Kooyong, says is less than one per cent. So, in the face of a 7 per cent inflation rate, they would increase wages by less than one per cent. The honourable member knows that that would immediately lead to a wage break-out on which he would employ, if he were Treasurer, a much tighter monetary policy and much higher interest rates than currently prevail.

TALK.START.PARA: —What information is the Minister for Industrial Relations able to provide on how the Government's wage-tax package and award restructuring will benefit the economy and provide greater flexibility in the labour market?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last night's wage-tax package is an historic achievement in the accord process. Honourable members opposite moan and groan and just cannot contemplate the consultation and consensus that are the background to the accord process. The commitment of the trade union movement to the elements of last night's package means that in the coming year we will be able to contain the increase in average weekly earnings to 6 1/2 per cent. We can compare that with the proposals that come from the Opposition. The Opposition wants the old catch and kill your own arrangement, each enterprise making its own industrial arrangements, each business-732,000 of them-making its own arrangements for wages and for job and work conditions. One knows what the result of that would be. It would be the same old wage explosion of 1981-82, the same old rampant inflation, the same old collapse in the economy, the same old massive increase in unemployment.

ANSWER.PARA: We can add the Opposition's fascinating formula for lifting family living standards. Its response has been that the tax cuts and the wage increases are inflationary in this rapidly growing economy. In other words, it is saying that the tax cuts are too high and the wage increases are too great. By keeping tax cuts down and by not giving wage increases other than of the order of one per cent, members of the Opposition would somehow lift family living standards in a magical fashion. It is a fascinating formula.

The wage increases that this Government is going to support before the Industrial Relations Commission are wage increases that are linked to participation in the award restructuring process, a process that will give us greater flexibility in the use of labour, increased productivity, increased efficiency and better trained workers and put this nation in a position where it can compete more ably with industries and countries abroad.

In the award restructuring process we will see an overhaul of the job classification process and work arrangements, abolition of demarcation problems and, as I said, greater flexibility in the use of labour. To that end I can say to the honourable member for Burke that the Government is providing some $12m in the coming year to assist employers and employees through that process of changing their job classifications and arrangements in the workplace and introducing the new training arrangements. That process is something that is new to the Opposition. It will be new to many of the managements in this country, but it is the fundamental change into which the trade union movement is locked through the accord process. That is the way in which we will enable Australian products and Australian services to become more competitive in this country and more competitive abroad. That will give us the ability to build on the 1.3 million new jobs that have been created under this Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Prime Minister: Will he assure the House that last night's economic statement will not be followed by further increases in home loan interest rates?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Leader of the Opposition gives further evidence to the fact that he is a considerably slow learner.
—That is an easy question.
—I know that it is a remarkably easy question and honourable members will get a very direct answer. I have made it clear that neither the Treasurer nor I will speculate in terms of--

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —There go these idiot noises again-no brains, big lungs, big bellows and no mind. Those opposite fool no-one with their noise. They are empty vessels. Why do they not just calm down?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The House will come to order.

INTERJECT.PARA: Mr Downer interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Little boy, calm down and listen.
—Order! The honourable member for Mayo has been told to come to order.

—As I was saying, neither the Treasurer nor I will speculate in terms of likely movements in the short term on interest rates because the very fact that either the Treasurer or I should undertake such speculation in regard to short term movements-as the honourable gentleman opposite, who has himself been Treasurer of this country, disastrously, would know-would of itself have an impact upon what will happen in the market. However, the Treasurer and I-and I am prepared to say it again-have put in place the macro-economic policies in terms of responsible fiscal policy, responsible wages policy, which together, as exemplified last night, will create the conditions that I believe and the Government believes in the longer term will have the impact of bringing interest rates down. There is no reason at all to doubt that.

ANSWER.PARA: As my colleague the Treasurer said, it ill becomes this failed Treasurer, that now temporary Leader of the Opposition, to talk about interest rates or any other aspect of macro-economic policy, because in all the externally imposed difficulties that this Government has had to operate under never at any stage, including at present, have we begun to approach the figure of 22 per cent interest rates which the previous Government brought about in this country. Why did it bring it about? Because it had no idea of how to conduct macro-economic policy in the central area of wages.

I remind the Leader of the Opposition that in each of the three years from 1980-81 to 1982-83 there was a double digit increase in wages; that is a fact. If the Leader of the Opposition has any understanding of the difference between the conduct of policy under this Government and under him, he ought-if he has not already-to turn to page 23 of attachment A, because it is all spelt out there. In figure 3 in attachment A there is set out, going back to September 1966 and up to the present, the correlation between wages movement and overtime. A second graph shows the correlation between wages movement and capacity utilisation. What we find is this: under the Leader of the Opposition's stewardship in 1981, the economy was booming, overtime was going up and capacity utilisation was rising. What did we see? Wages went up massively. What has happened under this Government? Overtime and capacity utilisation have gone up with a growing economy, but wages growth has been low. That is the essential difference between this side of the House and the other. We have the secret of the conduct of economic policy because we know how to control the level of wages.

Under the former Treasurer what happened was that when the economy started to move upwards wages exploded because he had no relationship at all with the trade union movement; he treated the trade union movement and the organised workers of this country with contempt; he regarded this area as a battleground. In the battleground that the previous Government created, it had wages going through the roof. I remind those opposite that this is what their proud record was: in each of the three years, 1980-81 to 1982-83, wages increased in double figures. When a government cannot control wages policy, that is the inevitable result. The inevitable result was what happened in 1982 and 1983: unemployment went through the roof.

The previous Government achieved the hitherto unachieved double. It got the great quinella: double digit inflation and double digit unemployment. No Treasurer in the history of this country had ever achieved that quinella before. And honourable members opposite have the temerity to get up in here and talk about interest rates. The reason why interest rates are high now is quite deliberate. They are high because we have got wages policy as tight as we can. We have got fiscal policy as tight as we can. One little thing the Opposition will have to do tonight is bring the people of Australia into its confidence. If the Opposition believes that fiscal policy can be tighter, it will have to face up to the barrier. If the Opposition would have tighter fiscal policy it will have to tell people where it would cut. Would it cut defence? Would it cut roads? Would it cut schools? Would it cut pensions? Where would it cut? Where would it make fiscal policy tighter?

If honourable members opposite ever face up to that barrier there will be an almighty yawn from the people of Australia. They will say `Johnny, you have been there. You have tried it. We gave you the responsibility. You did what no other Treasurer has ever done. In percentage terms, you got double digit unemployment and double digit inflation. We have tried you once. We don't want you again'. But honourable members opposite probably will not be given that opportunity because the most interesting statistic around this Parliament at the moment is the number 34, the current tally of votes the shadow Treasurer has in the attack that he is making upon the leadership of the Leader of the Opposition. If any figure is likely to rise in the next few days it will be the number 34 because the intelligence is that gradually the shadow Treasurer is increasing his numbers. I hope that he does.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Social Security aware of claims that the better-off aged have the most to lose from yesterday's economic statement? Can the Minister advise the House of the validity of these claims?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Sydney Morning Herald today carries quite false claims regarding the impact of the Government's economic statement on retirees. It begins with the false premise that a married couple with income of just over $20,000 is ineligible for the age pension and, therefore, miss out on government assistance. The facts are that pensioner eligibility for a married couple does not cease until private non-pension income reaches $484.20 a week combined, just over $25,000 per annum. Therefore, the retiree couple example in the article with a private income of $420 a week would have a pension entitlement of $32.10 or $1,669.20 per annum. If they were renting privately they would be entitled to additional assistance.

ANSWER.PARA: From the false premise that this couple would have no pension entitlement, the author proceeds to label the couple as the biggest losers from the Hawke Government's mini-Budget. Far from losing, such a couple would gain from the bringing forward of their pension indexation rises in three stages to secure by 1990 the speediest indexation of consumer price index (CPI) increases in history. By then pensions will be paid at a higher indexed rate for 24 weeks of each year. They would gain $6.72 a week in tax cuts from the tax changes announced last night by the Treasurer, as acknowledged in the article concerned.

The article also claims the gains made by such a couple would be eroded or even exceeded by changes to the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. That is equally false. As my colleague the Treasurer indicated last night, pensions will not be affected by changes in relation to the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. So, far from this couple being losers, it is more than likely that they would want to join the Australian Pensioners Federation in describing the Treasurer's announcements last night as good news for Australia's older people. The Australian Pensioners Federation correctly understood that the two reforms with respect to the aged announced last night were both unprecedented reforms, that is, they were not marginal changes. They were changes that mean, firstly, that the delay with respect to the CPI will be referred to an earlier point than ever before.

Secondly, for the first time full rate pensioners will pay no tax at all. The income test free area will become equivalent to the tax free area. This second change is also historic. It will benefit 80 per cent of aged pensioners. It means that 80 per cent of aged pensioners-more than one million pensioners-will not pay tax. One can understand the Australian Pensioners Federation welcoming last night's decisions as part of the Government's review of retirement incomes.

It is impossible to avoid the contrast between the Government and the Opposition, either in respect of families or of the aged. In the case of families, in the Opposition's period in government we had ad hoc reforms, which were never pursued and which never resulted in any real change, reforms that melted like ice in the Sahara. In respect of the aged this Government has made two more significant reforms, not as the end of a reform process, as is understood by the Pensioners Federation, but in the context of the review by Professor Cass of the retirement incomes system and as the first major instalment of what will be a comprehensive review of retirement incomes. That is the difference. Under the previous Government we had ad hoc changes and a deterioration of living standards. This Government not only has achieved substantial reforms but also will ensure that those reforms are entrenched and will remain for decades to come.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Treasurer: In the light of last night's economic statement, is the assumption in his Forward Estimates of a consumer price index increase of around 4.25 per cent to 4.5 per cent in 1989-90 still valid or is the projection by the Minister for Land Transport and Shipping Support earlier this week of a CPI increase this year of between 7 and 8 per cent correct? Would the Treasurer now advise the House what his current projection is for inflation next year?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The increase will certainly be higher than 4.5 per cent. We have made that clear for a long time now. But as I said yesterday-I repeat it-we expect inflation to decelerate over the course of 1989-90 and 1990-91. We have secured a better wages outcome than the market would otherwise have secured under the kind of policy mix which the Opposition would administer. That will permit a decline in inflation over time, particularly as productivity improves. The measure of productivity will improve as employment slows somewhat. We will see the productivity improvements of the last couple of years eking their reward on the measure of productivity, thus reducing inflation even further over time.

ANSWER.PARA: I remind the right honourable member that his colleagues the shadow Treasurer and the shadow finance spokesman did not understand the difference between the non-farm gross domestic product deflator, which had export prices in it, and the broadest measure of consumption, the implicit consumption deflator, which was 7.1 per cent for the year. That is much closer to the level which the Government believes inflation is really at now, around 7 per cent. That is why the Australian Statistician is now reviewing his methodology regarding the measure of housing costs in the CPI for the next quarter. It is awfully difficult to predict what the CPI may be when we are uncertain what methodology the Statistician will finally employ.

TALK.START.PARA: —Would the Prime Minister advise the House on the extent of the Government's commitment to improve Australian schools?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Brand for her question. I remind her-she would well know this and it should certainly be remembered on the other side of the House-that under this Government the year 12 retention rate has increased from 36 per cent in 1982 to 57 per cent. It is interesting to compare that tremendous increase with what happened in the last five years of our predecessors, when the rate went up by one per cent. It moved up from 35 per cent to 36 per cent in the last five years of the Government of our predecessors.

ANSWER.PARA: As a result of the Government's concern for social justice, increased retention has not been occurring only in middle class schools. It is very important that this be understood. Year 12 completion rates amongst the lowest socioeconomic groups in society are also increasing dramatically. Children from the most underprivileged 10 per cent of our society, in the very lowest socioeconomic category, are now completing their full secondary education in about the same proportion as the great bulk of children in the middle socioeconomic groups. I believe that is something which this whole country ought to be profoundly proud of and gratified by. I speak with pride, as the leader of this Government, at having seen that dramatic change.

The stagnation under this Government's predecessors meant that we inherited a country with an abysmally low retention rate compared with that of any other developed country with which Australia would normally compare itself. Of the many bitter legacies left after seven years of conservative government, many of which honourable members opposite should be totally ashamed of, there is none of which they should be more ashamed than that 36 per cent retention rate. All Australians-irrespective of their political persuasion and socioeconomic group-should take pleasure in the fact that our greatest asset, Australian children, as a result of the policies of this Government are now staying on in school. This applies no matter what socioeconomic group the children come from. It does not matter how low the income of their parents is; because we have more than doubled the rate of the secondary allowance to kids and undertaken a range of other reforms, these children are now staying on in schools. Honourable members opposite should be ashamed of their record. Our record is something that we are entitled to be proud of, and the whole Australian community is entitled to share in that pride.

As proud as we are-and we are indeed proud of that great achievement-more can always be achieved in education. Of course, to achieve it, given the division of powers we have in this country, there has to be cooperation between the Commonwealth Government and the governments of the States. All Australians know that in regard to education there is this division of power and responsibility between the Commonwealth and the States. While the honourable member for Brand and all other members of the House will know that we cannot tell States what to do with their schools, we can and do encourage them to participate in initiatives which will assist schools in meeting the undoubted challenges that they now face with these increased retention rates. The honourable member for Brand will be interested to know that a year ago I wrote to all State Premiers asking them to support a Commonwealth initiative called Strengthening Australia's Schools. This document--

TALK.START.PARA: —A bit like--

—This subject is far too important to be interrupted by the honourable member's ridiculous and irrelevant observations. This document, produced by my colleague the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, set an agenda to strengthen Australia's schools which include national goals for schooling; and annual national report on schools; common curriculum frameworks; and the removal of unnecessary differences between school systems, particularly between States. I think all members of this House, irrespective of which side they sit on, will understand the very considerable difficulties for Australian families-remembering that some half a million young Australians move home each year-that are entailed in having eight different education systems.
—But they don't go from State to State.
—Order! The member for Deakin will not interject again.

—The honourable member for Deakin does not even know what a CAE is, so I do not think we need to worry about him. The Australian Education Council, which, as honourable members know, is a body comprising all the State Ministers in conjunction with the Commonwealth Minister for education, met several times in the past year to consider the issues raised in this document issued by my colleague the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. At its meeting in Tasmania this weekend, which the Minister will attend, the Australian Education Council will, I hope, make a commitment to implement reform in these areas.

ANSWER.PARA: I repeat that the future of these and other reforms lies ultimately in the hands of the State Ministers for education. The Commonwealth has taken an important initiative to lead this debate. But the simple and unavoidable fact is that, without the cooperation and agreement of the State education Ministers, our attempt to strengthen Australia's education system still further will not succeed. I hope that I speak on behalf of every single member of this House in expressing the hope that at this important meeting of the Australian Education Council this weekend-when it has before it the agenda, the opportunities and the challenges set out in the Commonwealth document-all those present will be able to rise above party political considerations and put the interests of Australian children first. That is something honourable members opposite were not able to do when they were in government. We have done it federally, and we hope that, with the cooperation of all the States, we will be able to improve further the quality, the quantity and the relevance of Australia's education for its greatest asset; that is, the children of Australia.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hewson Dr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Treasurer to a statement he made in his press conference on the February balance of payments, when he said:

QUESTION.PARA: Now, the only way we can increase the available savings within Australia is by a program, an ambitious program, of even further public sector dissaving. And if we believe that cannot succeed, there is only one instrument to be using, and that is monetary policy to actually reduce the size of the investment phase.
I ask the Treasurer: Given that he is now running down his public sector surplus, does he intend to use monetary policy to contain the prospective boost to consumption from last night's mini-Budget?

TALK.START.PARA: —I said here two years ago that this gentleman prides himself on having some technical facility.
—He runs rings around you.

—Well, the honourable member would like to hope he would but he is not, is he? That is what worries honourable members opposite. More professors of economics have sunk without trace in here than Premiers. There is one two rows back. But the honourable member for Berowra has something going for him-we like him. The premise of the question is that we have run down the surplus. Two days ago the shadow Minister asked me about unfunded tax cuts from a surplus, and I made the point, `How could they be unfunded from a surplus?'. He put out a press statement saying, `I have been saying this often. The press knows that. The frequency of the misinformation guarantees that it should be taken notice of'. It was the most absurd comment I have ever seen. We now have talk about running down the Budget surplus. The Government is saying that next year the Budget surplus will be at least $5.5 billion-no less than this year's surplus. There is no running down of the surplus. Therefore, the net difference between one year and the next in relation to the stimulus coming from public policy is zero. There is no difference from this year in the stimulus coming from public policy with a $5.5 billion surplus next year. So the whole premise on which the question is predicated is wrong.
—Come on, you are struggling.

—Come on! The honourable member for Wentworth is supposed to be the professor of economics. He must have got his chair at the University of New South Wales out of a lucky dip. If the honourable member does not understand that a surplus of $5.5 billion next year following a surplus of $5.5 billion this year adds nothing to the stimulus to the economy-it might change the composition of demand, but it adds nothing to the fiscal stimulus coming from the Commonwealth-he ought to go back and re-swot his textbooks.

—I refer the Treasurer to the statement he tabled last night in the House, indicating that the tax cuts would more than offset what is known as fiscal drag or bracket creep. Would he please explain to the House why this is so and how it compares with other recent periods in Australian history?
—You are the bracket creep.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The member for Deakin is such a scintillating wit. The shadow Minister did one clever thing in his life; he chose his business partner well. In dealing with this question of fiscal drag, during all of yesterday the Opposition tried to give credence to the lie that, had the Government indexed the tax scales back in 1983, somehow there would have been a lower tax burden on the Australian taxpayer. The fact is that, had the Government indexed the tax scales from 1983, there would have been a larger tax burden than there is now, because mathematically the Government has given back more than tax indexation would have.

ANSWER.PARA: The facts which the Opposition ignores in its analysis are the employment growth and the fairness in the tax system by the broadening of the tax base, making former avoiders and evaders pay their way so there is more revenue. That increase in revenue does not imply that there has been anything less than tax indexation since 1983. The Opposition can persist with this line of argument if it chooses. It is mathematically wrong. It will finally have to abandon it or correct it. It had best abandon it, rather than correct it, by not continuing to peddle it.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, I seek your indulgence, to add to an answer I gave in the House yesterday.
—My indulgence is granted.

—Yesterday, the honourable member for Chisholm raised with me a question concerning health insurance coverage before the introduction of Medicare. He asked me to provide the basis of my statement of the previous week that Medicare enfranchised the two million Australians who were without health cover under the previous Government. The answer to the honourable member's question is contained on page 1 of the very Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) Bulletin `Health Insurance Survey March 1983' to which he referred yesterday. Let me quote, for his benefit, from page 1 of the bulletin from which he quoted. This is what it states:

ANSWER.PARA: 1,031,500 contributor units (containing 1,826,300 persons) were without health insurance cover and were not identified in the survey as having access to special Commonwealth health benefits. In March 1982 there were an estimated 1,129,300 such contributor units (1,953,000 persons).

Table 14, to which the honourable member referred, deals with contributor units, not individual Australians, as claimed in his question. Here is a medical practitioner who one would assume knew the difference between contributor units and individuals. My statement, therefore, is validated by the ABS bulletin. The assertion by the honourable member for Chisholm that 1,031,000 Australians were uninsured is plainly, simply wrong. Let the doctor go and do his homework. I hope his prescriptions are better than his analyses in this place.

I do not wish to detain the House longer by providing more detail about further mistaken assertions contained in the honourable member's question. I therefore table, for the information of the House, a copy of the letter which I have provided today to the honourable member for Chisholm, putting right his profoundly and obviously incorrect statement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shack Mr P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek your indulgence, Madam Speaker, to make a brief but concise submission to you on standing order 145.
—Are you asking a question of the Speaker?
—No, I am seeking your indulgence to make a brief submission to you on the status of standing order 145.
—My indulgence is granted.

—Thank you for your indulgence, Madam Speaker. I make this submission after Question Time, not wishing to be accused of interrupting Question Time and in recognition of the fact that you warned the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) for raising points of order under standing order 145. It is a brief submission. I ask you to hear me out. I do not wish to engage in argument with the Government.
—I interrupt you for one moment. I warned the honourable member for O'Connor for shouting across the table when he was out of order. It had nothing to do with standing order 145.
—Thank you, Madam Speaker. Standing order 145 is a very brief standing order, as I have pointed out in a previous submission to you. It simply states:

SPEECH.PARA: An answer shall be relevant to the question.

In responding to my earlier submission, Madam Speaker, you came back into the chamber and pointed out that in the Chair's opinion it was very difficult to define relevance. My submission to you is that relevance has been defined by a previous Speaker, Speaker Snedden. That definition has been employed by you as we, on a number of occasions, have reminded you. In the Parliament, on 27 August 1981, Speaker Snedden said:
The Minister will answer the question and not engage in irrelevancies, such as contrasting the Government and the Labor Party.

We, at that time, were in government and the Labor Party was in opposition. My submission to you, Madam Speaker-I will come to a conclusion very quickly-is that standing order 145 has been defined by a previous Speaker; there is a precedent. If you go through all of your rulings-I will not draw them to your attention-you will find that on some occasions you have adhered to that precedent and on others you have not.

I recognise that contrasting one political party with another is the substance of politics. But the substance of standing order 145 is that one does not do it in Question Time. There are plenty of times to do it under the Standing Orders. Both sides of politics engage in that sort of contrast. But standing order 145 is supposed to ensure that honourable members may ask questions of the Government and they may receive from the Government succinct answers. I conclude on this point: it is very likely that this Parliament is soon to be prorogued for an election. As you know, Madam Speaker, things get very hot in this chamber as we get to election time. You, yourself, have but a few weeks, I would imagine, before you retire.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr Beazley

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, I wish to raise a point of order.

INTERJECT.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, there is nothing wrong with raising points of order when an honourable member is speaking with the indulgence of the Chair. There are very strict provisions in Standing Orders about reflection on the Chair. Quite clearly, the last remark which the honourable member directed towards you, Madam Speaker, which suggested that your time in this place was to be foreshortened-particularly the way in which he presented it-whilst not by any means the most severe insult which has ever been imposed upon you by the Opposition, nevertheless, was outside the area of indulgence and a reflection upon you. I would seek that you protect yourself on this matter.

—If I ruled on that I would not rule it in order. I would consider it an error of judgment made by the honourable member for Tangney and not a prediction of what will happen to me or my health. The honourable member for Tangney may conclude his remarks.

—Madam Speaker, I will conclude, simply by asking you to reply to my submission-not today, but to take the next fortnight to consider it-and to come back into the Parliament when we resume in May to uphold the integrity of Question Time; to uphold the status of standing order 145 and, indeed, to secure for your place, and for you as a Speaker a lasting reputation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, I seek your indulgence to make one or two points on the same matter.
—My indulgence is granted.

—The point about relevance and Speaker Snedden's direction in that particular instance obviously depends on the nature of the question asked and whether the nature of the question asked permits a contrast of Government and Opposition policy. Nobody in this place-not you or me-who has sat in opposition can recollect a Question Time in which an occasion was not taken to contrast Government and Opposition policy-indeed, this has occurred when the honourable member for Tangney (Mr Shack) has been here. Standing order 142, which outlines the way in which questions may be put to Ministers, states:

SPEECH.PARA: Questions may be put to a Minister relating to public affairs with which he is officially connected, to proceedings pending in the House, or to any matter of administration for which he is responsible.

The public affairs with which a Minister is officially connected obviously incorporate those public affairs related to policy development in the area of the Minister. Obviously, there will be a wide variety of views circulating in the community, and for a Minister to be deprived of opportunities to comment on those views, be they from the Opposition or anyone else, and whether those views constitute a rational course as opposed to the course the Government follows, is clearly within the anticipation of Standing Orders and was clearly endorsed by Speaker Snedden when he was in the chair on the many occasions when he permitted a contrast to take place between Government and Opposition polices.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Chair will take on board what the honourable member for Tangney has had to say and will reply to him at a later date.
