SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spender Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I seek leave to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—I do, comprehensively.
—Leave is granted.

—I claim to have been misrepresented by Mr Laurie Oakes in the most recent edition of the Bulletin under the heading `Back to the '50s'. Mr Oakes claims that the coalition is `unwilling to acknowledge or understand' the dramatic changes that are taking place in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe and implied that I do not see much difference between Stalin and Gorbachev. Neither of those claims is true.

SPEECH.PARA: The coalition's foreign policy was released at a public launch, noted by Mr Oakes in his article, to which I personally invited him. He is a busy man; he did not attend. If he had, he would have heard me speak of a time of change, of hope and welcomed reform in the Soviet Union and some Eastern bloc states, of a more stable, constructive international climate, with agreement on intermediate-range nuclear forces (INF) and progress on strategic nuclear systems, to take but two areas. He would also have heard me express my hope that one day we might welcome the Soviet Union to the ranks of the democracies, hardly the views of someone ignoring the processes of change or who sees little difference between the dreadful Stalin era and the present time of hope.

Having missed the opening, and not having bothered to canvass with me separately my views on the Soviet Union-which I would have thought to have been fairly basic before attacking them-he even managed significantly to misrepresent the coalition's policy. Mr Oakes chose to ignore the policy's specific references to radical reformists in Eastern Europe--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order. Claims of misrepresentation under Standing Orders should be addressed by reference to where a member has been misrepresented. If the policy of a party has been misrepresented, the matter can be dealt with in the various forms of debate in this place, not by way of personal explanation.
—Yes. I would like the honourable member for North Sydney to restrict his explanation to where he personally has been misrepresented.

—Yes, most certainly. Mr Oakes said that `Spender's policy mentions glasnost and perestroika in passing'. In fact, Mr Oakes chose to ignore in `Spender's policy' specific references to radical reformists in Eastern Europe, our welcome of Soviet policy reassessment which led to the INF agreement, and the withdrawal from Afghanistan. He also ignored our call for exploring opportunities for constructive agreements in relations with the Soviet Union and Eastern bloc states and the following statement by me in the policy, which I drafted, on Gorbachev's domestic reforms, namely:

SPEECH.PARA: Gorbachev is trying to revitalise the system with more economic incentives and competition, individualism and openness, legality and political accountability.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, on a point of order: while we are intrigued by the fact that Opposition policy has come to the point of discussing the Soviet Union, this is no longer a question of personal misrepresentation. It is a debate or a presentation of policy. This really is an abuse of this period of time in the House.
—I ask the honourable member for North Sydney to wind up and say where he has personally been misrepresented.
—There are other matters, which I will go to. Mr Oakes also said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . it makes no sense to behave as though the cold war is still going on.
I entirely agree and I have never at any time suggested that it was still going on.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker: this really is becoming absurd. This has absolutely nothing to do with a personal explanation. I urge you to ask the honourable gentleman to draw his explanation to a conclusion. He is debating a matter of policy which he could raise as a matter of public importance. That is quite clearly open to him.
—I have already done that. I ask the honourable member for North Sydney to bring his personal explanation to a close.
—I refer then to another statement, concerning me directly, made by Mr Oakes. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: He-
namely `Spender'-
conveniently ignores the fact that the US itself has had such an agreement . . .
He said that in respect of fishing agreements. I should like to quote, if I may, from a statement which I had previously made--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member has gone far enough with his personal explanation.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, Mr Oakes has claimed that I ignored a certain matter.
—You have said that you did not and I think you have made that clear.
—Not only did I not conveniently ignore it, but I explicitly referred to the matter in a press release of 13 May 1988.
—I ask the honourable member now to resume his seat.
—Furthermore--

—I ask the honourable member to resume his seat. I consider that he has informed the House where he has been misrepresented. He is now going on to quote from lengthy documents, which is not getting to the point.
—No, Mr Deputy Speaker. I was simply going to make the point that not only did Mr Oakes--
—I ask the honourable member to resume his seat.
—Not only did Mr Oakes not get things right; he did not even seek to get things right.
—The honourable member for North Sydney will resume his seat.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I seek leave to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—I do, sir.
—Please proceed.

—At the end of Question Time today the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) added to his response to a question that he was unable to answer yesterday and claimed that my figures were incorrect. For the record, I say that the Australian Bureau of Statistics document shows 1,031,500 contributor units without health insurance, of which 391,800 live in Queensland. The Prime Minister knows very well that people in Queensland had access--
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order.
—I inform the Leader of the House that I have been listening carefully to the honourable member.

—My point of order is that the honourable member is now going on to debate the matter. He is arguing the position of Queensland. He says he has been misrepresented. There is a very limited ambit for misrepresentation discussions in this House. He can make these points on the adjournment.
—That is certainly the case. I was listening carefully and I am sure the honourable member will not go on to debate the matter but will show where he has been misrepresented.

—I have no intention of debating the matter. I just want to say what the facts are. The Prime Minister said my figures were incorrect. I seek briefly to show that the Prime Minister was not correct in the assertion he was making. If one takes out Queensland, one is left with 639,700 people. If one takes out those eligible for a health care card, one is left with 449,400 people. If one takes out those who are healthy enough, one is left with 376,500 contribution units.

—On a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker: the honourable member is not at all within bounds. Obviously this lengthy debate on statistics is appropriate for the adjournment debate and is not a point of personal misrepresentation. Personal explanations are being consistently abused in this place.

—On the point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker: the honourable member is entitled to point out the facts on which he claims he has been misrepresented. He was doing that very concisely. The Leader of the House is anticipating what he may or may not do. I suggest it is for you to determine whether the honourable member breaches protocol in these matters. The honourable member has not been given the opportunity to point out the basic facts, so that he may then claim to have been misrepresented in a most ungraceful way by the Prime Minister.
—I will allow the honourable member to point out to the House where he has been personally misrepresented.

—I have been personally misrepresented because if one multiplies this last figure by 1.77 one gets 666,000 Australians, not two million as the Prime Minister was suggesting. I have done my homework and I will put my integrity against the Prime Minister's any time.
—I seek leave to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—I do.
—The honourable member may proceed.

—I refer to some comments made by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in Question Time today when he suggested that I had spoken of tax cuts unfunded out of a surplus. I did not. I said they were unfunded in the sense that they were not accompanied by necessary expenditure restraint.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker has received a letter from the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The adverse impact of continued high interest rates and high inflation on living standards flowing from the Treasurer's economic statement.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to commence this discussion of a matter of public importance by quoting from an editorial in the Australian newspaper of today's date. I will start not at the beginning but with three brief quotations. This refers to last night's economic statement:

SPEECH.PARA: The inescapable conclusion is that it no longer has a policy other than preserving the accord with the trade unions.
That refers to the Government. Earlier the editorial says:

But having finally admitted that the key forecasts of the Budget cannot be achieved, the Government still has not explained what its economic strategy is, or detailed its revised forecasts. On the contrary, it has even covered up its own calculations.
Those two statements are damning enough, but let me take the House to the first paragraph:

The most telling assessment of the contents of the Hawke Government's package of give-aways is Mr Keating's statement: `If a Government cannot run wages in Australia it cannot run the Australian economy.' Last night the Government disqualified itself from running the Australian economy.
And that is it. The editorial in the Australian said that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Written by a rabid right winger.

—Here we go. It was like all those people in the audience on the television program last night; 99 per cent of them vote Labor but the Treasurer (Mr Keating) was into them as tories. He would not have a bar of them because they would not listen to him. Honourable members know what happened last night, of course. Those people came along here last night and they could see through the cruel hoax that the statement was and the cynicism that they felt is rampant today. I will not confine myself if the Treasurer wants to do a good spray around of the editorial writer of the Australian. Let us get on to his old mate Paddy McGuinness.
—He is just as mad.
—I will get that into Hansard by saying that it ought to go on the record. Paddy McGuinness wrote in the Australian:

SPEECH.PARA: The saddest thing about all this is that it shows that the Treasurer, who not so long ago was offering himself as a source of dynamism and new ideas that would infuse a government of which he would be the Prime Minister, has shown that he is devoid of ideas, groping for support, lacking in dynamism, and hopelessly lost in a policy blind alley.

There may have been a parting of the ways in recent times, for which fact we are sorry, but Ross Gittins-a former close friend of the Treasurer and certainly an advocate for the policies he was pursuing-wrote:

At last Paul Keating's new economic strategy is revealed: Step 1, get re-elected. Step 2, worry about the economy after the election . . . But you don't need a degree in economics to find the catch. It's the pressing matter Mr Keating hardly mentioned: interest rates.

And that is it-interest rates, and that is the motivation for this matter of public importance. The Government's tax cuts and wage rises will be swallowed up by high interest rates, high inflation and high taxes. At Question Time I heard the Prime Minister refer to some quinella in answering a question and relating it to the performance of the previous Government. I can do one better than that. I can refer to the Keating trifecta. Last night we got the usual Keating trifecta-high inflation, high interest rates and hyperbole-and so much of it. This economic statement is at root a recipe for high interest rates and high inflation. The Treasurer can give the editorial writer a spray, but nothing he says in here can take away from the fact that the Managing Director of the National Australia Bank Ltd, Mr Nobby Clark has predicted that under the current economic policies pursued by the Treasurer, mortgage interest rates will increase further.

Last night the Treasurer did not even give the nation a forecast of inflation. The forecast for average weekly earnings appears on the low side. With no guarantee of productivity improvements, wages growth will fuel inflationary pressures, leaving nobody better off. Because wages are unrelated virtually to productivity, the increases will fuel inflation. The Treasurer came in here and told the House about the wages accord and award restructuring. His wages policy, dressed up as award restructuring, involves stitching up a deal with the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) leadership and shoving it down the throats of all Australian employers and businesses which are forced to live with the consequences. The headline of the Australian editorial I quoted from reads: `A package for the ACTU, not Australia'. We ought to get Kelty along here, bring him to the bar of the House and let him tell us-- Mr Keating-He would eat you alive.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will tell you what, mate: if he came in here, we would be hearing from the ventriloquist and not the dummy; so bring him in. And if he comes in we might ask him about how the Treasurer consummated this little deal last weekend. The Treasurer got into bed with him over the weekend and I would like to ask whether he still respected you in the morning. I would like him in here to answer a few of these questions. The Treasurer has implicated what he calls a wages policy. He ought to have a look at it. I have a document here and, as I said, it it like a grid; everything connects to everything. That is interesting. Either Lenin or Marx said years ago that everything related to everything and everything connected to everything. It is interesting that it should have been one of those two because, just on the point of Lenin and Marx, the Treasurer is about the only person running an economy these days who is going backwards and trying to centralise things. Even in the Soviet Union the Government is trying to free the system up-but not the Treasurer here.

SPEECH.PARA: I have here the new wages policy of the Government, that is, the national wage case submission of the Australian Council of Trade Unions. It was the old award restructuring which was accepted by the Government. It is in the form of a grid. The Treasurer drops the Government's wages policy in the grid; he gives a figure to the metals industries as an increase and off the policy goes, all over the grid. The increase is given to the fitter, the carpenter and the building industry. It is a most unbelievable proposition. This wages policy is already the most unsuccessful wages policy in the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) countries because it has delivered high inflation in every year, abysmal productivity growth, low real wages, one of the highest unit labour costs in the OECD countries and total factor productivity declining by 0.2 per cent a year. The Treasurer talks about a wages policy that increases wages in relation to productivity. We have had an increase of only 0.5 per cent in productivity. That is all the Treasurer has given. I would be totally ashamed if I was the Treasurer and I said that productivity was only 0.5. It would not, of course, happen under us. We give employers and employees the right to negotiate at the enterprise or industry level to take account of what is transpiring in their own area. If they do not want to do it and they want to remain within the Treasurer's so-called centralised system, we will amend the Industrial Relations Act and require the Australian Industrial Relations Commission to take account of productivity, employment, inflation and international competition. That is vastly different; it is related to what is actually happening. That is a wages policy. It is not like the grid that I have here where the Treasurer drops a wages policy in and it spews through wherever it moves, with everything going up, thus retreating to the old comparative wage justice notion and further cementing rigidities at a time when the test has to be for this economy. If the Treasurer was right about freeing up the financial system and the banks, the test is to free up the labour market, and the party which can do it is the party to govern Australia. That is the point. It is not the person who can fit into this slot or grid. That is the harsh reality today.

TALK.START.PARA: —You wouldn't know what you were doing.

—I hear the Treasurer interjecting. I will use the phrase that he used again last night: if a government cannot run wages in Australia, it cannot run the Australian economy. We have heard what the Australian newspaper thinks about that. We think that the Treasurer is right. The Treasurer has the worst wages policy. The Treasurer is running the economy into the ground with low living standards and huge foreign debt. Unlike the Government, as I have just explained, we are free to formulate our own wages policy giving back to employers and employees in factories and at the industry level the right to settle working conditions and wages. We will give back to Australian workers the right to organise their own affairs and, hence, the opportunity to raise productivity and real wages. That, in association with the amendments that I talk of in terms of the direction of the Industrial Relations Commission, is a real wages policy. It is not some dolliedup version of a centralised system with rigidities given to the Government by the ACTU.

SPEECH.PARA: After the tax changes, there is one inexorable fact, that is, the Treasurer will continue to hold his position as Australia's highest taxing Treasurer in postwar history. He is the highest taxing Treasurer in the history of the nation. We know of the figures and the fiddling that the Government is about. Whether one is on average weekly earnings or cutting into the top rate when one earns $35,000, we know of the impact of high rates of taxation under this Government. Even the tax cuts make negligible changes to the top marginal rate for wage earners earning above $20,600 per annum. This is well below average weekly earnings. As a result, there will be very little additional incentive for Australians earning more than $20,600 to work and to save. At the end of the year, most Australians will be no better off and most Australians will still have little incentive to work harder.

The Treasurer's gamble with the living standards of Australians will simply not pay off. This wage-tax deal, as I said near the outset, is a cruel hoax. In one breath, the Treasurer offers tax cuts but in the very next he sets an economic policy which will devour the tax cuts. What he gives with the one hand he takes away with the three. It is the old trifecta again-other than the hyperbole-of high interest rates, high inflation and more tax.

What we witnessed last night was a total abrogation of economic leadership by this Government in the pursuit of a cheap election bribe. This out of touch Treasurer, as I sat with him in a studio last night, could not comprehend the disillusionment of the Australian people with what he had introduced. As I said last night, the Budget strategy remains in tatters with every projection gone asunder. Inflation was to be 4.5 per cent; it is nearly double that. It is certainly well in excess of 7 per cent-closer to 8 per cent. Interest rates were to come down; they have gone up. The balance of payments was to have improved; it has deteriorated. It moved me to say on one occasion that the consequence now is that the national accounts look like the balance sheet of the Victorian Division of the National Safety Council of Australia. It is not something to be proud of. There is no forecast, nevertheless, of inflation. There is no forecast despite high inflation and high interest rates that are crippling people. Perhaps the Treasurer is having difficulty counting; I do not know. Last year I recall saying that he was forced to count on eight fingers. That left him two to say `G'day' to the Prime Minister-but he was having a battle at that time. His campaign manager has gone to bed. He has given up that now. So I suppose he is counting with eight fingers and the other two are permanently crossed.

That is about all that Australia has going for it at the moment. At root the statement was a disgrace. At root the Treasurer produced a hoax. The Treasurer has been doing interviews around Australia today and so have I. I have never known a reaction like it. Commentator after commentator has seen through what the Treasurer has done. It is a sham and the Australian people will take it out on the Treasurer and the retribution will be strong. If the Treasurer thinks that he can pull a ploy like that and get support, brother, has he got something coming.

As a political ploy, last night's statement was a disgrace. It was a failure. As an economic policy, last night's statement was a disgrace and a failure. That pretty well sums up the record of this Government. It is a disgrace and a failure to millions of Australians who have seen through the Treasurer's hoax last night. No amount of moving the figures around and stroking the platitudes until they purr will give the Treasurer anything but a warm inner glow. Those who are struggling at the end of the day know that an environment of high inflation and high interest rates will simply erode the benefit of their tax cuts. They know not only that the wages rises, will be hit by more taxation but also that the fact that they are unrelated to productivity means that the Treasurer will fuel inflation. Whilst we have all the dressage in advance of the event, with the posing of economic responsibility as a guise of the means whereby the Treasurer was bringing in a responsible statement, we have one that will continue to have Australians living with depressed living standards and with little chance at all. If the Treasurer pulls this as an election ploy, he is closer to a kamikaze pilot than I ever thought.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The speech by the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock) was very entertaining. He really missed his calling as either a horse owner or an actor. I suppose it is true he knows more about horses than the rest of us but he does not know much about economics. At the moment the key thing is to know about economics and public policy and not about horses. All his comments about dressage, horses, strutting and the rest come, as an old show pony from Flemington, as an easy jump across the lobes to produce. But the fact is that it is not an easy jump when it comes to a bit of substantial policy.

SPEECH.PARA: We hear about the Australian newspaper. Of course, journalists at the Australian think they are a bunch of William F. Buckley Juniors putting forward the new conservative model. But honourable members should just cop this. The editorial in the Australian says:
The package imposes a wage equivalent rise of 12 per cent on the economy . . .

That is, the Australian newspaper bases an editorial on a wage cost on the economy twice what it actually will be. That is not called conservatism; that is just plain incompetence. The wage cost to the employers and to the nation is 6 1/2 per cent. Yet the Australian says:
Yet the package imposes a wage equivalent rise of 12 per cent on the economy.
Some paper cut-out of William F. Buckley Jr tapped away in fury at the typewriter to produce this drivel for the rest of us this morning. We will say no more about him.

The modest agenda of Paddy McGuinness-the real wage overhang, do honourable members remember that?-was drummed into our heads by him over about five or six years along with a few other modest objectives. We met that. We exceeded his modest agenda in 15 months. He has had it in for us ever since. There is nothing like the wrath of the jilted guru. The fact is that he has now addressed it to that right wing broadsheet-the Australian newspaper-where he can prosper with this right wing rot. It was not that long ago that Paddy was wandering down Fleet Street in a bowler hat with a black rolled-up parasol playing the London banker number. He then got into the black priest-like uniform and played the economic guru, the salvation of Australia. But when we ran past that modest agenda he was awfully chuffed, and he remains chuffed to this day. Good old Paddy. He is now rotting away in the Australian.

The honourable member for Kooyong then talked about Ross Gittins. Ross Gittins is somebody I admire. But I say seriously that the sad thing about Ross Gittins is that he does not have the personal courage to write what he actually believes. That is not something that I can say about most journalists but, sadly, I now have to say it about Ross. I hope that he sees the error of his ways before long and goes back to being the great journalist he once was.

Let me get on to the real issue about award restructuring. The shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Kooyong, talked about shoving it down the throats of employers. In other words, we will shove 6 1/2 per cent down the throats of employers when employers would shove 16 1/2 per cent down their own throats. Employers would pay a wage increase of 15 to 16 per cent. By using the Budget surplus to carry the tax cuts we are bringing about a cost to employers of 6 1/2 per cent. Every employer in the country would have put up a cheer last night knowing that it was not coming out of his pocket but out of the Budget surplus. Yet the shadow Treasurer makes this inane comment about award restructuring and shoving it down the throats of employers. He should listen to the Metal Trades Industry Association or the other people running large companies in the real world of Australian industry and commerce and see what they have to say. He should see what ordinary wage and salary earners and pensioners, the people who have restrained their incomes over these years and whom we now want to assist and support, have to say. They do not speak of that package in his derisory terms. The reason why the package can be delivered is that it is coming from the Government's hard-won Budget surplus: by cutting public sector expenditure over six years; by sitting in the Cabinet room for three or four months at a time, 10 or 11 hours a day, cutting back the profligacy that we inherited from the previous Government. It is only by reducing those outlays to 24 per cent of gross domestic product that we can afford to have tax cuts funding a smaller public sector. That is where the tax cuts are paid from.

The shadow finance spokesman, the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson), who insists on making a mug of himself, got up after Question Time to make a personal explanation, claiming that tax cuts paid from a Budget surplus are unfunded. He really believes that these tax cuts should have been matched last night with their equivalent value in spending cuts.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which he won't nominate.

—Which he will not nominate. That is the position of the Opposition. The shadow Treasurer believes that we should have a tri-fiscal policy, but he will not say so, and the shadow finance spokesman believes that there should be no tax cuts which are not offset-and not just from the surplus. In other words, he believes that we should retain not just the Budget surplus but another $5.5 billion by cutting public expenditure. A couple of weeks ago on the Face to Face program he told us that he would hop into the Department of Social Security and the Department of Veterans' Affairs and rip them apart. That was after he said that he would not serve in the lowly position of Minister for Veterans' Affairs. That was below his station in life.

SPEECH.PARA: Yesterday he said on the AM program, `We are very concerned about tax cuts that are not substantially funded by cuts in government expenditure'. What he means by that is that there should be more cuts on top of those which this Government has introduced-a further cut of $5 billion to finance tax cuts of $5 billion. In other words, he wants a surplus of $11 billion and he wants the tax cuts to be funded by another round of $5 billion. He reinforced that view by saying after Question Time today that he believed that the tax cuts ought to be funded by further cuts in Government expenditure. He said on the Face to Face program that a Liberal government would make no draconian cuts-only $5 billion worth, and that is on top of the $20 billion worth of cuts under this Government. But where will they come from? He is silent. He does not know. He will not say.

There are two really compelling charts on page 23 of yesterday's Government statement. One shows overtime relative to wages growth and the other shows capacity utilisation. Let me just explain the import of these charts. The first chart, which runs from 1966 to 1987, shows that, in 1972-73, when overtime rose, wages followed very quickly and there was a wages explosion. In 1981-82, under the former Government, when overtime rose, although the rise was nothing like that of 1974, a wages explosion still followed very quickly. The table for this period shows overtime at a record level, way beyond any other in the charts, but with wages holding at 5 or 6 per cent. It is the most amazing illustration of the performance of wages in the economy compared with the performance in two other periods, the last period when the former Government was in office.

The capacity utilisation chart shows when the system is straining with full capacity, high capacity utilisation rates. It shows that, in 1972-73, the moment that capacity utilisation peaked a similar shadow peak, the boom in wages, followed. The same thing occurred in 1981-82 but the increase was nowhere near as large. The previous Government got a wages explosion out of a fairly modest lift in capacity utilisation. But, under Labor, there has been a massive lift in capacity utilisation and wages are still running at 5 or 6 per cent. That speaks volumes about this Government, its accord, the trade unions and our running of the Australian economy. Anyone in business or in finance who had any doubts about this period who looked at those two charts would say, `How could we return to that?'.

This debate is about tax cuts being used from a hard-won Budget surplus to maintain moderate wage outcomes, to keep inflation down, to keep the country competitive and to maintain investment with employment-in other words, to keep economic growth going without the disruption of a recession. That is what our policy is about. It is not designed to buy votes, with an election in mind; it is designed to go straight to the main chance-to keep economic growth going and complete the structural transformation in Australia.

We have heard nothing but jeers from the Opposition. There is no recognition of the fact that with these changes we will usher in the greatest change to the award structure of Australian trade unionism and pay scales ever and introduce into the wages system a totally non-confrontationary model whereby a worker, rather than having a fight with his enterprise employer about his wage rate, can actually get a larger wage increase by training himself or herself to become multiskilled and do a more interesting job. If the worker finds that that does not bring him enough money he can go to another level of multi- skilling and receive more money by being more productive in that enterprise.

That is one of the largest micro-economic reforms that the Government has presided over as part of these changes, as part of the agreement with the Australian Council of Trade Unions as to the new wage system that will be established and presided over by the Industrial Relations Commission. That is what is at stake here, but we would never know it from listening to the speech of the honourable member for Kooyong. It was like a speech that we could have expected in the Sydney Tivoli in the early 1950s-a bit of soft shoe shuffle at the footlights; a bit of vaudeville; a bit of fun and games; a few empty phrases thrown around; a couple of old jokes; a few horse jokes from Flemington. That passes as economic debate.

We know, because he has told us, that the fellow who answers the hard, technical argument is the honourable member for Wentworth. He has told us that the shadow Treasurer does the pappy stuff but that he does the hard technical stuff. He is the hard man, but he does not seem to understand the difference between one surplus and the next being the same and not changing the stimulation of the economy from public policy. He wants us to believe that he has all this technical ability but he does not understand a basic economic fact. For example, he did not understand the other day his remark about unfunded tax cuts.

That is how the two honourable members opposite behave. They think that Australian companies, the employers-the serious people who run the companies, employ people, run a business, carry all the costs, pay the wages at the end of the week, find business in a competitive market, are competitive, price their products properly and keep the game going-are going to give the jokers on the Opposition side a go, so they can wreck their businesses like they did in 1980-81. The interesting thing is that the whole group is back-the former Treasurer as Leader of the Opposition and his principal economic adviser, the honourable member for Wentworth. He is back on the job, so he can wreck the economy twice. No-one would believe that a political party, having dredged up such a duo once, could do it a second time, but here they are back again.

No comment has been made about the fact that low and middle income earners will have their tax burden relieved and that there has been a real change for those people, nor was there any comment about the fact that we have taken pensioners with income in the free area right outside the tax system. There was no comment about the fact that a taxpayer on about $20,000 with two children has a net tax of zero, or that a taxpayer on $24,000 with three children will also have a net tax of zero. The Opposition could not care less. I ask whether the Opposition, on race day at Flemington Park, cares whether a family on $20,000 with two children has a net tax rate of zero. When His Nibs, the honourable member for Wentworth, drives around Vaucluse in his Ferrari does he care whether someone on $20,000 a year with two kids and living in Blacktown or Bankstown has a net tax rate of zero? He could not care less. He sheds crocodile tears about the public and how it has been duped.

The public is a lot smarter than the jokers on the Opposition side of the House think it is. The public understands where value is, and where employment is. This Government has seen a 20 per cent growth in the employment rate in six years compared with the 4 per cent in six years achieved by the Opposition. There were all those kids leaving school with no jobs to go to. There was a massive growth in unemployment. There was a high work force growth and no employment. The Opposition achieved a 4 per cent growth in employment in six years and we have achieved five times as much. Yet the Opposition still has the hide to say that it is better when it does not even have the fundamental policy in place-wages. How can the Opposition ask to be taken seriously? At the end of a couple of days of hard debate and exposition of our policy and the changes, I found it was a good opportunity to expatiate upon them and, more than that, to be entertained by the shadow Treasurer and his equally entertaining colleague the honourable member for Wentworth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hewson Dr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have just seen a classic Keating performance-with the Treasurer playing the man rather than the issue. In the space of 15 minutes this turkey, the Treasurer, attacked my colleague the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock), the editor of the Australian, Paddy McGuinness, and Ross Gittins and he spent a fair bit of time attacking me. Now, of course, he is about to leave rather than stick around for the debate. He has absolutely no interest in serious economic debate.

SPEECH.PARA: I pick up a couple of points the Treasurer made. For example, when he attacked Paddy McGuinness he said, `There is nothing like the wrath of a jilted guru'. What we have seen today is the wrath of a jilted world's greatest Treasurer. This turkey has no understanding of economic debate. He has no capacity to participate in debates on matters of substance, and he just takes cheap shots at anybody who dares to disagree with him. Of Ross Gittins, of whom he has spoken highly in the past as an individual and a journalist, he says `He does not have the personal courage to write what he believes'. The Treasurer does not have the personal courage to tell us what he believes; he does not have the personal courage to inform us of the advice that he has received from his Department or, more importantly, the Reserve Bank about the current state of the economy. He does not have the personal courage to come clean.

All we got last night was 17 pages of an election speech. We did not get any economic analysis. Of the 17 pages a little more than one page was devoted to the economy, in a situation where there is no doubt that the Government's entire economic strategy is in tatters. The Treasurer, in the run-up to the election, is trying to hold things together and get himself re-elected, rather than face up to any of the economic issues.

I remind the House of the situation which existed a few months ago at the time that the Budget was delivered. The Treasurer painted a very optimistic picture of the Australian economy. At that time he talked of how he would control inflation, how the balance of payments would improve, and how he would get a wage-tax trade-off from the union movement. He talked in terms of a zero increase in average weekly earnings as a trade-off for a tax cut to be made in July this year. Since then everything has gone wrong with that strategy. All the forecasts are in total disarray. For example, a key Budget forecast was for a current account deficit of $9.5 billion. It now looks like being $15 billion. That forecast got one sentence in last night's statement. The inflation rate which the Treasurer predicted would fall to 4 1/2 per cent by the middle of this year and 3 to 4 per cent by the middle of 1990 also got only one sentence in last night's statement.

The whole document presented last night was devoted to the fact that the Treasurer has been decisively rolled by the Australian Council of Trade Unions and that he has been forced by them to eat crow on wages and economic management. It is quite clear that the Treasurer has come here as a puppet. There is no more substance to this man than the strings which are being pulled by Bill Kelty and, perhaps, the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) in the preparation of a document like we saw last night.

There is no doubt that the Treasurer, who wanted a zero increase in average weekly earnings a few months ago when his Budget strategy was laid down, has now settled for a substantial wage increase, quite unrelated to productivity, in circumstances in which his Budget is in tatters. The Treasurer is a joke. He says that some people in this place do not know anything about economics. I have never seen him demonstrate any understanding of economics. He constantly demonstrates that he is a total captive of his politicised department and a few of his private office advisers, yet some people who have left his staff now spend all their time pointing out to him just how misguided he is.

For example, Professor Barry Hughes, who left the Treasurer some time ago, warned him at the time of the last Budget that his forecasts for wages, prices and the balance of payments would not be achieved. Just the other day Barry Hughes again criticised the Treasurer; he pointed out that the Treasurer is in a balance of payments stranglehold. One the Face to Face program last week he pointed out that the Treasurer had embarked on `a very high risk strategy'. The wage-tax situation presents a very high risk strategy. Barry Hughes said that we will have to spend most of 1989 hoping that `something nasty' does not pop up. That is the situation in which the Treasurer finds himself. He is disowned by the thinking media in this country and his past economic advisers and he is a total captive of his present over-politicised Department.

The tragedy is that today when we are discussing a very important matter of public importance about what will happen to interest rates and inflation under this Government the Treasurer does not have the grace to lower himself and discuss the basic issues which are of importance to the average Australian. Why is that? It is because the Treasurer's track record in all these areas is absolutely pathetic. He has had a pathetic track record during his time as Treasurer in predicting and controlling the rate of inflation.

When one considers the Budget forecasts the Treasurer has made during the last six years, one sees that he has bettered his inflation forecast only once, and that was in the first year. Ever since then he has got it wrong. Not surprisingly, the Treasurer is not prepared to talk about inflation in this place. Of course, he also has a longstanding, well-established record of playing politics with interest rates and spending all of his time manipulating interest rates for short term political ends. He has no genuine interest in getting interest rates down. He does not care. He has no personal interest in getting interest rates down for the average Australian. He does not care that so far in this financial year the average person is paying $40 more a week-about $2,000 a year-as a result of the increases in home loan interest costs. He has a house in my electorate, which is sitting there unoccupied and allowing him to speculate on the capital gains. He is one of my constituents. I imagine he votes for me! He sits here in Canberra cheating on his expenses rather than dealing with the issues of this fundamentally difficult set of economic circumstances that are before us at this time. Look at his record on interest rates--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. My point of order is that for the honourable member for Wentworth to use terminology in respect of the Treasurer that he did he would need to move a substantive motion. He should be asked to withdraw it. The Treasurer is not cheating on anything in relation to his allowances in this place.
—I think that particular matter has been canvassed quite considerably in the past. I am sure the Treasurer would be offended by the remarks. I ask the honourable member to withdraw them.
—I thought he admitted it in his explanation.
—I ask the honourable member to withdraw.

—I am happy to withdraw. The key point is that the Treasurer is not the slightest bit interested in serious economic debate about these issues. He is prepared, however, to play politics with interest rates, to push them down and to mislead the electorate as he has in the lead-up to every major political contest in recent years, only then to put them up subsequently. Indeed, for most of last year, for example, he was not prepared to admit that he was putting them up. He was not tightening; he kept denying that he was tightening while he was busily instructing the Reserve Bank of Australia to do differently.

SPEECH.PARA: In the lead-up to each recent election-the July 1987 election, the New South Wales election, the Victorian State election last year and the Oxley by-election-there is evidence that interest rates were manipulated by this Government. They were restrained in an upward direction recently, and pushed down in the first two cases in order to create a favourable impression in the eyes of the electorate. The fact is that as a consequence of that sort of political manipulation he set this economy on a roller-coaster. He has had periods of boom followed by periods of bust. He is now coming out of a period of boom, and has been since the end of 1986 and the pick-up in the terms of trade, and the economy is now dead-set in the direction of an economic bust. Interest rates will probably be put higher by this Government, they will ultimately bite and they will ultimately send this country crashing down. The thing he fears most, a pick-up in unemployment, is indeed a very real possibility in the course of this year. The Australian community can look forward to higher interest rates, higher inflation, more bracket creep and job insecurity. All of them in one way or another, will claw back the temporary benefits of last night's mini-Budget, which at best can be described as a cruel hoax.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Griffiths Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson) in his opening remarks made his contribution to our balance of payments situation very clear when he said, `My Ferrari is fine'. As he travels around his electorate in his car worth many hundreds of thousands of dollars, I hope that his constituents reflect on his personal commitment to basic things such as making a choice where possible that ensures that Australian technology and Australian workers gain the benefit. `My Ferrari is fine' evokes the feeling of just how out of touch some people are.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member went on to criticise the Treasurer (Mr Keating) for allegedly attacking the man. During Question Time he sat next to the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey), who in his usual way made one of the most vile and personalised interjections ever made in this chamber. But did he distance himself from that attack on the man? Of course he did not. He did not distance himself and he has the opportunity of doing so.

He is also the individual who has gained a reputation bar none for attacking the individual integrity of public servants, no matter what their commitment or their length of service. As bipartisan independent public servants, they will be reasonable targets for the invective of the honourable member for Wentworth. The other slur, the other nasty little bit of personal invective and attack, is to imply that the Treasurer is getting a capital gain from his only place of residence. Everyone in this chamber knows that there is no such thing as a capital gain on a principal or sole place of residence but, once again, attacking the man is not too much for the honourable member for Wentworth.

Let us go to some of the more important matters that we should be addressing today. In both contributions, that of the honourable member for Wentworth and that of the Deputy Leader of the Liberal Party of Australia and honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), there was no substantive discussion of the economic issues that from their own mouths are to be regarded as the important areas for debate. The honourable member for Kooyong spent most of his contribution commenting on today's editorials or newspaper coverage. He referred to the accord. One particular editorial alleged that the whole thrust of last night's statement was to ensure the survival of the accord. Of course it is. What is that about? It is about a coherent wages policy.

If we look back over the last few years in Australian economic history, we will understand that the governments that will retain control of the economy are those governments with a viable wages policy. What happened in 1974? There was wage pressure, a wage break-out, inflation, recession and job loss. They all happened, and it is a matter of record. In 1981-82 again there was no wages policy. What was the outcome? When pressure built up, reflected first in overtime rates, there was a massive wages break-out and everyone in this chamber knows the result of that: high inflation, recession and massive and unprecedented job loss in this country.

In the last year of the previous Government hundreds of thousands of people were thrown out of work. When we talk about families, we ought to be talking about what a job means. In a society such as ours a job means a decent environment and dignity. It is not something that is necessarily important to someone travelling around his electorate in an imported Ferrari. A job means dignity; it means waking up in the morning and knowing that one's kids can get a decent feed and go to school with decent clothing, and that one's environment is conducive to one's self-respect.

We have a world record in terms of job creation. When we talk about the 1.3 million jobs that we have created, to the other side of the House that is something to be criticised. On this side of the House we are proud of the fact that all those factors that I have just mentioned are relevant for those 1.3 million people and that they have the dignity and security of employment. That is something that everyone on this side of the House should continue to be proud of.

Let me refer to the numeracy skills of the Opposition. The honourable member for Kooyong stands up and says that he has heard of the quadrella. He went one better and referred to the Keating trifecta. Even with the repartee in this chamber he cannot get his numeracy skills in order.

Let me go back to the wages policy. There is no wages policy on the Opposition side of the chamber. Every Australian and the people in the galleries here today should take the opportunity of listening to the replies of members of the Opposition to last night's statement by the Treasurer because I can guarantee one thing: if precedent and the last six years of my time in this chamber are going to be any guide, they will be verbiage. There will not be a single positive, sensible recommendation about how members of the Opposition would contain a wages explosion. We have all their public statements on record. For example, in February last year the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) indicated that by August of last year members of the Opposition would have their policies put together. It is no good my going through the record. John Elliott is on the record. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition is on the record on a number of occasions. The Leader of the Opposition is on the record, again as recently as May, as is the honourable member for Wentworth. They are all on the record indicating that their policies are about to arrive. We really would not want to be hanging by our fingernails waiting for those policies to arrive. The Opposition lacks a wages policy. It has produced a document entitled Future Directions but it looks to the past. We should look back for our own analogies. An analogy that comes to my mind most sharply about the Opposition's wages policy or lack thereof is Henry Lawson's The Loaded Dog. We can all recall the image of that great slobbering dog running around with a stick of dynamite in its mouth and the fuse burning down. That is what the Opposition's wages policy represents, because that is precisely the impact it would have. If we had no wages policy in our contemporary economic environment we would have this stupid dog running around, wagging its tail exuberantly, with a stick of dynamite with the fuse burning down. As sure as God made little green apples, the end result of the implementation of the Opposition's non-existent wages policy would be a repeat of what we have seen before. We saw it in 1974. We saw it in 1982. The end result would not be some theoretical outcome. The end result would be massive job losses and the commensurate misery that would represent for Australia.

Last night's economic statement was really all about politics as the ideas market. It was not only about-although this was important-massive support for ordinary Australian families and pensioners. It was much more fundamental than that. In terms of wages policy it was about a structure and, as the Treasurer indicated, order. In terms of a wages policy it was about award restructuring, in my view, the single most important micro-economic reform that this country has ever grappled with. In terms of the workplace it was about efficiency, competitiveness, productivity and workplace involvement and the quality of workplace involvement for ordinary Australian workers. It was about multiskilling. As I have said, it was a rational framework for wages policy.

I would like to have said a number of other things. Let me conclude on this note: in 1974 I was working as a rigger on a construction site. When we talked about what we could do on the wages front we knew that we had one choice, and one choice only. We jumped on that treadmill and we went as hard as we could because we knew that there was no alternative. If we missed out, then we missed out forever. The difference now is that workers in this country know that there is a tax trade-off, that they are guaranteed to get a decent increment to their standard of living, and that a whole raft of other policy areas has been attended to by this Government. It takes the chance out; it puts in certainty. Where there would be chaos under the Opposition, we offer order.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The debate is concluded.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Mr H.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the thirteenth report of the Publications Committee, sitting in conference with the Publications Committee of the Senate. Copies of the report are being circulated to honourable members in the chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: Report-by leave-adopted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hollis Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works, I present the seventh, eighth and ninth reports of the Committee for 1989, relating to the redevelopment of Royal Australian Army logistics and training complex, Stage 1, Bandiana, Victoria, the upgrading of Royal Australian Navy living-in accommodation at HMAS Cerberus, Crib Point, Victoria, and the development of Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF) Base, Wagga Wagga, New South Wales.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the reports be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The reports which I have just tabled bring the number of reports tabled this year to nine and bring to $222.15m the expenditure recommended by the Committee to date in 1989. The report relating to the Army's Logistics and Training Complex at Bandiana, Victoria, represents the first stage of a major redevelopment of this complex at an estimated cost of $68m at August 1988 prices. Phase A of stage 1 will commence in mid-1989 while phase B will commence in 1992-93 with completion of both phases scheduled for mid-1995.

SPEECH.PARA: In recommending the redevelopment to the Parliament, the Committee has drawn attention to two matters which it believes require further examination by the Department of Defence and Australian Construction Services. These are: the need for Defence to examine and review security arrangements at the Bandiana complex; and the need for Defence and Australian Construction Services to re-examine the location of the distribution centre, as the Committee is concerned that it is proposed to be built over an existing water channel.

The Committee's report relating to the upgrade of living-in accommodation at HMAS Cerberus, Crib Point, Victoria, at an estimated cost of $15.7m at September 1988 prices is the second report the Committee has tabled this year relating to the Navy's main training establishment. The Committee's second report of 1989 related to the construction of new communications and recruit schools. The objective of this proposal is to upgrade accommodation buildings at HMAS Cerberus to provide a standard of living-in accommodation which is as close to current service scales and standards as the existing building envelopes and layouts permit. The conversion of existing four-bed rooms to two single cabins will create a shortage of junior sailor accommodation which will be overcome by the construction of an additional junior sailor accommodation block.

The final report I have tabled relates to the development of RAAF Base, Wagga, New South Wales, at an estimated cost of $23.6m at April 1988 prices. RAAF Base, Wagga, is the RAAF's main base for technical training and the proposal reported on by the Committee allows for the construction of a number of new buildings, the refurbishment of a number of existing buildings and the upgrading of engineering services. In recommending the construction of the work in this reference the Committee has commented on a number of issues which require examination by Defence and Australian Construction Services.

The Committee believes that Defence should commence negotiations with the State Rail Authority with the aim of resuming the rail easement through the Base. The Committee is concerned regarding the location of the proposed fire station and the apparent lack of an adequate fire and emergency service to the airfield and has recommended that this matter be further examined. The Committee has also drawn attention to the fact that the flammable goods bulk store appears to be located too close to accommodation blocks and has recommended that either it be relocated or that appropriate mounding and landscaping be provided. I commend the reports to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fischer Mr T.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Mr Deputy Speaker, I do not wish to take too much time because I know that my colleagues also wish to speak on these public works projects. Commendably, they decentralise certain aspects of defence in this country. I was with the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works when it visited the Albury-Wodonga military area for the detailed hearings in relation to that area. I point out that the Committee had some foresight because the drainage system which the Committee was concerned about has been under intense pressure in the last four weeks because of the bizarre seasonal conditions which apply across much of south-east Australia. They will possibly lead to a green drought. Farmers this year may not even have the opportunity to sow their wheat crops, let alone harvest them.

SPEECH.PARA: I commend that aspect of the Committee's report relating to the complex at Bandiana and point out that that, combined with the decentralisation of the Mulwala explosives factory which the Committee reported on last year, will lead to a big boost in the border region, with an economic impact on both sides of the border. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT COMMITTEE ON FOREIGN AFFAIRS, DEFENCE AND TRADE

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker has received a message from the Senate about a reference to the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade relating to the operations of the National Safety Council of Australia, Victorian Division.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Willis, for Mrs Kelly, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The Australian Telecommunications Corporation Bill 1989 is the second and final stage of legislative changes to implement the Government's reform package for Telecom Australia, announced in the ministerial statement of 25 May 1988, `Reshaping the Transport and Communications Government Business Enterprises'. The first stage was implemented by the Telecommunications Amendment Act 1988.

A central plank in the Government's micro-economic reform agenda for restructuring the public sector is that government business enterprises-GBEs-should be as efficient as possible and responsive to consumers' needs. The GBEs within the Transport and Communications portfolio, in addition to producing final goods and services for consumers, also produce intermediate inputs for the rest of the economy, with a resulting impact on Australia's overall cost structures and the ability of Australian businesses to compete internationally. Telecommunications is an increasingly important input factor in the production of other goods and services by Australian business for supply to domestic and international markets.

The Government sees the commercialisation of GBEs as a necessary and fundamental pre-condition to improvements in efficiency. GBEs such as Telecom are being placed on a more commercial footing, bringing them more into line with private sector competitors, and subjecting them increasingly to the disciplines of the marketplace. Implementation of the Telecom reform package, together with real reductions in the average price of a basket of basic telecommunications services through the price control formula CPI-X, will bring about increased efficiencies and economies in the provision of telecommunications services by the public sector. As announced in the 25 May 1988 statement, the reform package strategy for Telecom has as its key elements the implementation of a new corporate and financial structure, establishment of new planning and accountability mechanisms, modification of major strategic controls and removal of day to day ministerial controls.

The Telecommunications Amendment Act 1988 was principally concerned with putting in place the new corporate structure and removing ministerial controls. In particular, from 1 January 1989 the Australian Telecommunications Commission-Telecom-was renamed the Australian Telecommunications Corporation. Telecom became a statutory corporation, with a separate Board of Directors, instead of commissioners who were members of the Commission. This structural change did not change Telecom's legal identity or status, but the separation of the enterprise and the Board assisted in a clearer definition of the roles of the Government as owner, the Board accountable for performance and Telecom management responsible for operations.

In line with the philosophy of moving from oversight of the proceeds to an emphasis on results, the Telecommunications Amendment Act 1988 also removed a range of controls over day to day activities such as approval of individual contract and borrowing proposals. These are now appropriately the responsibility of the Board. This Australian Telecommunications Corporation Bill 1989 replaces the Telecommunications Act 1975, under which Telecom is established, with a new Act, planned to operate from 1 July 1989. The provisions in the Telecommunications Act dealing with regulatory issues are now contained in the Telecommunications Bill 1989, which establishes the new regulatory body Austel.

The Australian Telecommunications Corporation will continue in operation, again with no change of legal identity or legal status. The provisions in the Bill relating to appointment of directors and meetings of the Board, appointment of the Managing Director, and employment conditions for Telecom staff repeat, without significant changes, the new provisions inserted by the Telecommunications Amendment Act 1988. Telecom's functions and powers have been redefined. The Bill emphasises Telecom's principal role as a provider of domestic telecommunications services, but it has subsidiary functions allowing it to engage in other business or activities related to telecommunications within and outside Australia, related to telecommunications, and incidental functions allowing it to conduct other business in the course of fulfilling its principal role. The Bill provides Telecom with all the powers necessary to carry out its functions. The Bill places commercial, community service and general obligations on Telecom, to perform its functions in a manner consistent with sound commercial practice. It is an integral feature of the reform packages for GBEs that commercial performance is the primary responsibility of the enterprises. However, this does not detract from Telecom's social responsibility to provide universal service, that is, to deliver its community service obligations (CSOs).

Telecom's statutory CSO is the supply of a standard telephone service as efficiently and economically as practicable. This service must be reasonably accessible to all people and on an equitable basis wherever they reside or carry out business within Australia. Also there is a requirement that service performance standards reasonably meet the social, industrial and commercial needs of the Australian community. The importance of meeting CSOs is evident in the corporate planning process I describe later. Telecom's plan for, and delivery of, CSOs are part of the accountability measures of the Board. The costs involved will be separately identified and will be taken into account in fixing the financial target Telecom is expected to meet. Austel has the function of monitoring and reporting on Telecom's delivery of its CSOs. Telecom is also required to comply with directions by the Minister and, where these are notified in writing, government policies.

The Bill provides for the remaining key elements of the reform strategy, which are the implementation of a new capital and financial structure and the establishment of new planning and accountability mechanisms. The Bill also provides for Telecom's initial capital to be determined by the Minister for Transport and Communications as soon as possible after commencement, which will involve conversion of some part of existing Commonwealth loans to capital. Telecom's assets will be revalued before 1 July 1989. Following this, the Government will determine an appropriate debt-to-equity ratio for Telecom on a basis comparable to leading telecommunications companies in other parts of the world. Telecom's assets will be revalued at least once every five years in accordance with normal commercial practice. The Bill gives Telecom a commercially-oriented financial structure with the usual commercial obligations to pay taxes and charges and appropriate dividends on owner's equity. The removal of day to day controls means Telecom is no longer subject to routine oversight by Government of the way it carries on business. This Bill provides for more structured oversight by the government, as owner, of the objectives and strategies proposed by Telecom and for the Government to indicate the financial target it expects Telecom to achieve.

The Board of Telecom will be required to prepare and revise a corporate plan for a period of between three and five years, the first plan commencing on 1 July 1989. The corporate plan will set out the objectives of Telecom and its subsidiaries and outline the overall strategies and policies it must follow to achieve those objectives, including meeting its CSOs. Financial matters to be included in the corporate plan include an overall financial target to be agreed with the Minister, overall pricing, investment and borrowing strategies and estimates of the costs of carrying out CSOs and general governmental obligations. The Board is to provide the Minister with a copy of the corporate plan. The Minister can direct the Board, within 30 days, to vary the financial target and/or the strategies and policies to meet its CSOs or both.

The Bill also provides for other accountability requirements, including timely presentation of annual reports and financial statements audited by the Auditor-General; disclosure of the objectives, strategies, policies, operations and performance of Telecom and its subsidiaries, and details relating to CSOs. The Board will also be required to give the Minister prior notification of significant business activities in which Telecom and its subsidiaries propose to engage or in which they cease to participate. Telecom will be subject to taxation under State and Territory laws from 1 July 1989. Transitional provisions are set out in the accompanying Telecommunications and Postal Services (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Bill. Telecom's current exemption from other State and Territory laws will continue until a sunset provision in the Bill comes into force on 30 December 1990. This can be extended by regulation generally, or for particular laws or classes of laws.

With the enactment of this Bill the Government will have substantially completed the implementation of the key elements of the Telecom reform package. Some other aspects of reforms have been completed. These include revised industrial relations monitoring arrangements. Controls relating to Telecom's borrowings, executive remuneration and superannuation are under progressive review. The Government has put in place the key elements of its reform strategy for Telecom including planning and accountability mechanisms. These, in conjunction with the measures reflected in the Telecommunications Bill 1989, will significantly change the Australian telecommunications industry.
I commend this Bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum.
Debate (on motion by Mr Braithwaite) adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

The Australian Postal Corporation Bill is the second and final stage of legislative changes to implement the Government's reform package for Australia Post, announced in the ministerial statement of 25 May 1988 titled `Reshaping the Transport and Communications Government Business Enterprises'. The first stage was implemented by the Australian Postal Services Amendment Act 1988.

The Bill also provides other accountability requirements including timely presentation of annual reports and financial statements audited by the Auditor-General, disclosure of the objectives, strategies, policies, operations and performance of Australia Post and its subsidiaries, and details relating to CSOs.
