DEBATE.TITLE: TELECOMMUNICATIONS AND POSTAL SERVICES (TRANSITIONAL PROVISIONS AND CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Willis, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill is related to the Telecommunications Bill 1989, the Australian Telecommunications Corporation Bill 1989 and the Australian Postal Corporation Bill 1989. It repeals the Telecommunications Act 1975 and the Postal Services Act 1975, which are replaced by the new legislation and makes consequential amendments to other Acts. It also includes transitional provisions for the imposition of income tax and State and Territory taxes and charges, and for other purposes.

The Bill inserts new parts in the Crimes Act 1914 covering postal and telecommunications offences, covering the same ground as in the existing legislation. However, the opportunity has been taken to revise the offences, taking into account developments since 1975 and treating Australia Post and the three carriers-Telecom Australia, Overseas Telecommunications Commission Australia (OTC) and Aussat Pty Ltd-consistently.

In some cases the existing Telecom and Australia Post offences are adequately covered by general Crimes Act provisions and have not been repeated. The consistent treatment of the three carriers is desirable because of the national importance of the telecommunications network and services and an exception has been made to the general classification of Commonwealth bodies for the Crimes Act. OTC and Aussat will be deemed to be public authorities for all purposes under the Crimes Act, and their employees, including people who perform services for and on behalf of Aussat and OTC and their employees, will be treated in the same way as Commonwealth officers. This inclusion of OTC and Aussat within the Crimes Act umbrella is a temporary measure only and is subject to the Government's decision about which, if any, of its business enterprises should be so protected.

At present, Telecom and Post security personnel investigate offences under their Acts in cooperation with the Australian Federal Police, under guidelines about the break-up of responsibilities. This situation will continue. However, we have made one important change. Under the existing legislation, Telecom and Australia Post employees and any other person are given a power of arrest without warrant for certain property offences. There will be no such powers conferred under the new legislation.

The Bill repeals redundant provisions in the OTC and Satellite Communications Acts to be covered in the new Telecommunications Act and makes minor consequential amendments to bring the language into line with the language in the Telecom and Australia Post Acts.

Australia Post and Telecom will be subjected to State taxes and charges from commencement, planned for 1 July 1989. The Bill provides that the enterprises will not be subject to stamp duty or similar duties on property acquired, transactions entered into or securities issued, before the commencing day. The transitional taxation provisions in the Bill complement the details of the imposition of income tax on Australia Post and Telecom from the 1990-91 year of income and provide for arrangements to apply in respect of valuation of trading stock, capital gains tax and depreciation.

Austel, established by the new Telecommunications Act, will investigate complaints about failure to provide telecommunications services, connect customer equipment or perform cabling work. The Bill amends the Ombudsman Act 1976 to give the Ombudsman a discretion not to investigate such complaints where Austel would deal with them more effectively, and for the transfer of the complaints.

In deciding whether or not to issue licences under the Radiocommunications Act 1983 and when imposing conditions on such licences, the Minister for Transport and Communications will now be able to take into account the policy for the regulation of telecommunications networks stated in division 1 of part 3 of the new Telecommunications Act.

Part 9 of the Bill contains a number of consequential amendments to the Telecommunications (Interception) Act 1979. That Act currently affords protection from interception to communications passing over telecommunications systems provided by or with the authority of Telecom. The Act also provides for the interception of such communications in the limited circumstances specified in the Act, such as under a warrant or in connection with the operation or maintenance of the telecommunications system. However, with the enactment of the Telecommunications Act 1989, both OTC and Aussat will also be able to supply certain domestic telecommunications services. The amendments to the Telecommunications Interception Act take account of these changes to the telecommunications industry. They are designed to preserve the ambit of the Act's prohibition on interception of communications, the scope of the provisions allowing for interceptions, and the communication of information obtained thereby, in specified circumstances. I commend this Bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum.
Debate (on motion by Mr Braithwaite) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Kerin, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr KERIN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is to introduce new marketing arrangements for the wheat industry and thereby establish a sound future for one of Australia's most important export earners. In a speech to the annual conference of the Grains Council of Australia (GCA) last year, I invited the industry to take the opportunity of the need for a new wheat marketing Act and the report of the Royal Commission into Grain Storage, Handling and Transport to think seriously about the future structure of the wheat industry and its position in the Australian and world economy. It is a matter of some regret that the GCA has been unable to articulate a vision for the future of its industry and has adopted a position of non-negotiability on the major issues.

While the GCA has been arguing for the status quo it seems not to understand that this is an industry which has been undergoing continuous and, in some cases, quite major change. For instance: wheat growing is becoming part of a broader grains industry in which more growers are prepared to make changes in their cropping based on relative prices. The industry has recently weathered extremely unfavourable market conditions caused by heavy export subsidisation by the United States (US) and the European Community (EC).

Wheat purchasers are becoming more specific about the quality characteristics they seek. Australian Wheat Board (AWB) operations have changed significantly over the last decade. For instance, the Board is now a significant offshore borrower. More recently the AWB has provided growers with more flexible delivery options through the introduction of pool cash out arrangements, warehousing and a special stockfeed segregation.

The domestic market has already been partially deregulated with the introduction of permits for feed wheat and continued black market trading. Growers have been getting more experience of alternative methods of selling their grain. Even the GCA has recognised this through its recent establishment of the National Grain Exchange.

The industry has shown that it can respond to the pressures for change. It must continue to have this flexibility. The wheat market is currently very buoyant due to a combination of crop shortages and a rundown in United States stocks. However, the mechanisms which encourage overproduction in some countries remain in place. We are seeking through the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade Uruguay Round to have these measures wound back, and I am very pleased that during recent negotiations in Geneva progress was achieved in setting out a long and short term framework for liberalising agricultural trade. However, much remains to be done and, as I have said before, Australia cannot compete with the treasuries of the US and EC. We can only respond to difficulties on the world market by ensuring that we not only grow but also handle and market our grain as efficiently as possible. This objective cannot be achieved while unnecessary regulation and controls limit the AWB's effectiveness and impose extra costs on growers and users of wheat.

The Bill contains provisions to retain the AWB's export monopoly, but to open up more choice for growers by deregulating the domestic wheat market. In place of the compulsion contained in the current marketing arrangements, the Government is introducing a range of measures to extend the AWB's commercial powers and flexibility to ensure that it will be able to compete effectively in a deregulated market. The Bill also gives effect to the Government's concern to minimise its own control over the AWB's operations and to extend the Board's accountability to growers. The AWB will not be weakened, as has been claimed, but will be significantly strengthened. Specifically, and most importantly, the AWB will have clear powers to buy wheat for cash. This will enable it to remain a force in the domestic market, but will also ensure that it has the flexibility to access particular qualities of wheat for export if these are not made available through the pooling system.

Second, while the AWB's principal objective will remain the marketing of wheat, it will have the scope to market other grains and wheat grown in other countries where this assists its own wheat marketing effort. Third, the AWB will still be able to pool returns, but it will have flexibility in deciding how to conduct these operations. Under the current Wheat Marketing Act there is a single Australian standard white (ASW) pool with differentials established for other grades. This leads to inflexibility. Under the new legislation the AWB will be able to establish separate pools for separate grades or time periods. This, together with a wider range of payment options, will provide greater scope for responding to market movements.

I should also point out that the legislation does not make any specific requirements of the AWB regarding its pooling activities and the balance between these and any direct trading in wheat. This will be for the AWB and growers to decide in consultation. The AWB will also have powers to enable it to establish subsidiary companies and to engage in other commercial activities such as countertrade, processing, storage and handling. To assist these activities the legislation will also provide for an industry fund to provide the AWB with a much needed capital base. I will elaborate on arrangements for the fund later in this speech. To complete its marketing powers the AWB must be able to operate within States. The Government urges the State governments to ensure that the Board is not weakened by the lack of appropriate facilitating legislation.

A significant issue for Australian grain producers is the cost associated with the storage, handling and transport of their product. The Royal Commission identified that in 1987-88 these costs were equivalent to around 22 per cent of the f.o.b. price for wheat. It recommended a series of deregulatory moves which included the removal of sole receival rights for grain handling authorities, removal of restrictions on the transport of wheat in certain States and the disaggregation of charges for these services to enable growers to make informed decisions about least cost grain paths. The Royal Commission estimated that these changes could lead to potential resource cost savings of up to $10 per tonne.

The Commonwealth Government has endorsed the broad thrust of the Royal Commission's findings and last year amended the Wheat Marketing Act to provide the AWB with choice in contracting for grain distribution services and to disaggregate charges to growers. Much of the responsibility for putting the Royal Commission's recommendations into effect rests with the State governments. However, New South Wales is the only State to announce a positive response.

If the AWB and other grain trading corporations are to realise the savings estimated by the Royal Commission, they must have the scope to use least cost methods of handling and moving grain. The amendments to the 1984 Wheat Marketing Act, which I have already mentioned, were a step in this direction. However, some States have chosen to deny growers the opportunity of benefiting from the potential savings by continuing monopoly practices in their handling and transport sectors.

May I provide some examples. In Victoria, section 188 of the 1983 Transport Act restricts the mode of transport of certain goods. Bulk wheat, barley and oats are not to be carried by private road hauliers beyond a 60-kilometre radius of the place of consignment unless the vehicle owner has been granted a permit by the State Transport Authority. Under section 10 (2) of the Grain Elevators Act, the Grain Elevators Board has the exclusive rights to handle grain in the State. In Queensland, similar regulations effectively restrict to rail grain transport over distances greater than 120 kilometres. Section 26 of the Grains Handling Act provides Bulk Grains Queensland with exclusive rights to the storage and handling of export grains shipped from Queensland.

The AWB and other grain trading corporations must not be disadvantaged by this lack of action on the part of the States. The new Wheat Marketing Act provides clear powers for the AWB and other grain trading corporations and their service providers to enter into contracts for storage, handling, transport, port services and marketing of grain intended for interstate or export unencumbered by State regulations.

I turn now to the marketing provisions in this Bill. The Government recognises that world grain markets remain under the influence of distorting Government policies. I have decided, in response to widespread concerns expressed by the GCA and growers generally, that the AWB should remain the single export marketer for all Australian wheat. The AWB will continue to be able to use private traders as principals or agents as it does now and it will be able to authorise the direct export of wheat if the Board and growers judge it in their best interest. While it continues to have this export monopoly, the AWB will continue to be the receiver of last resort. This will, however, not prevent it from setting standards for the wheat it receives.

There is no justification for continuing the AWB's domestic marketing monopoly. Wheat is the only industry subject to Commonwealth regulation which has this control. In its 1988 May economic statement the Government announced that domestic support arrangements for agriculture should be progressively reduced in accordance with the general reductions in protection and assistance across the economy. The Bill provides for the domestic marketing of wheat to be freed up, and this will be achieved through the removal of compulsory acquisition and termination of the arrangements for an administered domestic price. The objective of this move is to give growers greater choice in how they sell their wheat and when. Growers will still have the option of delivering to the AWBs pools but, in addition, they will be able to sell their wheat for cash either to the AWB or to other buyers on the domestic market.

It is quite clear that many growers want this choice. Some 90 per cent of the wheat used for feed purposes is traded under the permit system. It is also a fact that wheat continues to be traded on the black market and, as indicated recently by the Flour Millers Council, that milling wheat is being sold through the feed wheat permit system. The essential point is that compulsory acquisition is no longer needed for an efficient marketing effort. I am confident that the AWB will remain the dominant force in a deregulated domestic market, given its expertise and the additional commercial powers which I outlined earlier.

An important benefit arising from freeing up the domestic market will be the greater scope growers will have to arrange their own storage, handling and transport. These additional competitive pressures will assist in achieving the potential resource cost savings in this sector identified by the Royal Commission. Users of wheat, particularly feedlotters, will also benefit from a freer domestic market and the removal of the costs and red tape involved in the current grower to buyer and permit systems.

In the recent debate on wheat marketing much has been made of the effect of domestic market deregulation on growers' returns. The argument has centred on concern that when prices are depressed by heavy subsidisation on overseas markets, this will be reflected in the domestic market price. This effect, however, depends on the level of subsidisation and also the size of the Australian crop. During the last season the smaller Australian crop and improved market opportunities meant that there was little need for the AWB to discount its prices, even though there was continued strong subsidisation by the US and EC. When market prices are rising rapidly, the domestic price arrangements can cost growers money. The inclusion of past prices in the formula can lead to the home consumption price being lower than the free market price.

The AWB through its export monopoly will still control some 80 per cent of the wheat produced. Average export prices as reflected in the expected net pool return will put a floor in the market. Contrary to claims by the GCA, no grower selling wheat outside the AWB system is likely to accept a farm gate price which is less than the price obtainable through the pool. Estimates show that over the last four years, if none of the wheat sold domestically had passed through the AWB pools, the loss to the pools would be in the range 23c per tonne to $2.93 per tonne overall. This is the worst that could happen and, in my view, is highly unlikely to happen. In a free market millers can be expected to continue to pay a premium to secure their special requirements for regular supplies and there will be scope for individual growers to achieve quality premiums within the ASW range, something that is not available to the AWB under the current administered domestic price. In addition, the potential savings through the use of more efficient storage, handling and transport facilities can be expected to more than outweigh any transient reduction in prices likely to result from subsidisation on export markets.

These new marketing arrangements will meet the needs of growers of specialty wheats, such as durum, and organically grown wheat. Currently these producers incur the AWB's pool costs even if they do not use its services. In future they will be able to sell their wheat freely on the domestic market and I would expect that the AWB will be able to accommodate the export needs of these producers either through its additional pooling flexibility or through the scope it has to authorise the direct export of wheat.

While the AWB will have extended commercial powers and a continued export monopoly it should not abuse its market power. The Trade Practices Act will apply to its commercial activities. In this regard it will be important for the Board to keep its trading and pooling activities at arm's length and for it to visibly and separately account for these activities. Concern has been expressed that domestic market deregulation will affect Australia's ability to maintain its current high standard of grain hygiene and that this will affect our export effort. I do not believe this will be the case. The AWB will be able to enforce existing hygiene standards through its contractual arrangements with those providing storage, handling and transport services. The legislation will make the Board's powers clear in this respect. Wheat which moves outside the AWB will be subject to market pressures if it does not meet hygiene standards acceptable to buyers. Some growers may choose to store more wheat on farm, but this is unlikely to be extensive particularly since the option of warehousing is now available.

A guaranteed minimum price (GMP) scheme has operated in the wheat industry for 10 years. This scheme has its drawbacks. Because of the averaging effect of the GMP formula the GMP, and therefore advance payments, is not necessarily a good indication of expected market returns. For instance, because of the recent strengthening of the wheat market, the final GMP set recently for the current season is only about 80 per cent of expected net pool returns. The GMP has tended to be used as a market indicator but is clearly a poor one. The GMP arrangements have also been the source of rigidities in the operation of the current wheat marketing arrangements, particularly with respect to the AWB's pooling operation.

In all years the principal benefit of the GMP scheme has been the backing it provides to enable the AWB to borrow at favourable interest rates and pay a relatively high first advance to growers delivering wheat to the AWB pools. The Government will continue to provide this benefit via a specific borrowing guarantee. Essentially this means that the AWB's borrowings will continue to be underwritten by government. Should there be a call on the guarantee the Government will meet its obligation and will not seek repayment by the industry. This is a significant commitment and is indicative of the Government's willingness to continue to back the wheat industry. In the initial year of the new arrangements this guarantee will be set at a level which will enable the payment of a first advance equivalent to 90 per cent of estimated net pool returns in the current season. I would point out that because of the current rising market prices, this will result in a higher first advance than would have been available under the GMP scheme.

In the 1988 May statement the Government announced that industry should progressively take over responsibility for funding the costs involved in reducing price uncertainty through underwriting schemes. Consistent with this intention the level of the borrowing guarantee will be phased down to 80 per cent of estimated net returns in year five of the new arrangements. The guarantee will be subject to review within five years. Should the industry wish to have a higher level of first advance than that available through the borrowing guarantee, provision has been made for it to introduce its own mechanism to make any additional payments.

Arrangements for setting the level of the guarantee will involve preliminary ministerial determination, in consultation with the Australian Wheat Board and the Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics, of the estimated net pool return for the season by 1 October. As under the current arrangements, a final guarantee and advance could be established later in the season. It will be up to the Australian Wheat Board in consultation with the Grains Council of Australia to determine the actual level of first advance for particular categories of wheat delivered to pools which will be based on the level of available borrowings. The level of the Government's financial commitment, however, will be limited on an aggregate basis to the level of the borrowing guarantee.

I am aware that the averaging arrangements in the previous GMP scheme provided support to growers in circumstances of extreme market downturn such as in 1986-87. If such a crisis were to occur again the Government would need to give close consideration to special support arrangements for the industry. I would also point out that the Government is also providing drought assistance and national interest insurance cover to the wheat industry.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr Hawker

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I take a point of order. I am reluctant to intervene in the Minister's second reading speech, but I draw his attention to page 89 of the notes attached to the Treasurer's April statement last night, where he said in part:

INTERJECT.PARA: The Government has decided to discontinue, with effect from 1 July 1989, reimbursement of expenditures by the six States--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! What is the point of order?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr Hawker

TALK.START.PARA: —The point of order is about drought relief. It has been discontinued. The statement goes on to say:

INTERJECT.PARA: In addition, the Commonwealth will not support expenditures on any relief measures for drought declarations made after 12 April 1989.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There is no point of order.
—I just want to draw it to the Minister's attention.
—There is no point of order.

—Let me just respond. The provision for drought assistance has effectively been transferred from the Minister for Finance to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy and the new arrangements will be announced.

SPEECH.PARA: The financing arrangements I have just described relate only to the Australian Wheat Board's pooling operation. However, as I have indicated, the Board will have a broader commercial role and there is a need to establish a capital base for it. It is a source of major weakness to the industry that the Australian Wheat Board has no asset base despite its role as one of the country's largest marketers; probably the second largest. The new wheat marketing legislation will provide the mechanism for the establishment of an industry fund through a levy on all wheat sold. The Government will also assist in the initial establishment of this fund through the provision over five years of a loan guarantee of up to $100m for the purposes of the fund. This will not be a stabilisation fund. It will provide finance for a range of activities which would include: the Australian Wheat Board's commercial undertakings, including cash purchases; making advance payments above the level provided through the AWB borrowing guarantee; and providing insurance on credit sales. It will be for the GCA in consultation with the AWB to determine the specific uses to which finance from the fund will be put.

The fund will be a powerful new avenue through which the industry will be able to influence its future. Detailed arrangements for the fund are still being considered by the GCA and the AWB and will be incorporated in regulations. I would emphasise, however, that the Government would want to see a commercial relationship between the fund and the AWB and proper equity arrangements established for growers. The fund will be activated only if industry agrees to the introduction of a levy for this purpose. Levy arrangements are the subject of separate Bills.

The AWB will be moving into a new phase of its operations and facing new challenges. It will be undertaking expanded commercial operations with a minimum of Government control but with Commonwealth Government borrowing guarantees. If the AWB is to perform effectively in this new environment it is essential that the best qualified people are appointed to the Board. It must be able to develop clear corporate strategies and purpose. The new Act will provide for Board members to have a balance of skills in the areas of production, marketing and finance. It will also be essential for the AWB to have a highly skilled management team. It must have a managing director as the chief executive who the Board should be able to pay at market rates, free from the Remuneration Tribunal constraints which operate at present. In principle I favour the appointment of a non-executive chairperson who in the long term would be part time. I recognise that the Board faces a challenging task in the transition to the new arrangements and that stability in its leadership structure is desirable. I have indicated to the GCA that the AWB will continue to have a grower chairperson.

I am aware of grower concern about `loss of control' of the AWB. Let me emphasise that the Board will continue to be accountable to growers. However, this responsibility will be exercised through the the Australian Wheat Board Selection Committee and consultative arrangements between the Australian Wheat Board and Grains Council of Australia rather than through participation in the day to day running of the Board.

The new Act will make clear provisions for the AWB to consult the GCA on the performance of its functions. In particular, I would expect the AWB to consult the GCA on such issues as the establishment of subsidiaries, pooling arrangements and general policy on trading in other grains and wheat of other origin. While the Act provides for a minimum of one consultative meeting each year, I would expect the AWB and GCA to consult more frequently than this. Given its continuing role as a statutory authority, the Australian Wheat Board will also continue to be accountable to the minister and the parliament. The Board's annual report, corporate plan and annual operating plan constitute important avenues of accountability both to the Government and the Grains Council of Australia.

The current arrangement under which the cost of shipping wheat to Tasmania is funded through a levy on domestic wheat sales will be terminated with the deregulation of the domestic market. The Government has, however, undertaken to continue funding this assistance from consolidated revenue. The exact amount of this assistance has still to be worked out, but in 1989-90 I expect it to be close to the average level of about $3m which has applied in recent years. The assistance will phase down by 25 per cent over the five-year period commencing in 1989-90 and the scheme will be subject to review within five years. There are no other direct financial implications arising from the legislation, although the Government is committed to assuming contingent liabilities under the proposed borrowing guarantees.

I believe that this new legislation will set the Australian wheat industry on a clear path for a prosperous future. It provides for a commercially strong Australian Wheat Board, free from unnecessary regulation and with clear lines of responsibility to growers. The marketing arrangements will provide more flexibility and choice to growers and an opportunity for both growers and end users to keep costs down. These changes together with the introduction of new financing arrangements for the AWB will ensure that the industry is in a strong position to meet competitive challenges into the next century. I commend the Bill to honourable members and I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
Debate (on motion by Mr Tim Fischer) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Kerin, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr KERIN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: — I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill and the associated Wheat Industry Fund Levy Collection Bill is to enable the wheat industry to impose and collect a single ad valorem levy on wheat, for distribution between the Wheat Research Trust Fund and any industry fund which may be established under the provisions of the Wheat Marketing Bill 1989. This latter Bill is the basis for the whole legislation package covering new wheat marketing arrangements to apply from 1 July this year. The levy will be paid on wheat that is sold, delivered or processed by or on the growers' behalf from 1 July this year. This will enable the continuation of the current research funding arrangements based on grower and matching Commonwealth contributions from that date. The Grains Council of Australia will determine the rate of levy, based on a percentage of sales value, for payment to the research fund. This percentage, which will be set by regulation, cannot be less than 0.25 per cent, and this compares with the current rate of research tax of about 0.35 per cent of value. The industry has already indicated a preparedness to increase its contribution to research over a three-year period in order to move towards the ceiling of the Government's matching contribution of 0.5 per cent of average gross value of production.

The industry fund provided for under the Wheat Marketing Bill to finance a number of commercial activities by the Australian Wheat Board will be activated only if the industry, through the Grains Council, determines that a percentage of the total levy to be imposed under the levy Bill is to be used for this purpose. This percentage of sales value cannot be less than 2 per cent which is equivalent to about $3.80 per tonne for standard quality wheat.

The decision to implement an ad valorem levy to replace the previous fixed rate per tonne wheat taxes, which were imposed for research purposes, and the operation of the stockfeed permit scheme, was designed to make the levy as equitable as possible. For example, a tonne of prime hard wheat is more valuable by about $35 than a tonne of feed wheat and therefore an ad valorem levy will distribute the levy burden more evenly among growers of different qualities of wheat.

The amount of revenue collected for wheat research purposes under the new levy arrangements is not expected to vary from current estimates, which reflect the industry's agreement to increase its contribution to research. Revenue is expected to increase to $11.8m by 1991-92 from the current level of around $10.5m.

It is estimated that if the industry fund is activated the component of the levy for payment to the fund would initially be set at 2 per cent of sale value. This would result in revenue of an estimated $55m in a full year. Administration of the levy collection arrangements will be undertaken within the existing resources of the Department of Primary Industries and Energy.

I commend the Bill to honourable members and I present the explanatory memorandum covering this Bill and the related levy Bills which are part of this package-that is, the Wheat Industry Fund Levy Collection Bill 1989, the Wheat (Termination of Tax) Bill (No. 1) 1989, the Wheat (Termination of Tax) Bill (No. 2) 1989, the Wheat (Termination of Permit Tax) Bill 1989 and the Wheat Tax (Permit) Collection Amendment Bill 1989.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mrs Kelly, for Mr Willis, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kelly The Hon R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

On 25 May 1988 the Government released a policy statement outlining a new framework for telecommunications services in Australia. This was an integral part of the Government's third term micro-economic agenda, which emphasised the need to improve the efficiency of our economic infrastructure. The new arrangements for telecommunications were designed as part of a process of structural adjustment of key industries, with a view to establishing and sustaining longer term economic growth. Also, the Government will continue to serve the significant social objectives associated with the important role in the Australian community of access to telephone services.

The Australian telecommunications industry is of strategic importance to both the manufacturing and service sectors of the Australian economy. It is a key to export led growth. The importance of information industries in the world economy is growing. The world's telecommunications market is currently estimated at around $400 billion per annum, more than computing, pharmaceuticals or air travel. The Australian market is about 2.5 per cent of the world market or $10 billion. Australia's telecommunications industry must be established on a sound and efficient basis, so it can adapt to changing technologies and user needs. This will contribute to Australia's ability to compete effectively in the rapidly growing world market. Greater efficiency and competitiveness are also required if the Australian people are to continue to receive high standard communication facilities, provided efficiently, economically and on an equitable basis. Significant reforms are being undertaken by the Government to achieve these goals. Changes to the structural frameworks of the telecommunications carriers-Telecom Australia, the Overseas Telecommunications Commission (OTC) and Aussat-are being implemented separately. These changes will ensure that these government business enterprises are more efficient, responsive and accountable to both government and Australian users of telecommunications services.

New regulatory arrangements, introduced in this Telecommunications Bill, will separate the technical and regulatory functions from the operations of the carriers and place these responsibilities in the hands of an independent industry regulator, the Australian Telecommunications Authority-Austel. Austel will also be responsible for consumer protection, promotion of competition in the industry, and monitoring the efficiency and adequacy of the services provided by carriers. This is the most significant reform in Australian telecommunications since 1975, when the Whitlam Labor Government created two major public enterprises, Telecom and Australia Post, from the former Postmaster-General's Department.
There are five key elements in the Telecommunications Bill now before the House:
the establishment of the Australian Telecommunications Authority, Austel, as the telecommunications industry regulator, with both technical and economic regulatory functions;
the definition of those telecommunications services which will, for reasons of network development and social objectives, be reserved to Telecom, OTC and Aussat;

the creation of a streamlined licensing regime for other services which, combined with safeguards against discriminatory behaviour by the carriers, will allow free and fair competition in the provision of value added services and the efficient operation of approved private networks;
the assurance of fair and open competition in the customer equipment market; and
the provision of mechanisms to ensure that consumer interests are protected and the Government's social objectives are achieved by the telecommunications industry.
Austel

As the new industry regulator, Austel will encourage the right environment for growth in the telecommunications industry. In addition to administering the provisions which define the boundaries of the monopoly, Austel will take over from Telecom the function of approving equipment for connection to the public-switched telephone network. Industry will play a major role in the development of appropriate technical standards which will be administered by Austel. There will be close cooperation between Austel and the Standards Association of Australia in the development of both mandatory and voluntary standards for the telecommunications industry.

As well as being the technical regulator, Austel will have an economic regulation role. Austel will operate with a Chair and two other statutory office holders. Austel will have approximately 70 additional staff, and the cost of running the Authority is estimated to be $5m per annum. It is our aim to have Austel operational on 1 July 1989. It is intended for Austel to develop close links with the Trade Practices Commission, in order to assist both bodies in their respective roles of ensuring that the carriers do not misuse their monopoly powers in competitive markets. The Government intends to appoint the Chair and one other member as part time associate members of the Trade Practices Commission. The Bill contains mechanisms to ensure that those affected by an Austel decision have the right to seek reconsideration by Austel or review by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. It is not the intent of the Government to foster legalistic processes which could be used to thwart Austel's legitimate decision making processes, but to ensure that those involved receive natural justice. If the appeals machinery is abused or proves too cumbersome in practice, I will move to amend the legislation as necessary.

As for other similar statutory authorities, the Government expects Austel to seek to recover some of its costs of operation from the industry. A companion piece of legislation to this Bill, the Telecommunications (Application Fees) Bill 1989, provides for the setting of fees for a range of Austel services such as applications for variations to class licences and applications for permits to attach equipment to the network. These fees will be set to recover direct costs only and Austel will be asked to report to Government, following consultation with the industry, on the practicalities of recovering some of the other costs of its operations from the industry.

Provision has been made for a power of ministerial direction over Austel, but only as regards policy matters. This power of direction will not extend to specific decisions in individual cases. The Minister will also be able to request reports from the Authority on a broad range of issues. In this regard, I will shortly be writing to the Chair of Austel to seek reports on matters affecting both the operations of Austel and the wider operations of the telecommunications service industry. As foreshadowed in the 1988 May statement, these will include a report on the implications of licensing an additional operator of public mobile telephone services and a report on the appropriateness of the current policy on the joint use of private networks by `common interest' groups.
Basic Network Services

After reviewing telecommunications policy early in 1988, the Government decided that certain services should be reserved for provision by the three established carriers only. One reason for this was network development. There is a clear need to secure the orderly and efficient development of the basic telecommunications network by taking advantage of the economies of scale and scope that exist in the industry, and by avoiding costly and uneconomic duplication of facilities that can be most efficiently provided by a single supplier. The other reason is the important need for universal service, which is a particular community service obligation placed on Telecom Australia. The Government expects Telecom to provide equitable access to standard telephone services as efficiently and economically as practicable. It is therefore necessary to allow for Telecom to average its prices and practise some cross subsidy. Telecom will be specifically accountable to the Government, through Austel, which will monitor the efficiency with which Telecom meets its obligations.

This legislation provides for the continuation of a monopoly by the carriers in the provision of telecommunications facilities. It also specifies certain services which can be provided on those facilities only by designated carriers. Telecom will be the sole domestic provider of public-switched voice, data and video services, public switched integrated services digital networks (ISDN), non-satellite leased circuits and public mobile telephone services. OTC will be the sole provider of these services internationally, and Aussat will be the sole provider of satellite facilities within Australia and is given extended scope to provide private network facilities to and from Australia. Third party carriage, or the shared use and resale of leased circuits, will continue to be prohibited.

The legislation also includes provisions to ensure equity within the industry and to encourage the efficient utilisation of our telecommunications infrastructure. These provisions require the carriers to supply capacity on a non-discriminatory basis to all valid customers: residential or business users, private network operators or value added service providers.
Value Added Services

Beyond the reserved services, the legislation provides for full and free competition in the provision of value added services, or VAS. This Bill creates a licensing regime for VAS which will minimise government intervention in routine commercial activities. The introduction of a class licence, subject to standard conditions, will provide for the operation of all currently approved forms of VAS. There will be no need for a VAS provider to obtain specific approval for a service which clearly falls within the class licence. A person who wishes to introduce an innovative service which is not already covered in the class licence may apply to Austel for a specific authorisation. No authorisation will be given to a service which infringes on the reserved services. If it does not infringe, the class licence will then be amended to encompass provision of the new service by any VAS operator. In this way, the costly and burdensome practice of individual licensing can be avoided.

Austel, and not the carriers, will be the arbiter of what is a value added service. Austel will thus administer the boundary determined by this legislation between the reserved services and the competitive services. Provisions in the legislation require carriers to provide carriage for all authorised VAS, and to ensure that there is no price discrimination. The carriers will be required to maintain separate accounting arrangements for their own VAS activities, to provide a level playing field for competition in these services. This Bill maintains the status quo with regard to video and audio information and entertainment services (VAIES), but should the current review of the broadcasting legislation require amendments to this legislation, then I will move them as necessary.
Customer Equipment

With the exception of the first phone, steps have already been taken to liberalise the provision and maintenance of customer equipment. These are formally recognised in this Bill, and in conjunction with the new regime for value added services, they will open up new opportunities for Australian industry to develop and expand. The encouragement of active competition provided by this legislation is a major step towards making the telecommunications sector stronger and more able to compete on an international level.

There is provision in the legislation to give effect to the Government's new industry development arrangements for the customer equipment manufacturing sector. These were announced in December last year and are aimed at making the industry internationally competitive. I will be directing Austel, under the legislation, to ensure that all relevant customer equipment complies with these arrangements.
Consumer Protection and Social Obligations

One of Austel's prime roles will be as a consumer watchdog, reporting on the performance of the carriers in their delivery of reserved services. It will administer the Government's formula for the price capping of basic services, which will ensure that the average price of a basket of basic telecommunications services will fall in real terms. The legislation also provides a power for the Minister to declare that a specified reserved service charge is to be subject to notification and disallowance. This will provide an additional safeguard for consumers and Austel will be able to give advice to the Minister on pricing practices for carrier reserved services.

Austel will also report to Government on the performance of Telecom in meeting its community service obligations, including its responsibility to provide universal service and other socially necessary services such as public telephones.

With regard to consumer complaints, Austel may deal with them itself if general regulatory considerations are involved, or it may direct them to the Trade Practices Commission or the Federal Ombudsman. It is not intended that Austel will take over any of the Ombudsman's current activities regarding the investigation of individual complaints. Appropriate arrangements will be developed to co-ordinate the work of Austel and the Ombudsman's Office. Austel will, however, have a responsibility to investigate complaints that raise regulatory questions, and it will work closely with the Ombudsman's Office to ensure that complaints against the carriers are investigated promptly and that any necessary follow-up action is taken. It is intended that there will be a review of the respective roles of Austel and the Ombudsman within two years of Austel's creation to ensure that consumer complaints are being handled as effectively as possible.

The Government is confident that these measures-stabilising an independent regulator, defining specific community service obligations for Telecom, guaranteeing that average price rises for basic telecommunications services fall in real terms, introducing new accountability arrangements for the carriers-will protect the rights of consumers and ensure that the telecommunications industry fulfils important social obligations and contributes to national economic growth. This Bill has widespread support within both the telecommunications services industry and the general community. There was extensive consultation with interested groups before the Government's decisions relating to telecommunications reform were announced in May 1988, and this consultation has continued. A draft of this Bill was made available to the industry for comment and a wide range of interested groups responded. While this legislation incorporates the results of these consultations, the Bill does not simply reflect the demands of sectional interests. This Bill is an important element in the Government's program of micro-economic reform. It serves the interests of the telecommunications industry and at the same time it legislates for the continuation of universal service. It will benefit all members of the Australian community.

Before I conclude I would like to thank some members of the Australian Labor Party, particularly those involved in the Caucus committee, for their long term consultations with us. I would also like to pay tribute to representatives of my Department who, under the leadership of Miss Vanessa Fanning, led these consultative teams in very elaborate discussions. DEBATE.TITLE: SITE REDEVELOPMENT OF CSIRO LABORATORIES, STAGE 1, NORTH RYDE, NEW SOUTH WALES

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Approval of Work: Public Works Committee Act

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, it is expedient to carry out the following proposed work which was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and on which the Committee has duly reported to Parliament: CSIRO North Ryde Laboratories, site redeveloped, stage 1.

The proposed public work involves the first stage of a long term program to construct new laboratory facilities, refurbish existing buildings, demolish inefficient and unsafe buildings and upgrade mechanical services, site entry, internal roads and car parks at the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO), North Ryde. The North Ryde complex is the CSIRO's principal research centre in New South Wales. It currently accommodates some 700 staff and is the national headquarters for the divisions of biotechnology, coal technology, food processing and a principal centre for the division of exploration geoscience. The site also accommodates parts of other divisions.

Works include a new three-storey gene technology laboratory building, a new computer and administration building, additions to the library-conference centre and refurbishment of an existing laboratory for the division of biotechnology. Also included is a new three-storey geophysics laboratory building for the division of exploration geoscience, the first stage of a central chilled water installation for the divisions of exploration geoscience and coal technology, and refurbishment-modification of part of two buildings to be occupied by the division of coal technology. The scope of work further includes demolition of some obsolete and substandard buildings, relocation of some existing roads and services, and upgrading of car parks and landscaping

The work accords with the master development plan prepared for the site in 1984. This redevelopment proposal is essential to permit increased research into topics of vital national importance. The estimated cost for this project is $18.5m at August 1988 prices. I believe that it is expedient that this work be carried out and I commend the motion to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: CONSTRUCTION OF FACILITIES FOR 2ND CAVALRY REGIMENT, DARWIN

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Reference of Work: Public Works Committee Act

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, the following proposed work be referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for consideration and report: Construction of facilities for 2nd Cavalry Regiment, Darwin.

This Government's defence policy includes the permanent deployment of both Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF) and Army units in northern Australia. The proposal now before the House is for the construction of new facilities to allow for the relocation of the Army's 2nd Cavalry Regiment from New South Wales to Darwin. The operational role of the 2nd Cavalry Regiment is to conduct reconnaissance, provide security and engage in offensive, defensive and delaying action in northern Australia. The 2nd Cavalry Regiment currently occupies permanent working and living-in facilities at Holsworthy in New South Wales. The move to the Northern Territory will involve around 400 service personnel and equipment, including some 70 armoured fighting vehicles. As defence facilities currently available in Darwin are fully committed, new working, training, recreational, messing and living-in facilities are required for the unit. Some additional administrative support facilities are also required.

The extent and areas of the proposed work are as follows: New 2nd Cavalry Regiment barracks and training facilities will be provided on a newly acquired site at Palmerston, approximately 20 kilometres east of the Darwin central business district. The site is of sufficient size to accommodate the working, recreational, messing and living-in facilities for the unit, and also provides a close training area for the unit. Additional administrative support facilities are to be provided at the existing Larrakeyah barracks near central Darwin. There will be both the provision of some new buildings and the refurbishment and extension of some existing facilities. Additional ammunition store houses are to be provided within the proposed RAAF explosive ordnance storage complex to be built at RAAF Base Darwin. The estimated cost of this proposal is $62.7m at December 1988 prices. Subject to parliamentary approval and Department of Defence funding priorities, the construction program is planned to enable the 2nd Cavalry Regiment to relocate to Darwin by the end of 1992.

I trust that my action today in referring this important defence project to the Public Works Committee illustrates our commitment to proceed with this project. There have been some ill-informed comments in the Northern Territory by Ministers of the current Government of the Northern Territory to the effect that this project might not proceed, despite repeated assurances on this subject by me and the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley). I trust that our actions here today will put the matter to rest once and for all. We are committed to this project. We expect that it will be dealt with expeditiously by the Committee, and I will come back to the House as soon as possible to recommend expediency. I have much pleasure in tabling the plans.

TALK.START.PARA: —I put on record yet again that the Opposition totally supports the move of the 2nd Cavalry Regiment to the north.
—I am pleased to hear it.
—I hope the honourable member for the Northern Territory is listening, because he has been running around this country telling lies. He told one here today in this House.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. I ask the honourable member to withdraw the statement that I have told lies. It is totally unparliamentary and an accusation which I refute.
—I ask the honourable member to withdraw.

—I withdraw, Mr Deputy Speaker. The honourable member has been running around this country being extremely careless with the truth time after time. Will he get it through his thick head that nowhere is there a record of the Opposition ever opposing this move? Let us get that straight. If the Government has problems with some of the people on its side of the House, the honourable member for the Northern Territory is probably the bloke who is causing them.
—No; it is the Ministers from the Northern Territory who have been attempting to say that this will not proceed. You know what this is all about.
—Well, the Minister has put the matter to rest for his side of the chamber.
—I suggest the honourable member for McPherson ignore the interjections and proceed with his speech.

—Let me put the issue to rest once and for all for this side. We have always supported this movement of the 2nd Cavalry Regiment, and we still do. We support the reference to the Public Works Committee and we hope it will be dealt with expeditiously. Some 400 men and women are to move to Darwin. It is, from a defence point of view, a very sensible move to have a reconnaissance regiment in the north. I guess some 200 of those people will be married. Although I did not hear a reference to the building of married quarters, I presume that that is something that will be coming. I ask the Minister whether that is correct.
—Yes, there will be quite a number of houses constructed as part of this project, but it is not included in this reference.

—The regiment will take with it some 70 armoured vehicles. It seems appropriate at this time to make reference to those because there is something very strange about the Government's program to equip this regiment. The regiment is at the moment equipped with M-113 armoured fighting vehicles. Last year the Government offered, unbeknownst, I might say, to the Chief of the General Staff and his officers, to purchase 100 wheeled armoured fighting vehicles from the United States of America. There were no trials on these vehicles-nothing to say whether they were suitable or unsuitable-but the offer was made. I do not know at this stage whether it has been accepted. The point I am making is that to equip this reconnaissance regiment with wheeled armoured fighting vehicles before it goes to the north--
—This is out of order.
—I do not need any advice from the honourable member. Not knowing whether these vehicles will be suitable is a very strange way to conduct--
—Order! The Chair thinks the honourable member for McPherson is straying from the motion before the House. I ask him to come back to it.

—The development of this facility in the north follows the opening of RAAF Base Tindal a couple of weeks ago. I just remind the House and the people of Australia that, while the Government claims credit for that development, the decision to develop Tindal and place a fighter squadron there was made in the days of the Fraser Government. I would have thought that during the opening of that base some acknowledgment of that could have been made.
—Will there be any accommodation for those vehicles under this project?

—We do not know so far what vehicles will be taken. To mention another matter just briefly, I refer to the naval facilities in the north in Darwin. That is something that will have to be closely looked at in due course because the facilities at the moment can take only patrol boats and there is an obvious requirement that in later years-or as soon as possible-some facility be put there to look after the increasing deployment of our destroyers and frigates to the north. In short, we very much support this project. We want to see it go to the Public Works Committee and dealt with so that it can physically get under way as soon as possible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snowdon Mr W.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am encouraged by the support that the shadow Minister for defence, the honourable member for McPherson (Mr White), has given to this project. I might say that, far from walking around this country misrepresenting him or telling what he would describe as untruths, I have represented his view very accurately. His difficulty is that the only time he opens his mouth is when it is to change feet. If he were to take note of what he has said to people he would recognise that he has undermined the confidence of the Northern Territory community-I am pleased that he has done it-in the Opposition's policy on defence. He has implied on a number of occasions that the Opposition is concerned that the Northern Territory is getting too good a deal out of this Government in terms of defence expenditure.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to see this matter referred to the Committee as quickly as possible. I am assured by the Chairman of that Committee that it will be dealt with expeditiously. This will be done for a number of reasons, one of which is its importance in terms of the Government's defence strategy. Another reason is its importance to the Northern Territory community. It is important not only in the context of having Australia's armed services posited in the north but also because of the money which will go into the Northern Territory economy at a time when it needs it. The construction industry in particular has been experiencing a slump for 18 months or so. The infusion of funds into the Northern Territory economy as a result of this decision when it is finally made by the Parliament will add tremendously to business confidence in Darwin in particular and in the Northern Territory in general.

Another matter which relates to this project is Kangaroo 89. I am sure that the 2nd Cavalry Regiment, or elements of it, will be involved in that exercise. That, too, is something which has been kyboshed by the shadow Minister who has just spoken. I would suggest that, rather than making accusations about what I have or have not said about him, he need only get a transcript of what he himself has said. He will then realise that what he has said has undermined the community's confidence in his side of the Parliament. In fact, decisions such as the one this Government is making about the 2nd Cavalry Regiment restore the faith of the Northern Territory community in this Government's ability to deliver on its promises, not only in terms of defence policy but also in terms of providing infrastructure in northern Australia generally which will be of use to the whole community.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: CONSTRUCTION OF COMMONWEALTH OFFICES IN LOGAN CITY, QUEENSLAND

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, the following proposed work be referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for consideration and report: Construction of Commonwealth offices in Logan City, Queensland.

In line with the Government's objectives of increasing Government owned office accommodation and reducing overall rental costs, it is proposed to build Commonwealth office accommodation in Logan City, Queensland. This proposal is for the construction of a three-level office building of some 5,600 square metres of office accommodation. The proposed building will be ideally situated in the Logan City central business district and will house elements of the Department of Social Security and the Department of Employment, Education and Training, providing them with shopfront accommodation. Secure underground car parking for 120 vehicles and additional parking for motorbikes are special features of the proposed building.

The building has been designed with the surrounding suburban environment in mind and provides a focus for Commonwealth activity in Logan City. In recognising the need to cater for the future needs of intended occupants, the building allows for the expansion of approximately 800 square metres of office accommodation at the upper floor level. The cost estimate for the construction of this work is $9.6 million at April 1989 prices. I table all drawings of the proposed works and I commend the motion to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jull Mr D.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition welcomes the announcement made by the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr West) of the referral of the construction of the new Commonwealth offices in Logan City to the Public Works Committee. May I say, as one of the members who represents Logan City, that it is more than welcome in the community. I know the Mayor of Logan City, Alderman Fred Huntress, and Alderman Ken Cameron will be delighted with this particular news. Obviously, I would like to see its speedy passage through the Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: Logan City, south of Brisbane, is one of Australia's newest cities. It has a population of about 150,000 people and is one of the fastest growing areas of Australia. There are some very real difficulties in this part of the world. Ten years ago, Logan City was divided off from the Albert Shire. I do not think I am being unkind when I say that the infrastructural requirements of that particular city were, to a very great degree, affected by the then Queensland Government and the hosting Albert Shire. However, after a great deal of hard work and good management, Logan City is now very much playing its part in being the second largest city in Queensland.

This move by the Commonwealth to construct a three-level office building of some 5,600 square metres at a cost of more than $9 million will be more than welcomed by the community. Not only will it provide a centrepiece to the central business district of Logan City, but also it will bring together those Commonwealth services so urgently required and so often used in that part of Queensland.

Unfortunately, Logan City has one of the highest percentages of young unemployed in Australia. There is now no doubt that the present facilities, in terms of the Commonwealth Employment Service and the Department of Social Security, are stretched to the limit and have been stretched to the limit for a great number of years. The consolidation of the Commonwealth facilities will be a great boon to this district. In a personal sense, I welcome it. I know the Logan City Council will welcome the move. I wish this project a speedy passage through the Committee, as it will make a great contribution to the future growth and development of Logan City, Queensland's second largest city.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Downer Mr A.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to say a few words in relation to the amendments which have come from the Senate on the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987. I understand the other Bill will be taken separately.
—Three Bills will be dealt with in committee.

—As far as the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill is concerned, the Opposition will oppose these amendments. We believe that the whole saga of the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill is a very sorry one. This Bill was originally introduced in 1987; hence its title has the year 1987 in it. It was greeted with uproar from the customs community. Enormous concern was expressed about this legislation and the concern was transmitted back to the Government. The Government has not responded adequately to the concerns that were raised, many of which were entirely justified.

SPEECH.PARA: I get the impression that throughout this whole legislative process we have been dealing with a Yes, Minister saga. Proposal after proposal has been put forward. The Government strikes me as having a scant understanding of what is actually going on in the context of this legislation. That is the reason why the Government has not responded properly to representations put to it by this side of the House and by a number of different people in the business community.

The amendments to this Bill were sent to the customs community in February of this year. Customs was given about one week to comment on those changes before the legislation was due to be debated in the Parliament. I regarded that as entirely inappropriate. Consequently, the Opposition went to the Government and said, `For Heaven's sake, give that community more time to examine the proposals that you are putting forward and to consult more fully with you'. The Government agreed to that proposal so last week these amendments were passed through the Senate and came to the House of Representatives.

As a result of the Government's not considering the representations made to it in relation to these amendments, we have bad legislation which is being made worse. First of all, we have massively complex valuations of imported goods, valuations affected by these amendments, which cover some 38 pages. That compares with Canada's legislation, which contains only 10 pages of similar valuations. The interpretation sections of the actual Bill cover 18 pages and there are 56 definitions. The only way we will ensure that the Australian Customs Service operates efficiently is if people can actually understand what is going on. The Government, however, has decided to go down an extraordinarily complex path; a path which will involve enormous costs to the customs community, to customs agents and to importers in general. It is a path which, in turn, will disadvantage the general flow of trade in and out of Australia.

Secondly, these amendments include an amendment-I think it is No. 14-in relation to the duty on foreign inland freight. We made these points to the Government in another place, but the Government apparently paid scant regard to our concerns. We are not satisfied with its argument that by imposing duty on foreign inland freight the costs of imported goods will be increased. The Government's argument is that it will refer those to the Industries Assistance Commission, which can then make recommendations to the Government and the Government can adjust duty appropriately. The fact is that the Government has said this will be done in the context of soda ash, and the soda ash industry is one of those most concerned about this. But what about timber and paper products? Will the Government subsequently refer these things to the Industries Assistance Commission? Will we have months of examination by the Industries Assistance Commission and recommendations from the IAC going back to the Government?
