PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 12 April, on motion by Mr Keating:
That the House take note of the following papers:
Economic Statement, April 1989, Ministerial Statement, 12 April 1989.
Taxation of foreign source income-An information paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last night's statement by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) has been greeted with widespread cynicism and disbelief throughout the nation today. That is not because Australian families do not want and need taxation relief. It is because last night the Treasurer offered not a glimmer of hope that the benefits he announced would not quickly disappear under the heat of the high interest rates and high inflation which are the product of the policies of the Hawke Government. That is the central reality of the April statement. That is why today Australians all around the country simply do not believe the Treasurer and do not believe the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke).

SPEECH.PARA: Last night the Treasurer, the man who has presided over the largest tax bite in Australia's history, wanted everyone to believe that he was extending his hand to Australian taxpayers, but honest taxpayers already know that hand only too well: it has been in their pockets for the last six years. The Prime Minister and the Treasurer have both admitted that under their policies there is no fall in interest rates in sight. Since the 1985 tax package Labor has grabbed an extra $10 billion in tax, and last night it gave us back $5 billion.

So that not even the Labor Party can lie and misrepresent our position, let me tell this Parliament where we stand. We believe that hard-working people should receive tax cuts and wage justice, but we also believe that because the Government has failed to solve the key problems facing the Australian economy, any benefits delivered last night are likely to disappear very quickly. We want lasting improvements for all Australians, not temporary benefits which vanish.

Last night was an exercise in diverting public attention from a collapsing economic strategy. It was the politics of the warm inner glow in the desperate hope that no awkward questions would be asked. But those questions have been asked and indeed they must be asked. Last night the Treasurer did not tell us that in 1983 we spent 26c of every export dollar meeting our overseas debt commitments and that that figure has soared to 63c of every export dollar. He did not tell us that we had the highest inflation rate amongst major industrialised countries. He did not tell us that home interest rates are at record levels. He did not tell us that, despite a dramatic improvement in commodity prices, our trade balance remains in chronic deficit. He did not tell us that our productivity levels are amongst the worst in the industrialised world. He did not tell us that over the last six years living standards of an average family have declined sharply and he did not tell us that almost all the major economic forecasts made in his last Budget have gone hopelessly astray.

To borrow a phrase, it takes a special kind of talent to have done all of that damage to the Australian economy despite the fact that while the Hawke Government has been in power the world has experienced the longest sustained boom since the end of World War II and domestically we have enjoyed some of the best farming seasons for decades. One can only imagine the further economic wreckage we would now survey if the Hawke Government had faced a world recession and a desperate drought, both of which afflicted Australia in the early 1980s.

There was an air of total unreality about last night's exercise. Today we are more in hock to the rest of the world then ever before. We owe foreigners more than $120 billion. That is $7,500 for every man, woman and child. In 1982 our total foreign debt was $24 billion. I would say to those who rail against foreign investment that they should direct their anger not at foreigners who invest in Australia but at a Government which has produced this massive slide into debt and created a drug-type addiction to the saving of foreigners.

Foreign debt is piling up month by month, living standards are being squeezed, productivity is stagnant and inflation is surging. Yet in this climate the Treasurer asks us to believe that his tax cuts are going to be of lasting value. How can they last, unless we have lower interest rates and lower inflation and unless we reduce our high overseas debt? At present as a nation, we are spending far more than we are producing. That difference is being made up by imports, and we are paying for those imports by drawing on foreign savings to the tune of about 4 per cent of our gross domestic product (GDP). That is why our foreign debt continues to grow. These are the alternatives for Australia: We can go on using high interest rates to squeeze activity and thus slow down imports, but ultimately that means lower investment and less economic restructuring and does nothing to address the root causes of our foreign debt problem. Alternatively, we can reduce our reliance on foreign savings by raising domestic savings, increasing the incentive to invest and lowering the cost of our export and import competing industries, thus turning around our chronic balance of payments deficit.

To do this we must sweep away restrictive work practices, archaic production techniques, regulations which hinder entrepreneurial initiative and drive, and other measures which stop resources from flowing to their most valuable national uses. That is the only path to higher national productivity and efficiency. It is a path that a coalition government will take, and it is a path which this Government turned its back on last night.

To have been credible last night the Treasurer should have announced the following: first, further measures to reduce Government spending and eliminate waste and inefficiency, to give taxpayers value for money and further lower the tax burden in future; second, promotion of domestic savings and a more family oriented tax system to reduce our reliance on foreign capital and to give real incentive to families to look after themselves; third, a comprehensive program of privatisation to reduce industry costs. Improve consumer choice and, importantly, to repay national debt; fourth, a more productivity and enterprise based industrial relations system to encourage employers and employees to work together to improve company performance and reduce industrial disputes; fifth, a more flexible and entrepreneurial higher education system; sixth, fundamental freeing up of our coastal shipping and waterfront scandals-because it costs more to carry cargo from Burnie in Tasmania to Newcastle than it does from Newcastle to Los Angeles on the west coast of the United States of America. The seventh announcement should have been a reduction of the barriers in many areas of telecommunications.

Tonight I am releasing with this address, policy papers which flesh out our proposals in the key areas of award restructuring, the waterfront, coastal shipping and contracting out of public services. I want to spend a few moments addressing some remarks to those particular areas. Last night's statement totally ignored the huge disincentives for savings that exist within our present taxation system. Labor's capital gains tax is a tax on savings and that is why we intend to abolish it. In its place we will have a sliding scale speculative gains tax. We will tax a declining proportion of the real capital gain over the first five years of the investment. This will encourage savings and reward patient investors who wish to build up a business or accumulate a nest egg for their retirement. Once an asset has been held for five years there will be no liability at all for capital gains tax. This change will remove the distorting impact of Labor's capital gains tax on housing which is one of the major reasons the price of housing is so high in the major cities of Australia.

Superannuation is an important form of national savings and in recent years the tax treatment of superannuation has been radically revised. Because of the complicated nature of the legislation, the Government has yet to present it. I want to make it clear that we are opposed to changes that will act as a disincentive to saving through superannuation. Our recently released retirement income policy contains a number of proposals to promote self-provision for retirement and, in particular, our pension bonus plan will reward workers who defer retirement beyond the age of 65.

We believe we should reverse the trend of the last 20 years towards early retirement in favour of a policy which encourages able men and women to remain in the work force much longer. We will facilitate the establishment of retirement savings accounts for part time and casual workers. This will be of particular benefit to female employees.

The current taxation system has worked savagely against Australian families in recent years. The cost of raising children substantially affects the capacity of families to pay tax and should be given proper recognition in the taxation system. That recognition should never be regarded as a welfare hand-out. It puts greater equity back into the tax system and is an investment in our country's future.

I welcomed last night's adjustments to family allowances and to the dependant spouse rebate. They are a belated acknowledgment that over the last six years this Government has deliberately shifted the tax burden onto families through higher taxes and non-adjustment of family allowances and the dependant rebate. The increase in family allowances, while appearing substantial, is significantly less than the amount required to restore their value to what it was in March 1983 when the Hawke Government came to power. The increase in the dependant rebate is less than half the amount required to compensate for the fall in the real value of that rebate since 1983. Moreover, the income level of $282 is absurdly low and remains a substantial barrier to those married women wishing to work part time, thus balancing family and paid work responsibilities.

The Treasurer frequently boasts that fiscal policy is as tight as a drum. I therefore invite his attention to a vast area where substantial savings can accrue through competitive tendering for services provided by Government. At present, many services are provided in-house so that incentives to efficient and economic service provision are weak, if not absent entirely. The objectives and quality of service are often not clearly defined. Overseas experience such as in the United Kingdom suggests that savings of at least 20 per cent in the cost of services are possible without adversely affecting service quality. More flexible, efficient and economical methods of providing government services should result in a closer matching of service quality and cost and yield savings which can be used to increase program coverage. For example, private child care is up to $11 a week cheaper than public sector facilities, even after adjusting for differences in the number of places and age of children being cared for. If honourable members doubt that comparison, I invite them to have a talk to Senator Walsh.

In recent weeks, the Government has said much about the relationship between the trade union movement of Australia and a future coalition government. The Government simply cannot have it both ways. It cannot in one breath extol and applaud the alleged responsibility of the Australian trade union movement yet in the next breath threaten that same trade union movement which stands ready to sabotage the next coalition government. It simply cannot have it both ways. The union movement is either responsible or irresponsible. The truth is, as is acknowledged by union leaders such as Simon Crean and Michael Easson, the newly elected Secretary of the Labour Council in New South Wales, the trade union movement of 1989 will work with the next coalition government of this country.

Our relationship with that trade union movement will be different from that of the Hawke Government. Unlike the Hawke Government, we will not be owned by the trade union movement but importantly, unlike former coalition governments, we will have an unarguable mandate to implement a new and better approach to industrial relations. More importantly, the trade union movement will work with the next government because the policies of that government will carry enormous benefits for the rank and file members of that trade union movement.

Our industrial relations policy seeks to bring individual employers and employees together so that they have a common stake in the success of their enterprise. That is why we support enterprise based, profit sharing performance related pay schemes and employee share ownership. Such measures encourage managers and workers to improve communications within the firm, sweep away archaic work restrictive work practices and continually search for better ways of doing things and meeting customer needs. The shadow Minister for industrial relations, the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith), is currently working on a proposal to increase significantly the attractiveness of employee share ownership schemes. That proposal will be released in the near future.

A more enterprise or industry based union structure will reduce wage flow-ons to other industry areas and areas which face different economic conditions. The award restructuring proposals of the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) do not sufficiently encourage productivity improvement. While some pay scales will be related to acquisition of formal qualifications, they will not equate with actual on the job productivity and thus cannot be used to motivate improvement.

Our proposals for voluntary unionism are based on our belief in the benefits of competition. Compulsion infringes human rights and results in the exploitation of third parties. That applies whether one is dealing with trade unions or any other section of the Australian community. Unions have nothing to fear from competition if they are efficient and effective in representing employees. We will also enact secret ballots so that unionists are able to express their views free of intimidation.

Governments should not be involved in activities which can be performed better by the private sector. Public ownership insulates enterprise management from genuine competition, encouraging inefficiency, restricting work practices and lowering living standards for all Australians. That is why the coalition, unlike the Government, has for three years embraced a full-blooded policy of privatisation. We do not have a Clayton's privatisation policy where the Prime Minister of this country is begging his party for permission to raise some much needed capital for Australia's international flag carrier, Qantas Airways Ltd. We have a full-blooded privatisation policy that will offer enormous incentives and benefits for the employees of our great national enterprises.

Privatisation is not an exercise in flogging the national silver, privatisation is an exercise in selling into the hands of individual Australians the ownership of our great national enterprises. I am very happy to say that my colleague the shadow Minister for business and consumer affairs, the honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore), has developed a detailed program of privatisation which is winning the support and the admiration of the business community and intending shareholders in those enterprises throughout Australia.

Last December I released on behalf of the Liberal and National parties our Future Directions blueprint, which set out the values, the beliefs and the policies of the coalition parties. Future Directions raised three crucial tests to be applied by the next coalition government to any policy proposal. The first of those tests was: Does the proposal strengthen the family unit within our community? The second was: Does the proposal give individuals more incentive and hope? The final test was: Does the proposal give a preference to private enterprise over government enterprise and government monopoly? The Prime Minister and his Ministers, despite their furious denials, have been panicked into trying to respond to the agendas set by Future Directions since its launch last December.

In that context, I welcome a number of the measures announced last night which reduce some of the bias in our tax system against families. But let us not delude ourselves. We are still left with a tax system which has a profound bias against families, we still have an economic climate which hobbles initiative and enterprise and denies individuals lasting incentive; we still maintain massive public monopolies which cheat consumers; and this Government still dabbles with the notion that politicians and bureaucrats can run businesses and peoples' lives better than individual Australian men and women. In other words, the Government, having acknowledged the agenda set by Future Directions, has manifestly failed to match the standards of that document.

I believe that both the Prime Minister and the Treasurer have underestimated the intelligence of the Australian community. Australian families know full well that a tax cut rapidly devoured by higher inflation and higher mortgage interest rates is no tax cut at all. For years now we have lived with economic crisis and different excuses have fallen from the lips of the Government Ministers. Three years ago we were on the verge of being a banana republic but, now that our commodity prices are booming, new scapegoats must be found and, no doubt, as further failure compounds current failures, something else will be put in the dock.

Tonight I have outlined what the Treasurer should have said last night. Australia's problem is not that we lack resources. It is not our people; they are amongst the best and hardest working in the world. We are a stable nation politically and economically but, because we do not use our human resources productively enough, we continue to have economic problems. The challenge to raise our national productivity was the challenge that the Treasurer utterly failed to address last night, and that is why his statement has been greeted with cynicism.

DEBATE.TITLE: CUSTOMS AND EXCISE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1987

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The amendments which are proposed to the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987 will leave the Bill with only some major planks which seek to prevent importers minimising customs duty. However, according to the financial impact statement, the only directly measurable revenue gains will be $5.2m. This revenue derives from amendments to clause 12 which will include in the valuation of imported goods for customs purposes the cost of freight and insurance of those goods within a foreign country. This will represent a direct cost to importers and ultimately, of course, to consumers. I remind honourable member's that those consumers are not always people buying retail or luxury goods but, just as often, are manufacturers who require components for the production of goods in Australia which could ultimately be exported or, equally importantly, replace imports. It is not a logical or necessary change to the present position.

SPEECH.PARA: This change has the potential to create new anomalies as further advantages are given to those who ship directly from container depots in the major overseas ports. The Government has made noises suggesting that it can see the potential problems in this provision but is not willing to do anything about that right now. This is a completely unsatisfactory position for everyone, including industry, which needs certainty and stability in the application of customs duties and laws. The change I have mentioned is only a small part of a host of problems with the legislation as it will stand if these amendments are passed. The complexity of the legislation will cause considerable concern amongst those who have had to deal with it if this Bill becomes law.

The problems of complexity mirror difficulties which this Government has had with a range of its legislation. The common thread to such complexities is that they are usually concerned with revenue raising or the punitive functions of government. For example, in the Australian Taxation Office the complexity and ambiguity of poorly drafted legislation has been used to maximise the revenue gained from taxpayers through the use of penalties and a less than clear assessment of their liabilities.

The Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987, amendments to which we are now discussing, deals with the particularly important area of the valuation of imported goods for customs purposes and audit and verification powers to substantiate valuations. Unless the procedures laid down for these areas, which are important to the easy flow of traded goods, are as simple and effective as possible, both Australian businesses and consumers will suffer. Needless complexity does not assist the Australian Customs Service, which must administer the legislation and sift through the ambiguity to produce consistent decisions which will stand up under legal challenge.

The valuation provisions of the Bill are made more uncertain and potentially more onerous by the vast discretion given to the collectors of customs duties. It has been pointed out that 84 discretionary powers have been given to those making valuations under this Bill. The excessive use of discretionary power is not only indicative of lazy drafting of legislation, but also has the potential to produce a complete mess of the area where discretion is granted. The resort to greater discretionary and administrative powers is a feature of the incompetence of this Labor Government. The growth of these powers undermines the certainty of the rule of law and the ability of businesses to make sound commercial decisions.

A further feature of these amendments is the granting of power to administrative authorities which traditionally has been exercised only by the police or through the courts. Customs officials are to be given extensive powers to enter private offices and to inspect and copy documents. It is also to be made easier for Customs to obtain warrants and conduct searches. These powers should be taken very seriously indeed; yet the Government seems willing to throw these powers around with little regard for the rights of private citizens, or for the limits of government power. I doubt that the Government, with its traditional disregard for the sanctity of private property, is really aware of the enormity of the power involved in entering someone's premises at a time suitable to the Customs officials and having the ability to search for any relevant documentation, not on suspicion of a criminal offence, but merely to verify the assessment of customs duties.

TALK.START.PARA: —The rights of individuals don't matter to them.

—It is very heavy-handed stuff indeed. The record of other government departments which have similar powers is not very encouraging. The infamous Australian Tax Office raids on major corporations and providers of professional services is the most recent example of the disregard for the rights of citizens by Commonwealth Government administrative authorities.

SPEECH.PARA: There is another danger to these administrative problems. Throughout the world there is a growing concern with the rapid growth in non-tariff trade barriers. Any measure which makes it more difficult or more costly to bring goods into the country is a form of protection. If Australia is to have maximum credibility in world trade debates, it is essential that Australian law dealing with trade is of the very highest standards. The amended legislation which we are considering today does not meet those standards.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Downer Mr A.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —When I spoke to the amendments before the suspension of the sitting for dinner I was discussing foreign inland freight and the implications of the Government's amendments for the costs of importing into Australia certain goods which had incurred additional costs because of the application of the duty on foreign inland freight. I made the point then that I was concerned that, although the Government had said that it would refer these matters to the Industries Assistance Commission if there were any anomalies, it would take a great deal of time to resolve, and even when the Industries Assistance Commission had made its recommendations there would be no guarantee that the Government would act on those recommendations. That is a sloppy way to draft legislation; to draft it on the basis of hope-hope that the Government will do the right thing. The Government promised that it would not introduce a capital gains tax but it did. That is a very poor basis on which to draft legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: I have had representations from people who claim that this provision discriminates against small business. For example, a full container load which is assembled in a place such as Chicago and transported to a port and, in turn, sent to Australia would not attract duty on foreign inland freight. However, products which are packed at a container depot such as Los Angeles, having been transported in smaller parts from Chicago to Los Angeles, would attract foreign inland freight duty. I would like the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones) to clarify that point, because there is a lot of concern in the community about that apparent anomaly in the legislation. I would be happy if the Government clarified the potential for that anomaly occurring.

We on this side of the House have also expressed concern, as the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) did recently, about the implication for civil liberties in this sort of legislation. Some of the amendments enhance very substantially the powers of the Australian Customs Service to enter premises. The Law Council of Australia is a very good example of a highly reputable and respected body which is extremely concerned about giving the Australian Customs Service the sorts of powers which the Australian Taxation Office has. When one considers the enormous number of government instrumentalities, State and Federal, which are able simply to walk into people's business or private premises with some sort of warrant and inspect those premises for all sorts of vicarious reasons, one can see how civil liberties in this country are declining progressively. This sort of Customs power is a matter of concern to us because it is yet another example of still more power being put into the hands of the bureaucracy at the expense of ordinary Australians.

I have raised with the Minister and his officials my concern about Australian Customs Service officers being able to obtain warrants by telephone. I do not think that a Customs officer simply telephoning a magistrate and asking for a warrant to raid some business premises is an appropriate way of protecting civil liberties. If the community knew about the way in which those civil liberties could so easily be infringed in such a casual way, I know the broader community would support my concerns. I have suggested that, at the very minimum, if a warrant is to be obtained by telephone it should be obtained from a judge, as is the case, for example, under the provisions of the Telecommunications (Interception) Amendment Act 1987 and the National Crime Authority Act 1984.

I know that the Government has rejected this proposal because it suits the Australian Customs Service to implement its powers in the easiest, most casual, way. I understand that it suits the bureaucracy, but my concern is not always to satisfy the bureaucracy. My concern is to satisfy the rights of individuals in this country as well. The Government's proposal that a Customs officer, good as he may be-and I am not reflecting on the integrity of our Customs Service-can just pick up the phone, under this Act, and ring a magistrate and ask for a warrant is entirely inappropriate.

Let me say at once that these amendments are an improvement on the original proposal from the Customs Service that such a warrant could be obtained from a justice of the peace. In most instances a justice of the peace is not even a lawyer. It is quite outrageous that the Customs Service should have even considered including that sort of power in legislation. The Minister approved that proposal and he, not his officials, who might have put forward some advice which he accepted, is culpable. The Minister is responsible. He has agreed at least to restrict the issuing of warrants by telephone to magistrates, but this is still far too generous a power to give to officials.

The last point I wish to make about these amendments is that this sort of legislation enhances enormously the discretionary powers of the Australian Customs Service. The Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987 will add 84 different discretions in the valuation provisions to the Australian Customs Service. Anybody in this Parliament who takes notice of his or her constituents will know of the enormous problems caused by providing that sort of discretion to the Australian Taxation Office. Quite frankly, it would be utter madness to extend such discretion to other government instrumentalities.

For those reasons, we on this side of the Chamber have enormous concern about the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987 and, indeed, the amendments before the Committee. We are concerned about the enormous complexity of the legislation in terms of the valuation provisions. We are concerned about the implications of imposing duty on foreign inland freight-a measure that has been taken simply to satisfy some obtuse gap provision. We are concerned about the increase in the powers to Australian Customs officers to enter premises. We are concerned about the casual way the Minister wants to give the Australian Customs Service the power to obtain warrants just in a casual phone call with a casual magistrate. And we are, above all, concerned about the enormous additional discretionary powers that the Australian Customs Service has been given through this general legislation and through these amendments. On this side of the Chamber, as we expressed the view in another place, we stand opposed to this particular legislation and its amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BARRY JONES
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not propose to detain the Committee very long. I just make the point that the speech that the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) made before the suspension of the sitting for dinner began by his saying that this legislation had been rushed through, that there had been absolutely minimal consultation and that it was an example of a very heavy-handed authoritarian approach by the Government and in particular--
—Yes Minister legislation.

—The honourable member said it was Yes Minister legislation. He obviously thought that was an original line. The point is that this legislation has had about the gestation period of an elephant. It was introduced into the House in November 1987. It was clear that, as it was, it would not be able to pass the Senate because a whole number of objections were raised by various interest groups. The result was that over a very extended period, months, there were negotiations with organisers. In fact, far from it being a case of the bureaucrats whipping it past me and my applying my bare stamp at the end, I was very heavily involved in a number of the areas on which the major interest groups put their views. I was part of the negotiation and went through the whole thing with them, so I was very actively involved throughout. It has taken a long time because some of the organisations wanted further time to consult, they wanted to go back to their members and so on.

SPEECH.PARA: The legislation was introduced first in November 1987. There has been 18 months of consultation. What we now have, with no fewer than 45 amendments being introduced, is a piece of legislation about which, while I concede that there are points of disagreement with some of the special interest groups in the community, there is a much broader degree of consensus. The amendments were circulated not just a few days ago, as the honourable member for Mayo suggested, but in February 1989 after, as I say, this very long period of discussion. We dealt with over 100 representations from interest groups and 45 of the amendments have come in. This matter has not been handled in a very casual way; I think that it has been handled in a very responsible way.

When the honourable member for Mayo raises the question of civil liberties, he knows that he is touching on a very sensitive nerve as far as I am concerned, because I certainly have a passionate regard for civil liberties and I am always very conscious of the need to have some balance between preserving the rights of the citizen and the community at large. It is not as if we can say when we are concerned, for example, about the possibility of drugs entering the country, `Well, this is all terribly interesting. What we really need to do is to have an academic seminar of some sort where we get a marriage of the true minds and some sort of consensus about what we are going to do'. If we are going to act, we should act very quickly.

It is extraordinary that an esteemed colleague of the honourable member for Mayo, the Hon. Ted Pickering, a Minister in New South Wales, is traducing the Government, and me in particular-equally inaccurately, I might say-by saying, `Customs isn't doing the job. Why isn't it exercising powers? Why isn't it getting into it? Why isn't it really controlling the drug menace? '. I would have thought that if the honourable member for Mayo was following the line of--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Downer's friend Mrs Fuller is doing the same thing.
—Yes, so I understand. I would have thought that he would be endorsing the fact that we are taking the problem very seriously.
—It hasn't anything to do with drugs.
—Order! The honourable member for Mayo will cease interjecting.

—No, it is the way in which the Customs system operates. We are talking about the methodology used by Customs in order to protect the revenue and the Australian community. I will just take up a number of the points that were raised by the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) and the honourable member for Mayo.

SPEECH.PARA: The question of the special case of soda ash was raised. Some time ago Australian Consolidated Industries (ACI) approached the Government to express its concern over the new arrangements. On the basis of the figures presented it appears that importers of soda ask will face increased costs as a result of the new arrangements, resulting in a significant and unintended increase in the level of assistance to the local industry. On the basis of the information presented by ACI and the fact that the Industries Assistance Commission (IAC) has considered assistance levels for the chemical industry as recently as 1986, it has been decided to introduce an amendment in the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill 1989 to nullify the demonstrated assistance implications of the proposed valuation amendments in so far as soda ash is concerned. Consideration will also be given to submissions on other products where assistance levels are shown to be significantly increased as a result of the new valuation provisions.

The honourable member for Mayo raised a question about telephone warrants. I point out that the original provision in the legislation was for justices of the peace. It has been changed now to a magistrate and in the circumstances it is a judicially trained magistrate. The Government is proposing an amendment to provide a facility to permit in circumstances of urgency an application for a search warrant to be made by radio, telephone or other means of communication. Remember that Customs field audits and inspection of commercial documents might realistically have to be undertaken in parts of the country where chamber magistrates are not readily available. In situations of urgency, to preclude the removal or falsification of commercial records, a number of safeguards are contained in the provision to ensure against improper use, in particular the requirement that a judicially trained magistrate must be satisfied that this provision cannot be used indiscriminately or improperly.
Mr Downer interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Mayo will cease interjecting. I warn the honourable member for Mayo.
—In the circumstances, I think that is realistic.
—The Minister should not respond to the interjections either.

—No legislation is immutable. These matters are re-examined from time to time, and if evidence can be produced that there is some substantial injustice involved, I would not preclude the possibility of having another look at the legislation; but I am satisfied that it is a significant improvement on the original situation.

SPEECH.PARA: The question of inland freight was raised. The proposed amendments maintain the free on board basis of Australia's customs valuation system in that all overseas freight from the place of export to Australia is excluded from customs value. However, when the present valuation system was introduced in 1981, provision relating to inland freight had the effect of making optional the inclusion in customs value of inland freight and related costs incurred in the country of export. If inland freight and related costs are paid other than to the benefit of the vendor, then the amount is not included in the customs value.

That has created two possibilities: first, a purchaser may arrange its affairs so that all freighting is done by a third party to whom it pays directly; secondly, the purchaser may describe the freight carrier as a third party in the documents supplied to Customs, whereas that party is not in fact an arm's length third party but rather a conduit for those payments to the vendor. Customs has no way of distinguishing between the two situations by reference to the documentation provided to it by importers, since in the latter situation relevant documents will be retained overseas to ensure information about it is beyond Customs reach and knowledge. The solution chosen in the Bill is to remove the deduction for foreign inland freight. It was indicated in April 1987 in regard to the Government's strategy on the package of amendments that where the new valuation arrangements significantly raised protection levels for local industry, the Government would be prepared to consider requests for review by the IAC within six months of the new provisions coming into operation. That remains the case.

I think that covers the major matters raised by the Opposition. I tender the replacement explanatory memorandums. They cover the substance of the amendments. I commend the amendments to the Committee.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Resolution reported; report adopted.

Motion (by Mr Barry Jones) proposed:
That the amendments be agreed to:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Downer Mr A.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That amendment No. 11 be amended by omitting from proposed new clause 23a-
`` `234t. (1) Subject to section 243v, where:
(a) a person, whether knowingly, recklessly or otherwise:''
and substituting-
`` `243t (1) Subject to section 243v, where:
(a) a person, whether knowingly or recklessly:''.

The amendment that I have moved to the set of Senate amendments relates to the Senate's amendment No. 11. The reason that we on this side of the chamber are unhappy about this amendment is that the words it uses-`a person, whether knowingly, recklessly or otherwise:'-in relation to those who furnish a false or misleading statement being subject to penalties, are far too liberal. Our concern is the same concern we have had throughout the debates on this series of Customs Bills; it is a concern about the civil liberties implications of this sort of legislation.

Let me go to the report by the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills which I have in front of me. The report talks about proposed new section 243t (1) (a), the section which we on this side of the chamber would like to amend. I want to read to the chamber what the Senate Committee report says:

The Committee is concerned that innocent as well as fraudulent misstatements render the maker liable to duty. The Minister's view expressed in his response of 9 December 1987 that this is part of the price to be paid for a `green line' Customs clearance does not in the Committee's view justify the terms of this section.
The clause is brought to the attention of Senators as being possibly in breach of principle 1 (a) (i) of the Terms of Reference in that it may be considered to unduly trespass-
that is the Committee's split infinitive, not mine, Minister-
on personal rights and liberties.

That report by the Senate Scrutiny of Bills Committee sums up very clearly the concerns we have on this side of the chamber. The Minister tells us that he is concerned about civil liberties but, as has been explained to him before, he is not making provision in this legislation for people who have simply made a perfectly honest-let us say for the sake of argument-typographical error. If somebody who does that-for example, a typist who puts the decimal point in the wrong place or whatever it may be-does not happen to notice this minuscule change, that person will be subject to fairly severe penalties. I appreciate that that person can seek a remission from those penalties. I appreciate that Customs can give that person a remission. On the other hand, Customs may decide not to do so. The person could then go off to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, and so the process of law continues. The fact is that if somebody were to make an honest, simple slip, he would be guilty until he somehow proved himself to be innocent.

I think the words `or otherwise' are far too general. The Government is giving Customs this discretion-that is one thing-to determine whether a declaration has been misleading knowingly or recklessly, but it is adding to that discretion by saying `and in any other way as well'. In other words, if there happens to be anything wrong with it, Customs can impose a few penalties.

I am not denying the Minister's argument against this, which is `Oh, well, we have some sort of remissions provisions'. I have been through that point. The fact is that people should not be subject to potentially officious behaviour because of casual drafting of legislation.

The Minister and I have had some discussions about this matter. I have suggested to the Minister, as we are suggesting in this amendment, that the words `or otherwise' be left out. At one stage the Minister was kind enough to suggest to me that it would not be a bad idea if we replaced the word `otherwise' with the word `negligently'. Let me put it on the record that, having considered the matter overnight, I would be perfectly happy to have accepted the use of the word `negligently'. I do not think people should be negligent. I do not think they should be reckless. I do not think they should knowingly try to mislead Customs. I think Customs should act against people who do those sorts of things. But it is completely unreasonable to impose penalties on people who might have made some completely innocent typographical error.

Some people argue that we can at least accept the good faith of the Australian Customs Service, that its officers are not likely to act in a malicious or officious way. That is not a bad point. My experience of Customs officers in the six months I have been shadow Minister for Customs is that they are perfectly reasonable people and I do not think that typically they are malicious or officious. But who knows what will happen in the years ahead? If the Government is presenting legislation to the Parliament, it should do so in a way that ensures that that legislation covers various unforeseen contingencies, what has become part of the Australian lexicon in recent years since the Hawke Government has been in power-unintended consequences.

When one drafts legislation one has to think those things through. Who knows what the Customs officers will be like in future generations? Whilst we will be administering the Australian Customs Service in that time, I, as the Minister, will not be selecting every officer to work in the Customs Service. The legislation should be watertight. The Parliament should be outlining precisely what it intends rather than using vague language of this kind.

The only other point I want to make about this Bill concerns the Australian Democrats. We do not talk much about the Australian Democrats in here. I am sorry that the honourable member for Kingston (Mr Bilney) has left the chamber because he is utterly obsessed with the Australian Democrats. I do not think he thinks about much else during the day and possibly during most of the night as well. I imagine that he lies in bed, tossing and turning, worrying about them. There is a Senator called Senator McLean whom I discovered recently. Senator McLean, in a great and bold speech on this Bill, said that the Democrats would oppose this Bill unless the Government agreed to certain rather byzantine amendments in relation to the export of defence equipment. Naturally, the Government did not agree to that, as it turned out. So I assumed that the Democrats would oppose the Bill.

Interestingly, after what must have been a very heated discussion between Senator Button and Senator Haines-I am only guessing, but I think that must have been what happened-suddenly the Democrats caved in. We want to know what sorts of deals the Government has been doing with the Democrats in the Senate over the years to find out why it is that they continually cave in on these sorts of matters. It is interesting to see the way the Democrats stand up and thump the tub saying that they will do this and they will do that. They are all so strong and brave, saying that they will stand up for these sorts of people and those sorts of people, but when the crunch comes they simply cave in. These amendments to the legislation before us provide one example of the Democrats behaving in that quite extraordinary way.

Let me end on a positive note. In this legislation the Government has changed the forfeiture provisions. We on this side of the chamber certainly welcome those changes. There have been a lot of problems over forfeiture. They have been brought to my attention in the last few weeks. I was not aware of them before that. There have been a lot of problems and inequities involved with that kind of penalty, and I am glad that these amendments clear them up.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —As was so eloquently stated by my colleague the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer), the Opposition is concerned that the imposition of penalties under the proposed new section 243t in the amendments is potentially draconian in its application to cases of inadvertent error rather than deceit. The proposed section seeks to act as a disincentive for any errors, no matter, it seems, what their cause. I am not sure whether my colleague the honourable member for Mayo moved the amendment which was circulated in his name--
—I did.

—That is great, because I support that amendment. I now understand from the Chair that that is the case. I am sure that industry would not object to such penalties if public officials were also given the same incentives to perform. Everyone who is involved in business can recite a long list of errors by government officials which have cost them time and money. Often these errors are minor and understandable and do not really bring discredit on the public servants involved. But, with the efforts of businesses to complete the plethora of documentation and requirements which the Government imposes on them, it is equally clear that they should not be brought into discredit either. Minor errors should not be the subject of penalties as long as action is taken to rectify the situation on discovery of the errors. If commercial enterprises are expected to tolerate the multitude of errors by government and its agencies, then government should deal fairly with people in commerce. Surely there should be reciprocal arrangements.

SPEECH.PARA: The offending part of this Bill, and the one we seek to amend, imposes a penalty on a person who `whether knowingly, recklessly or otherwise' makes a false statement. Clearly, the term `or otherwise' is a broad catch-all which can include a multitude of very minor sins. The solution proposed by the Government to the obviously arbitrary nature of this provision is to give yet more discretion to the Comptroller. The Comptroller has the ability already under proposed new section 243u to approve an application for remission of the penalties imposed under section 243t. Additionally, allowance is made for an owner of goods to include a statement that he or she is uncertain about particular information and thereby become exempt from the penalty if that information turns out to be favourable to the granting of an exemption. These exemptions are insufficient to protect importers from being heavily penalised for inadvertent errors. For these reasons, the Opposition has proposed the deletion of the words `or otherwise' from this proposed section, so as to penalise only those who give false information `knowingly or recklessly'. The penalty for recklessly making false statements should still provide incentives against repeated errors without the inclusion of the incredibly wide term `or otherwise'. That term is so broad as to include, to give an absurd but real example, the making of false statements with one's shoelaces undone.

The Government made it clear in debate in the Senate that the purpose of this proposed new section of the Bill is to provide deterrence against underpayment of duty. It is clear from this Bill that the Government does not believe that it could prove that such underpayments are deliberate if tested in the courts. If, as has been suggested, the end to errors can really bring in another $26m of revenue-and I would be surprised if it could-if they are really errors, these penalties cannot do much to change the situation. If the shortfall does not result from mistakes, the amended clause, as proposed by the Opposition, will still be an effective measure for the Australian Customs Service to administer its responsibilities.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BARRY JONES
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government cannot accept the amendment proposed by the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer)--
—We proposed it--
—No, not quite, because the form the honourable member has put up is not the form that we discussed at an earlier stage.
—Senator Button wouldn't agree to it.

—Well, that is the honourable member's problem. This matter cannot be seen in isolation. It has to be seen as a corollary of the fast-track system, for customs clearance. It is not a matter of criminal intent. The fundamental distinction between the proposed new section to which the amendment is proposed and the previous section is that the previous section provides for criminality, where the concept of mens rea is essential. Under section 234 (a), for a person to be convicted of an offence the Australian Customs Service must have been able to prove criminal animus-that something or other was done knowingly or recklessly or that someone has made a false or misleading statement-and high penalties are prescribed.

SPEECH.PARA: The alternative approach is deliberately designed as a catch-all. Instead of going through the whole business of what would, in effect, be a trial, the intention is to try to handle such things administratively, with Customs not acting as a court and not trying to decide whether an error has been made. Thus, the only question will be: Is there an error? It will not matter whether an error is due to a lapse of memory, a bereavement in the family or something. The only question will be: Is there an error? The question of motive-the question of whether it was done deliberately, falsely, maliciously, accidentally, negligently and so on-will not really come into it. The question of penalty will be a matter to be determined by regard to the circumstances, and I would certainly hope-I am sure the honourable member for Mayo would endorse this-that, although it is a rather broad dragnet provision, it will be administered in a sensible, compassionate and balanced way. I am sure that it will be.

There are strong public policy reasons why this approach has been adopted. As I said, it is a corollary to the fast-track or green line system of processing imports under which in 90 per cent of circumstances an entry will be processed based on the information provided by the importer. But we have to recognise that there is a downside. If one says, `Accept what I have written here on its face value, and let us not go through the whole business of inspection', one cannot at the same time say, `Mind you, if I have accidentally misdescribed and there is an accidental error, I do not want to be called to account for it'.

If an importer does not want to go through the green line system and says, `Here you are. I am not absolutely certain that what I have described here is correct. The country of origin may be wrong. There may be some significant difference in it. I would like you to go through it all and check it out', then, of course, he does not get the fast-track system. The transaction will be held up, but the importer knows that there is no possibility of being caught by this provision. It is really a matter of saying, `Which way will I go?'. Does one choose the green line system with the implication that one accepts full accountability or the imposition of strict liability, or does one do it the other way, whereby one says, `No, I am not absolutely certain that what I have described is right. I want to go through it all. Inspect it; check it out'? In that case, it is the responsibility of Customs to make the decision and the importer is not held strictly accountable for anything, unless he has put something down that is deliberately, knowingly, falsely or recklessly wrong. Then that is a criminal offence. One has to see those two things as a corollary; they are inextricably linked. Even where there is an innocent mistake-the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) adverted to this-for example, the transposed decimal point, it has the effect that government revenue is reduced but it also means that the amount of protection given to Australian industry because of the presence of the tariff is reduced and that other importers competing in the same market place, who have paid the lawful amount of duty, are prejudiced.

If one went to the people who complain about this and said `All right, let's go right back to where we were before. Let's abandon this section, but at the same time, let's abandon the green line approach as well', I do not think one would get too many takers, because the answer would be `No, it suits us to have the fast-track method; it suits us to go through as quickly as we can,' and 90 per cent of them go that way. One can then say, `Okay, in that case you pay the price and the price is that you have to acknowledge the obligation to meet a test of strict liability. The honourable member for Mayo referred to what he called an honest error. In this context there is no such thing as an honest error. The only question is: Is it an error?

TALK.START.PARA: —I know, but that is what we were worried about.

—If people do not like it that way, they should not use the fast-track system. If people want us to get rid of the fast-track system perhaps we can be accommodating, but importers will not think that that is a terrific idea. I reiterate-at the risk of tedious repetition-that that is the point. If we want the fast-track system we have to take the lumps with it. If we do not want the fast-track system, we have to get our constituents and the importers to say that they do not want it and we will have another look at it. If we have the benefit of fast-track, we have to take the detriment as well. The Government rejects the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Downer Mr A.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me say, for the record, that the Opposition is not opposed to the fast-track system, or the green line system. There is no question of that. Nobody would think for a minute that we were. Customs should be looking out for people who are using that system. Customs have random checks within that system-I think I am right in saying it checks one person in 10. Customs should be trying to catch those people who frankly are knowingly and recklessly making misleading statements, not people who have made unfortunate oversights.
—But you get them under the earlier section.

—And under this section, which gives Customs the power to impose administrative penalties where there is clearly not some sort of massive criminal intent involved. I also wish to make a couple of other points. The Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones) said that he hoped the system would be administered in a fair way. I guess that confirms my concerns; it is not a matter of hope with legislation. It is a question of the Parliament saying, `It will be administered in a fair way'. This is what we define as `administered in a fair way'. I do not think we should send legislation out from this Parliament just on a wing and a prayer-in hope.

SPEECH.PARA: There was an interjection, which would have gone on record in Hansard. I want to clarify it. I said at one stage, when the Minister was talking about some discussions we had about an alternative amendment which included using the word `negligently' rather than `or otherwise', that I should have moved that amendment here and the Minister said, `That is your problem'. Actually, it is not because I know from the way the Government voted in the Senate, that the Minister, would have opposed that amendment had we moved it.
