DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT COMMITTEE ON FOREIGN AFFAIRS, DEFENCE AND TRADE

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Suspension of Standing and Sessional Orders

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Mr Barry Jones)-by leave-agreed to:

That so much of the Standing and Sessional Orders be suspended as would prevent the order of the day for the resumption of debate on the motion to take note of the report on Australia's relations with the South Pacific presented to the House earlier today by the Joint Committee of Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade to be called on forthwith.
Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bilney Mr G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Chairman of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, I have great pleasure in supporting the remarks of my colleague the honourable member for Isaacs (Mr Charles), who earlier today presented this very important report on Australia's relations with the island states of the South Pacific. The report represents more than three years work of a subcommittee of the Joint Committee, and I congratulate all 15 members of the subcommittee on their hard work, dedication and perseverence in agreeing to this unanimous and, in my opinion, very valuable report to the Parliament. It is not often realised that much of the work that is done in the Parliament is done with cooperation among members and with agreement among them on the matters that come before them. This very thick report represents just such an instance of that kind of cooperation and consensus.

SPEECH.PARA: Indeed, I am reminded of an occasion two or three weeks ago when the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade brought down a report on Australia's aid and development policies. Similarly, that policy was agreed to by all parties and it managed to get five sentences in the Advertiser newspaper in my home State. On the same day some candidate for the mayoralty complained about junketing by another candidate and that got 18 sentences and a picture on page 2. Inescapably, the conclusion is that the media pay attention only when there is some sort of suggestion that politicians are junketing or brawling; they pay very little attention to the much more constructive work which is done by most of us most of the time.

This report is a very important one. Although Australia has had a longstanding involvement in and contact with the South Pacific region, until relatively recently it has not been an active participant in regional affairs. Earlier contact was primarily for reasons of commercial exploitation or, at the other end of the scale-perhaps closely related-through the work of missionaries. There was a period of administration of a number of territories and naturally involvement in military action in both world wars.

As the report notes, until the middle of the 1970s, Australian governments tended to treat the region in a benign but rather paternalistic fashion. However, the rate of change within the region, particularly in the last 10 years or so, has brought home to Australians in a very powerful way that the Pacific is pacific no longer. Australia's changing responses to events in this rapidly evolving region are documented in the report. The Committee's report itself is a reflection of the fact that Australia is now according appropriate attention to regional matters.

I do not intend to delay the House for too long, because I know that other members of the Committee wish to speak in this debate. The honourable member for Isaacs has already highlighted a number of important areas in which the Committee makes major observation and recommendations, including political developments in the region, education and migration issues and economic development. However, I would like to highlight development assistance to the region, which has come to assume a very important part in recent times, and to indicate some of the Committee's other considerations.

In volume terms, Australia is the major aid donor to the independent South Pacific states. Indeed, about 50 per cent of the country program of the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau (AIDAB) goes to the South Pacific, in which one includes Papua New Guinea. Despite this and other substantial and increasing amounts of aid, the smaller Pacific nations remain largely economically dependent. Among the reasons for this situation, the more important factors are the natural characteristics of the smaller states-their so-called micro nature and remote locality, their limited revenue base and their high population growth rates by world standards. The report notes:

The total land area of the whole region is relatively small in proportion to the ocean in which these states are situated. Small populations, a limited revenue base, geographic remoteness and fragmentation, limited telecommunications and high transport costs have hindered the development of not only production of goods for domestic user, but also participation of these countries in the world market. Economies of scale are difficult to achieve with small, scattered populations, and many of the countries have insufficient funds from domestic revenue sources to finance the type of developments in infrastructure necessary to attract foreign investment.

Notwithstanding these factors, the Committee has concluded that to varying extents the island states' economic performance could be improved in three major areas. These areas involve improvements in and diversification of primary production, the development of tourism and the development of small scale industry. The Committee recommends that the Government promote the establishment of a South Pacific Forum agricultural diversification unit. If further recommends a more regional approach to marketing and promoting tourism with the region and specifically calls for action by AIDAB to review regional assistance in the tourism and hospitality industries.

The report examines in some detail Australia's economic relationship with the region, including trends in the relationship, the pros and cons of preferential trade agreements and the prospects of greater private sector involvement in investment in the region. It looks at regional defence and security issues, in which some of my colleagues have a particular interest. The report also analyses political developments and trends, concluding with an examination of levels of public awareness in Australia of regional conditions and issues and the impact of Australian media activities.
I could deal with a number of other issues, but I do not want to take too much time. However, I would like to conclude by quoting the last two sentences of the report:
Australia has expertise and knowledge of the region, arising from long involvement, particularly with the Melanesian countries, and should offer such expertise freely.

Australia and the region have great potential to strengthen their ties of friendship and co-operation; with goodwill and continued effort on both sides the next century should truly be the age of the Pacific.

I believe that sentiment is widely shared not just within the Committee, but also within the House. It encapsulates the tone which goes through this report. I believe the report is a most timely and significant contribution to public discussion of Australia's role in regional affairs. Again, I congratulate the honourable member for Isaacs and his colleagues on the work they have done. As the process of re-evaluation of Australian foreign policy towards the region continues, it can only be assisted by a more informed Parliament, press and public. I commend the report to the House for its contribution to that process.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to contribute to the discussion this evening of this report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, entitled Australia's Relations with the South Pacific. Like the honourable member for Kingston (Mr Bilney), who spoke before me, I am pleased to have been able to participate in the development of this report. He commended the Opposition and the parliamentarians generally for a document which deals with a great variety of issues and which does not contain dissentient views. In that spirit of bipartisanship I would like to mention two other matters, the first being the cooperation of the Government in relation to ensuring that a greater number of members than usual are able to participate in this debate by bringing the matter on again for discussion tonight, and secondly the way in which the Government cooperated readily in relation to assisting the Committee in carrying out its investigation for the preparation of this report.

SPEECH.PARA: As the honourable member for Isaacs (Mr Charles) mentioned in the debate this afternoon, this report contains a number of parts. Whilst the body of it deals with the principal terms of reference that the Committee was asked to deal with, there is an annexure which would normally be a report from a parliamentary delegation if members of parliament had travelled to the countries that are part of the South Pacific. It is a fact that over a long period only rarely have parliamentary committees been given the opportunity, in carrying out their work, to travel and to look at many of the places about which they are commenting in their report. It was my view-a view which the Government obviously shared-considering the importance of the South Pacific to Australia, that it was of fundamental importance that members of the subcommittee were able to form their views against the background of a visit to the region.

So in June and July of last year a visit was undertaken by the leader of the delegation, the honourable member for Isaacs, the honourable member for Warringah (Mr MacKellar), Senator Schacht, the honourable member for Casey (Mr Halverson), the honourable member for Cowper (Mr Nehl), the honourable member for Hindmarsh (Mr John Scott) and the honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous), and me as the member for Dundas. We visited the Solomon Islands, Tonga, Fiji, Western Samoa, Tuvalu, Kiribati, Nauru and Vanuatu. I will come back to the way in which that visit influenced, I think, the report that is before the House. It is important in looking at this report to recognise the breadth of it. I have said that the region is important to Australia and that understanding the region is fundamental to our being able to react properly to issues that might affect us. We have seen that in relation to Vanuatu and Fiji.

As has been mentioned by colleagues who have spoken earlier, we are dealing with a region that is diverse racially, historically and politically. Many of us have a romantic view of the region. In my own electorate last weekend I attended a musical comedy presentation by The Hills Musical Society of South Pacific. We have a romanticised view of the region as a result of the many writings of those who were there earlier and the way in which the area has been of such delight to many who have toured it for holidays or short vacations.

Notwithstanding that, we are now challenged by rapid political and social change that is taking place, and that makes this report particularly timely. It is because, I think, of the way in which we were unprepared for the changes that occurred in Fiji and Vanuatu that there was a desire to expedite consideration of this report. I cannot cover all the ground that the report covers, but let me note that it deals with economic issues that affect Australia, economic performance of the area itself, the constraints to development that exist, natural resource management in relation to agriculture, fishing, mining and forestry and the dangers associated with them. It deals with the importance of tourism. We deal with small business expansion and the economic prospects of the region. We deal with the trade relationship with Australia-Australian-South Pacific trade-preferential trade agreements that exist, promotional assistance and Australian investment.

We deal with the question whether economic relations ought to be pursued in a closer way through such arrangements as the Pacific Basin concept and private sector development, aid and trade questions. We deal with Australia's development assistance policies in the region, the purpose of aid, development potential and we look at Australia's aid projects. We look at the volume of aid and the development of country programs where aid has been developed on a country by country basis. We look at the collection of data, program design and selection, the role of non-government organisations. We look particularly at aid cooperation between Australia and the countries of the region, but not only the countries of the region; we also consider the other countries that wish to give aid to the South Pacific.

We look at a number of other areas, including education, communications, transportation, health, women, youth, environmental issues and the greenhouse effect in particular. Honourable members will appreciate that many of the countries we are speaking of are mere atolls which rise only several feet above sea level and they will appreciate why there is a natural concern amongst their populations as to their future in the context of this issue which we are addressing in Australia. We look at the question of migration, the many calls for change, the impact of migration on the source countries, the question of remittances, guest worker schemes and other issues that affect Australia, such as illegal immigrants and the like.

Then we canvass the political and security questions, relations with Australia and New Zealand, ANZUS, threats to the region, South Pacific defence capabilities and Australia's response to those matters, the question of whether there should be a regional peacekeeping force. We undertake an overview of the political relationship, our relationships as well as bilateral relations and the larger multilateral scene. We look at South Pacific development trends in the area of New Caledonia, the nuclear issue question, French Polynesia, involvement of other countries such as the Soviet Union, Libya, Japan and the United States of America and whether there ought to be special ways of addressing those issues.

We look at a number of other political developments, some of the law and order questions and political stability. We look at Fiji's new constitution. We look at the prospects for the future of Fiji. We look at Vanuatu and the constitutional problems that it has faced. I think honourable members will appreciate that this is a very wide-ranging report. The recommendations it contains are of importance to all Australians. I would like to take the opportunity of canvassing many of them, were there time for me to do so, but despite the Government's generosity, that time is not available. So I want to make a couple of comments only, arising from the Committee's visit to the region and for the purpose of emphasis. I do not play favourites with countries. I will not canvass them all but I want to emphasise two matters that impacted upon me.

The first matter relates to Vanuatu. We welcomed the opportunity of meeting Father Walter Lini. I was very impressed with him as a man. I was very impressed with his explanation as to the way in which Vanuatu had developed its associations with countries such as Cuba, the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics and Libya. It was particularly important to hear what he had to say about why he had led his nation in those directions. They were the countries that very early in the piece befriended and listened to Vanuatu.

TALK.START.PARA: —You did not mention Cuba.

—I mentioned Cuba. It is important to appreciate the very difficult circumstances that Vanuatu has faced of late, the way in which it has been portrayed in our press and the adverse impact that the way in which those issues have been portrayed has had upon Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Essentially, there were two incidents. The danger to individuals was not really significant in either of them, although there were some unfortunate incidents. Yet Australian tourism largely turned off as a result. Economically, the impact was significant. From the time I spent in Vanuatu I could see no substantial reason why Australians should not holiday there and why it should not be a very desirable destination. That is emphasised in this report. It is important that we emphasise, for the purposes of encouraging people to go there, the inherent safety of it as a location. I would have to say that I would be much happier for my family to be wandering the streets at night in Vanuatu than in much of Sydney, where I live and have my home.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is that Greiner Government.

—Comments like that from the honourable member for Kingston are not really called for in relation to this. Might I say that New South Wales is much safer than it was when it was led so incompetently by members of the Party to which the honourable member belongs. Having put that matter behind us, let us get on with the bipartisan treatment that I am offering to this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: The second matter relates to Nauru. Nauru has particular problems associated with perhaps its relative wealth in comparison with other countries within the region. It is making rather extravagant claims in relation to Australia as a result of the phosphate mining that took place there. I suspect that, as a result of the way in which it is making those claims, Australia has largely turned off listening to some of the other issues which Nauru would like to raise with us. What is mentioned in the report is that there is a desire, notwithstanding the question of compensation, to seek technical assistance from Australia in relation to the restoration of that island as a result of the mining activity. We ought to look positively at that. It is emphasised in the report. I hope those who read the debate and the report will do so with an eye to picking up questions of that sort and reacting positively to them. This is a very thought provoking report. It is one well worthy of conscientious reading by all members of the Parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous Dr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also want to pay tribute to everyone involved in the production of the report entitled Australia's Relations with the South Pacific. It is, as the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock) has said, a very wide-ranging, and positive report dealing with many of the problems of the South Pacific. I am pleased to be associated with it as a member of the Subcommittee and also as a member of the delegation which visited the South Pacific, with the assistance of the Government, in a special trip that was undertaken last year. I pay tribute to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) for supporting that trip. That support was very generous and important. The reception which the delegation received throughout the South Pacific was an indication of the high standing of the Australian Parliament amongst the peoples and governments of those nations.

SPEECH.PARA: We ought to do more to strengthen our relationship with the peoples and governments of the South Pacific. There is no doubt that they look to Australia for leadership, guidance and support in terms of their problems. There is much that can be done in relation to that. I want to touch on a couple of issues in relation to support of those nations. The report covers these issues quite extensively in terms of economic assistance and the problem of migration, including the guest worker program.

Let me begin with the question of migration, because it was an issue that naturally, as the chairman of the Government's immigration committee, I raised in the various discussions we had in the different countries. I am pleased to see that there is a whole chapter devoted to it in the report. It is quite clear that because of the guest worker program in New Zealand an expectation has arisen throughout the South Pacific that we ought to have in place some program which allows people from the Pacific Islands to come to Australia to work and send remittances home to their relatives in those countries, thereby assisting the population in those countries with their economic problems.

Remittances from relatives living in Australia and New Zealand are in some cases the major source of external finance for many of these countries. Without those sorts of remittances the economies of these countries in certain instances would collapse. Naturally, there was a lot of pressure on the delegation-indeed there remains pressure on the Australian Government-to do more to assist in terms of having programs similar to the one in New Zealand; that is, a program whereby people from those nations can come to Australia to work and send back remittances.

The problem is, as you would be aware, Mr Deputy Speaker, that we have no such program. We do not have guest worker programs in Australia. Because of that, many people from the Pacific Islands have tried to get into similar programs by migrating to Australia. But again, because our immigration policy is based on non-discriminatory principles, we have the situation where we have no positive discrimination in favour of peoples from the Pacific Islands. What does this mean in concrete terms? Because of the points system that applies in immigration, many of the people from the Pacific Islands who want to migrate to Australia, either temporarily or permanently, are not able to do so.

That does not mean that there is anything wrong with our non-discriminatory program, but it is impacting on them in a way which they see as unfair. They see it as discriminatory. They say, `Look, Australia is our big brother, our big neighbour. We expect Australia to assist us. One of the forms of assistance we expect from Australia is an opportunity to work there and be able to send remittances home. We have been told that to do so we have to migrate to Australia, but when we try to migrate to Australia under the official immigration program we are stopped by a tough points system which we understand is non-discriminatory around the world but which is hitting us and preventing us from being able to do what we want to do in relation to assisting our country by migrating to Australia'.

This is a complex problem. It is not one that is easily solved. Nor is it one that ought to be brushed aside because, as I say, the peoples of the South Pacific consider immigration to Australia to be probably the No. 1 issue for them in relation to assisting the domestic economies and assisting in improving the standards of living there. The report deals with these issues and tries to come up with some solutions, but it is not an easy question. At first we considered that perhaps we should exempt the whole of the Pacific and allow immigration from the Pacific to Australia. But the Government is not likely to adopt such a radical proposal. New Zealand had similar sorts of proposals in terms of quotas of people from the Pacific Islands. It found that it had to restrict the program after a period because a large number of people were coming from the Pacific Islands to New Zealand.

The Committee has suggested that one way of dealing with this problem is for the Government to consider putting into place some kind of special training program under which people from the Pacific Islands can come to Australia to work for a short period and gain training. If this were to be the case, they would be able to work and get training but they would not be in breach of our general immigration guidelines.

The second thing that we have suggested is that Kiribati and Tuvalu are exceptional cases-there is no doubt about it-because their economies are in a disastrous state. Unless we do something to assist them through our immigration program, it is not clear what will happen to them. I cannot emphasise enough how serious the situation of these two countries is. When one goes there, one cannot believe the physical circumstances in which people have to live. Essentially, those nations are built on coral. There is no earth there-just sand and coral. They have to build an infrastructure, a society and industry and work on the basis of these serious physical circumstances. In previous times when the populations were very small the circumstances might have been idyllic, but at the moment the circumstances are serious and the standards of living are very difficult for people on those islands.

I think the Government ought to take seriously the question of a special program to assist the people of those two islands. But, in broader terms, the Government must consider some kind of special relationship between Australia and the people of the Pacific Islands for the purpose of immigration. In the longer term we will have to face up to this question, and it is a question that we ought to keep under constant review. Having said that, I can assure the Parliament that the Government's immigration committee will certainly be looking into these recommendations and will be looking to discuss the outcomes with the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Robert Ray) and with the Department.

Another matter which has been raised is the economic links with the countries of the region. There are a number of suggestions as to how we can strengthen economic links. But I want to sound this warning: as we reduce tariffs in Australia the positive relationship with the Pacific in terms of the preference that is currently given to quotas and tariffs to countries of the Pacific will become less and less important. That means that the benefits for them will become less and less. So we have to think about whether we need some kind of special relationship with these countries to assist them in their economic development. I am throwing that onto the agenda. I am saying that, as a result of the reduction of the tariffs and the possibility of imports from big Third World countries, the Pacific nations will be in a difficult position. I think we have to help them, and we have to start thinking now in a bipartisan way about how we can develop policies to assist them and their economic development.

There is a section in the report which deals with each of the countries in specific terms. The honourable member for Dundas mentioned several nations but I want to emphasise one-that is, Fiji-which is somewhat dear to my heart. I am outraged and I continue to be outraged by the development of events in Fiji. I think members of this Committee from both sides of politics were outraged by the way in which the internal security decree was brought down by Colonel Rabuka, the high-handed way in which he tried to justify this decree and the methods used as a result.

TALK.START.PARA: —Brigadier Rabuka.

—As far as I am concerned, he is still Colonel Rabuka. Let me make a couple of points about the Fijian situation. Firstly, we totally reject the explanations that were put forward in terms of trying to protect the rights of the indigenous Fijian people, even though they were becoming a minority. Substantial provisions already existed in the Fijian Constitution to protect the rights of the indigenous people. The coup in Fiji had nothing to do with the protection of the rights of the indigenous people. The coup in Fiji had to do with something else entirely-namely, an entrenched group which had ruled Fiji since the time of independence. This entrenched, privileged group, which was only a section of the Fijian population, could not accept that it had made such a mess of the place that the Indian and indigenous Fijian people should combine to elect a multi-racial party to government, led by Dr Bavadra. That was the situation in Fiji.

SPEECH.PARA: That real situation has been obscured by Colonel Rabuka and his followers, who have said that the Fijian coup had something to do with protecting the rights of the indigenous Fijian population. It had nothing to do with it. The coup in Fiji was an attempt by an entrenched, privileged group that had lost a democratically held election to seize power-to reinstate whom? Surprisingly, it was to reinstate the same people who had lost power. That group did not even bother to reinstate new people; it reinstated to government the same people who had lost power. That was a disgraceful exercise of anti-democratic behaviour in our region.

Unfortunately, the people of Fiji as a whole-both the indigenous Fijian and the Indian peoples-have suffered dramatically as a result of this coup. Economic development is at a stalemate, tourism is virtually finished and people are still frightened of the actions of the military. In the period we were there, certain people were arrested by the Government, including people at the University of the South Pacific-in the case of one lecturer, for no other reason than that he had dared to write an article critical of Colonel Rabuka.

This is the situation that exists in Fiji today. We have to take action to ensure that the Government does nothing to encourage the pseudo-constitutional process that exists in Fiji at the moment, which is intended to continue the entrenched situation of Colonel Rabuka and his followers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Katter The Hon R.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I propose to speak for only a couple of minutes, for two reasons: firstly, because I had an alleged illness last year that prevented my participating in almost all of the activities of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade and, secondly, because what I propose to stress in my few words has already been dealt with by the honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous). I refer to the great necessity for our doors to be opened, not in an irresponsible and foolish way. I have attended two South Pacific conferences. I was fortunate in so far as they were both held on the mainland! My dreams of going to the Pacific islands and so on were well and truly dashed as one conference was held in Brisbane and the other in Darwin. However, they were effective.

SPEECH.PARA: People of obvious sincerity who felt they were being treated not as equals, or as a group of brothers of the Pacific, but as something less than that, made a special appeal to me and others that there should be a liberal manner but not an open door. I must not give the wrong impression; they did not expect that and would not open doors for us. They wanted a lot of the red tape which they were not anxious to cope with, or capable of coping with, set aside. If they want to come to Australia to visit relatives or to come as tourists-that would not be beyond the bounds of possibility-or for training or educational purposes, the process of doing so should be far more simple than it is now. That point was dealt with quite capably by the member for Calwell and I will not dwell on it further.

A few of us, as members of the Committee, will be in New Zealand next week and we will have a frank and forthright discussion with our counterparts there. I hope that out of those discussions will come decisions-perhaps not binding on either country-which will create common ground whereby we might examine giving such people greater self-esteem and a greater feeling of belonging to a Pacific family.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lindsay Mr E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The events of 1985 which led the Soviet Union to establish a fishing agreement with the Republic of Kiribati catapulted the South Pacific region into the arena of superpower rivalry. The South Pacific nations-micro-states-had remained rather insular before the fishing agreement was signed between the Republic of Kiribati and the Soviet Union. The signing of that agreement brought to the attention of the major nations of this region the importance of developing secure and mature foreign policies with respect to the relationship between the South Pacific micro-states, Australia, New Zealand and the United States of America.

SPEECH.PARA: When one considers the composition of these micro-states, one has to question whether they really are sovereign states. Do they have the capacity to administer their affairs on an independent basis, both economically and with regard to security? Do they have the capacity to defend themselves from external aggression? Do they have the capacity to ensure that the development of their economy can subsist without large doses of overseas aid? Failure on any of those legs raises the question of whether they can truly claim to be sovereign states.

That makes the development of Australia's foreign policy considerably difficult. Each of those sovereign micro-states has to be treated on an equal basis across the region. They have to be recognised as members of the United Nations, as indeed they are. They are entitled to be treated as sovereign countries, despite the fact that on many levels, as I see it, their would-be claims to sovereign status are deficient.

A dynamic process of political and economic change is happening now in the South Pacific. That change makes the development of Australia's foreign policy on our relationship with the micro-states of the South Pacific one of immediate priority. The South Pacific challenges Australia to develop a foreign policy which has strong bipartisan support and which recognises the fundamental, longstanding and unchanging interests that Australia has for the peace and security of the South Pacific.

It is acknowledged on both sides of the House that Australia has clear geopolitical and strategic reasons for and interests in preserving and promoting peace in the region. We have responsibilities, as the most developed country in the region, to discharge those duties of maintaining the peace. It has clearly been recognised by Papua New Guinea, Vanuatu and, as I understand it, other countries that Australia has a role to ensure that peace and security are maintained in this region.

Australia has a responsibility to develop a partnership with Pacific Island countries which promotes stability and security through economic development. It also has a responsibility to encourage, among the leadership of the South Pacific micro-states, a shared perception of strategic and security interests. It is most important that those countries are part of the ongoing development of the foreign policy issues which are essential to finding common ground between Australia and those island micro-states.

It is also important that Australia and the South Pacific micro-states share a strategy of constructive commitment. That means the promotion of a close, confident and broadly-based bilateral relationship not only between themselves, but also between Australia and each individual South Pacific micro-state. The promotion of effective regional cooperation, especially through the South Pacific Forum and other regional organisations such as the South Pacific Commission, is an important reason for the continuation of the ongoing scrutiny of Australia's foreign policy on these micro-states.

It is also important that Australia recognise that, for the Pacific Island countries, security hinges on economic and social development. It is important, therefore that Australia offer assistance to enable those countries to achieve both of those objectives. Above all, it is important that Australia have respect for the full sovereignty of all Pacific Island states in relation to their internal affairs and their right to establish diplomatic and commercial links with countries from outside the region.

In that respect I mention the activities of Vanuatu which the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock) referred to earlier. Despite what I have said about Australia's duty to treat these South Pacific states as independent, full sovereign countries, there is an established concern within Australia about the activities of Vanuatu. Vanuatu established relations with Cuba in 1983, and Libya, Nicaragua and North Korea in 1986. The establishment of relations with Libya should be the West's major strategic concern in the region after the penetration by the Soviet Union. This link between Vanuatu and Libya has given support to the Melanesian independence movement in various places in the South Pacific. This movement clearly plays a mischief-making role in Vanuatu. I believe that the Libyan interest has been motivated primarily to cause trouble-to confound the United States, and cause that country embarrassment with France with respect to the issue of French New Caledonia.

These are important matters that must concern Australia and the United States in their security policies in that area. Vanuatu has only approximately 300 paramilitary personnel to deal with issues which have led, on certain occasions, to a dramatic downturn in that country's capacity to maintain law and order. It is important also that Australia promote within the governments of the South Pacific countries acknowledgment and a shared perception of the region's strategic interests and security interests. It is important that we lay a foundation or a basis for regional approach to security situations, internal or external, which could put regional stability at risk. It is most important that Australia develop foreign policies which identify Australia as an integral part of the South Pacific region.

Australia has begun the task of shared awareness between Australia and the South Pacific nations on where the national interests of the region lie. It is important that we avoid shrill and shallow politicking on this very important issue. It is important that government not neglect the region and that the people of the South Pacific see that Australia does not neglect the region. The report that has been prepared is a constructive and detailed attempt by this Parliament to ensure that the issues of the South Pacific are before the people of Australia and are to the forefront in consideration by the Federal Government.

I simply want to comment on a few of the recommendations that have been made in the report which I believe are worthy of immediate implementation. The first concerns the training and funding of on the job experience for regional trade promotion officers and also the involvement of the private sector in such trade promotion training. The honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous) mentioned some of the economic difficulties that have been experienced by the South Pacific micro-states. I urge the Parliament to implement that recommendation contained in the report because unless the private sector is involved in trade promotion, and unless there is training and funding for on the job experience for regional trade promotion, none of the South Pacific micro-states will be equipped to deal with the economic reconstruction that they so desperately need.

I believe that the recommendation supporting the efforts of the Pacific Islands Association of Chambers of Commerce to provide a more coordinated approach to private sector development in the region is one that should be promoted by the Government as quickly as possible. I know-and I know that many of the people in the South Pacific believe-that the promotion of private sector development by them is fundamentally important to the diversification of their economy and also removing them from the aid dependency, which would be one of the tragic developments of the Pacific micro-states.

It is also important that the level of literacy and education be raised in many of these countries. I commend the recommendation that the Australian teacher volunteer program, whereby Australian teachers would undertake a one or two-year posting to a South Pacific country, should be implemented. I think that is an extremely important recommendation not only to develop awareness amongst Australians of the importance of relationships with South Pacific countries, but also to ensure that the literacy and education of these countries are catapulted to a very high level.

With the other speakers, I commend this report to the Parliament. I enjoin the Government to act on the recommendations contained in the report. I know that Australia's relations with the South Pacific will be brought up in this Parliament again and again. It is important that that be so. As I said earlier, Australia has a responsibility to maintain the peace in this region. It cannot resile from that obligation. I know that this can be effectively maintained not by Australia acting unilaterally on these issues, but rather by the shared acceptance of responsibility to ensure economic development and regional security not only by Australia but by the nations of the South Pacific.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nehl Mr G.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must say that I speak on this occasion with a great deal of pleasure because I believe that the report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade on Australia's relations with the South Pacific is very valuable and far reaching and is of great importance not only to Australia but, indeed, to the whole Pacific Rim.

SPEECH.PARA: I pay tribute to the hospitality of the governments and the people of the island states the Committee visited last June. It was certainly a tremendous illustration of how the people of Australia and the people of the island states can really get on well together. I also compliment the Committee staff, particularly Joanne Towner, on the way the inquiry was conducted and on the preparation of the report. I also pay tribute to Miss Karina Campbell of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade for the assistance she gave members of the Committee who made the visit to the Pacific nations last June.

There are a number of issues I would like to raise only briefly because time is rapidly running out for this debate. The first is the question of tourism. There is obviously a great potential for tourism in the island states. They are natural areas of great beauty and great friendship. If they are going to develop tourism, they will need a great deal of assistance for the infrastructure. An influx of tourists to a coral atoll cannot be sustained without appropriate provision of water and sewerage. The Pacific is an incredibly large area with a vast amount of water and very limited land. Transport is one major problem affecting the people of the South Pacific. If Australia is able to be of assistance to the Pacific island nations it should be considering giving a great deal of assistance in areas such as transport and communications. Wherever we went among the island states questions of migration and guest worker status were raised. Although we all in a bipartisan fashion agreed that there should be no discrimination in Australia's migrant intake, if we are ever going to bend, it should perhaps be in line with providing a little bias towards our Pacific island neighbours.

For once I agree with the honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophonous)-it does not happen very often-when he speaks about the problems that will be encountered when our tariff reductions come into effect and the special provisions for the island states disappear. I think there is a great need for a special economic relationship with the Pacific island states and we should start thinking about that now.

If one were to isolate the most important matter, from the vast range of matters covered by the report and the inquiry it would be education. The people in the island states really need a great deal more in the way of education. They need more teachers, more textbooks, higher standards and a much wider availability of education. It is just not good enough to build a school; we have to think about the recurrent costs involved because they can be a major problem for the people of those countries.

I particularly endorse the recommendation in the report that there should be a secondary school student exchange scheme and that particular attention should be paid to the development of curricula related to Australia and the South Pacific. Australia has a special relationship with the Pacific, but, above all, we must never be paternal and we must never adopt the role of big brother; nonetheless, we have to agree that we have a responsibility and we must always maintain a relationship of one family. If we can treat the people of the South Pacific as our family, and if they can treat us that way, it will work to the benefit of all of us. It is our family; it is our region. We have to understand the Pacific way and we hope that they will understand our ways, because we need each other. Australia has a great future, as do the Pacific nations, provided we go on working together for our mutual benefit.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: TRADE PRACTICES (INTERNATIONAL LINER CARGO SHIPPING) AMENDMENT BILL 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 12 April, on motion by Mr Willis:
That the Bill be now read a second time.
upon which Mr Blunt had moved by way of amendment:

That all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words: `whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House regrets the fact that the Government has failed to achieve micro-economic reform in the transport sector, a matter of such vital importance to the Australian economy'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I remind the House that the purpose of the Trade Practices (International Liner Cargo Shipping) Amendment Bill, which I must say has not received a great deal of attention in the second reading debate, essentially is to increase the efficiency of the international shipping industry by substantially reducing the protection from competition provided to the international shipping conferences or cartels. This is to be achieved by limiting the current wide-ranging exemption from the Trade Practices Act that is allowed to the international shipping conferences. These shipping conferences carry the vast majority of our non-bulk exports; so providing for more competition in this area should materially assist our exporters. This is, therefore, clearly a notable step in micro-economic reform and so adds to the substantial list of micro-economic reforms that this Government has already introduced or has in train.

SPEECH.PARA: In this debate Opposition speakers have alleged that the Government has done little about micro-economic reform. This is a massive untruth. This Government has set in train a vast program of micro-economic reform of which the Bill now before the House is a part. I would like to take the House through a list of micro-economic reforms which have been undertaken or which are being undertaken in the transport and communications area. We have acted to put government business enterprises (GBEs) on a much more commercial footing. The Government's role has been changed from one of detailed regulation and control of their activities on a day-to-day basis and in various other highly regulatory ways, which was the way in which they were operated by the previous Government, to a more removed process in which the Government sets the charter and the functions of the organisation, establishes a corporate plan, financial targets, any clearly established community service obligations and then essentially sends the enterprise off to run as a normal commercial business enterprise.

This is a very substantial reform which affects some major enterprises in this country. We are talking about such enterprises as Telecom Australia, the largest enterprise in the country, Australia Post, the Overseas Telecommunications Commission (OTC), Australian Airlines, Aussat, Qantas Airways Ltd, Australian National Line (ANL) and Australian National Railways (AN). To come we have reform packages for the Federal Airports Corporation and the Civil Aviation Authority. All of these bodies are being set on a commercial footing. They are being separated from the government in the sense of day-to-day controls. They are being made as much of a commercial enterprise as is possible to make them whilst they remain government-owned, and bearing in mind the community service obligations which at least some of these enterprises have to provide.

That GBE reform, which is very substantially on the way, is a major exercise in micro-economic reform. In addition, particular industry level reforms have been undertaken. We have deregulated domestic aviation from October 1990; we had to give three years notice, as honourable members know. That means that from October next year we will have a much more competitive domestic aviation industry. This industry has been highly regulated all through the long years of Liberal and National Party Government, through the 1950s, the 1960s and the seven Fraser Government years. The act of deregulation has been taken by this Government.

We have taken major decisions to improve the infrastructure for the aviation industry, the most notable of which is the decision to proceed with the third runway at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport. In addition and less well known are the steps taken to develop major international terminals. At Sydney Airport there has already been a $40m expansion, with a $240m expansion to come. At Brisbane Airport there has been a small improvement to the existing highly inadequate terminal. Expressions of interest have already been called for the development of a whole new international terminal at Brisbane. A $117m expansion of the international terminal at Melbourne Airport has been announced. In Darwin there is to be a $65m development of virtually a whole new civil aviation infrastructure. There will be $20m spent on Alice Springs Airport. Obviously, a massive amount of expenditure is involved in the development and improvement of aviation infrastructure at that small handful of airports.

We have instituted a program of aviation cost recovery which aims to ensure that operators pay substantial contributions to the cost of providing the infrastructure for their industry and to ensure a rational allocation of resources in this area, a major step in rational resource allocation. We have established a trend setting process of award restructuring in the coastal shipping industry through the Maritime Industry Development Committee which was established by my predecessor-one removed-as Minister for Transport, the honourable member for Shortland (Mr Peter Morris). That led to a reduction of crew numbers, multiskilling of the seagoing work force and increased efficiency in operations. We have now further reviewed the industry to achieve greater efficiency through the coastal shipping task force which will be reporting to the Government shortly. I am confident that that will provide the basis for further sweeping changes in the industry and substantial increases in efficiency. ANL has also been revitalised. When we came to office ANL was virtually bankrupt. It has been changed to a profit-making, taxpaying enterprise.

We have initiated a series of studies and inquiries to bring about reform of the waterfront culminating in the Inter-State Commission's (ISC) report on the waterfront released last week. Contrary to what Opposition speakers have been saying, totally incorrectly, in this debate, there has been no rejection of the ISC report by the Waterside Workers Federation or the Australian Council of Trade Unions. It is totally untrue to say, as was said by the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt) and another Opposition speaker, that the report had been rejected by those union bodies. They have been critical of a couple of the recommendations but they have not criticised the report as a whole. They have not rejected or criticised the great majority of its recommendations. I believe that we now have the prospect of achieving major restructuring of this important industry.

We have dramatically improved the efficiency of the Australian National Railways. We have reduced by 60 per cent the $100m per annum deficit which was being incurred by AN before we came to office, a mammoth reduction brought about by increasing the efficiency of that organisation. In relation to the road transport industry we have introduced for the first time in the history of the nation a regime of national uniform vehicle weights and speed limits for interstate trucks and so greatly assisted in improving the efficiency of the interstate road transport industry.

We have introduced a package of reforms aimed at deregulating the telecommunications industry in several important areas, thus providing competition and increased efficiency. We have introduced legislation today which sets a price-capping formula for Telecom and OTC which ensures continual annual declines in the real level of prices for their basic services.

This is a very quick summation of major micro-economic reforms in the transport and communications area which have been or which are being achieved by the Hawke Government. Yet the Opposition says that little is being done. Is this really little? It is infinitely more than was achieved by the Fraser Government or in the decades of Liberal and Country Party government through the 1950s and 1960s. Major structural reforms have been achieved and are being achieved in the transport and communications area. The Bill now before the House is another step in that very commendable program of major structural reform of the nation.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Before I put the question, I mention that the noise in the chamber is not an aeroplane descending upon us; it is the air conditioning unit, which is out of order at the moment. It is being investigated.

INTERJECT.PARA: Amendment negatived.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Clause 4, page 3, line 7, omit ``an incorporated association'', substitute ``a body corporate''.
(2) Clause 4, page 3, after the proposed definition of ``authorised officer'', insert the following definition:

`` `conference' means an unincorporated association of 2 or more ocean carriers carrying on 2 or more businesses each of which includes, or is proposed to include, the provision of liner cargo shipping services;''.
(3) Clause 4, page 6, lines 13 to 16, omit proposed subsection (1), substitute the following subsection:

``(1) For the purposes of section 46, if the parties to a conference agreement together have a substantial degree of power in a market in which any party to the agreement provides international liner cargo shipping services under the agreement, each party to the conference agreement shall be taken to have a substantial degree of power in the market.''.
(4) Clause 4, page 41, at the end of proposed section 10.90, add the following subsection:
``(2) The regulations shall not fix fees exceeding:
(a) in the case of an application for provisional registration of a conference agreement-$300;
(b) in the case of an application for final registration of a conference agreement-$175;
(c) in the case of an application for the registration of a person as an ocean carrier's agent-$20; and
(d) in the case of an application to obtain a copy of, the whole or any part of, an entry in a register kept under this Part or a conference agreement file kept under this Part-$40.''.

In putting forward these amendments, the Government is responding to comments on the Trade Practices (International Liner Cargo Shipping) Amendment Bill made by ocean carriers, Australian shippers and the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. The amendments are technical in nature and do not alter the thrust of the Government's policy to create a more competitive liner shipping environment. The definition of `association' is being broadened to enable shipper organisations, such as statutory marketing authorities, to apply in their own right to become designated shipper bodies. As I indicated in my second reading speech, designated shipper bodies will receive the necessary exemption from part IV of the Trade Practices Act to negotiate and enter into loyalty agreements with ocean carriers. In certain circumstances-which I explained in that speech-designated shipper bodies will also be empowered to negotiate minimum service levels with conference operators and to negotiate over arrangements for, and the terms and conditions of, carriage in Australia's export liner trades. The Government accepts the suggestion made by the ocean carriers that it would be helpful, particularly to people not involved in the liner shipping industry, to include a definition of `conference' in the Bill. This will help clarify the application of the legislation and complement the term `conference agreement', which is already defined in the Bill.

The amendment to apply section 46, `Misuse of market power', to conferences reflects the different organisational structure between conferences and corporations but avoids the possibility that collectively conference members are treated differently from corporations in the determination of a substantial degree of market power. Conferences operate as cartels, and the market power is derived from exemptions from restrictive trade practices regulations to permit collusion among parties to the conference agreement. Therefore, the test of market power must apply to the collective, not the individual, market power of the parties to the conference agreement. The provision ensures that, if parties to a conference agreement are found collectively to have a substantial degree of market power, then each party is deemed to have a substantial degree of power in the market by virtue of its membership of the cartel.

Finally, an upper limit is being included in the Bill on the fees which can be charged for the registration of carrier agents and conference agreements and the provision of documents in response to public inquiries. The actual fees to apply will be prescribed by regulation and will reflect the recovery of relevant administrative costs incurred by the Department of Transport and Communications. I ask that the amendments circulated in my name be adopted.
Amendments agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.
Bill reported with amendments; report-by leave-adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill (on motion by Mr Willis)-by leave-read a third time.

DEBATE.TITLE: SNOWY MOUNTAINS ENGINEERING CORPORATION (CONVERSION INTO PUBLIC COMPANY) BILL 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 5 April, on motion by Mr Barry Jones:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —This debate, concerning the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation (SMEC), holds a great deal of interest for the Opposition because it is one of the nominated companies on the list for privatisation. I am fascinated by the approach the Government has taken to the Corporation in this move. Just a while ago the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Willis) went to some pains to talk about the new reforms. As a consequence of those things, I am flattered to understand that this is a major example of the review of micro-economic reform. What a task! Let us take a look at exactly what has been going on.

SPEECH.PARA: The Snowy Mountain Engineering Corporation was established in 1970 as an independent consulting engineering organisation to retain and promote engineering skills required during the investigation, design and construction of the Snowy Mountains scheme. The Corporation is a government business which pays all the Federal, State and local government taxes and provides services to government and private organisations in Australia and overseas. The Corporation was established under the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation Act of 1970. In 1986 the Corporation adopted a strategic corporate plan, which stated its commitment to:
. . . undertaking engineering projects on a commercial basis in Australia and overseas in a manner that maximised its profit, enhanced its reputation and provided job satisfaction.

I have quoted at some length because I will later go into the balance sheet of the Snowy Mountains authority to illustrate what is going on. In light of this Corporation objective, it is imperative that we now review whether the Snowy Mountains authority can still adhere to its goals under government ownership. The major provisions of the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation (Conversion into Public Company) Bill are as follows: Firstly, the Bill establishes the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation as a company registered under the Companies Act. The Commonwealth will own all share capital in the company, but will withdraw from day to day control of the operations and remove certain statutory controls. The proposals has no financial impact. So the Government has gone quite a way; it has really done something in micro-economic reform!

I will now deal with the process. Step 1 of the process involves the creation of share capital and the application by SMEC for registration as a company-big deal! Step 2 involves the repeal of certain sections of the SMEC Act of 1970. Step 3 involves the transition of SMEC to a public company. Consequently, statutory control of SMEC will be removed by the repeal of most of the provisions of the existing Act. Step 4 ensures that SMEC maintains its legal personality at all times.

The Bill also provides that each staff member of the corporation will become an employee of the company on the same terms and conditions. All entitlements will be preserved. The name of the company will be the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation. The amount of the paid up share capital will be fixed at $5,207,870, which represents the capital contribution by the Commonwealth as at 30 June 1988, less losses. So we have written off the losses. The capital will be divided into $1 shares. Really, as the Minister for Transport and Communications walks out of the chamber, we are talking about a major step in micro-economic reform! It is really quite laughable when one thinks of it.

Mechanisms will also be set in place for strategic oversight by the Government of the new company's activities. So the Government feels it cannot let it go too far; it must make quite sure that the Corporation does what it wants. That is always a great way to make a profit! These mechanisms will also ensure that the company operates within the wages and industrial relations policies of the Government. They have gone so well; I am sure that the Corporation will love to know that! The existing Board of Directors will continue unchanged, and the Commonwealth, as shareholder, will have the power to appoint and dismiss the directors. That is a major step in economic reform. We are really going places! Although the controls on individual borrowing requirements, investments and banking arrangements will be removed, SMEC will remain subject to the Loan Council global borrowing limits. In other words, it will not be able to do too much borrowing. It will also be liable for the Commonwealth borrowing levy on any borrowings. In other words, it will have to pay that one half of one per cent if it uses government guarantees. It will, however, forgo all forms of government guarantees. That is some inconsistency!

While the second reading speech alludes to the possible future sale of some of the equity to employees of the company, it states only that the scheme is currently being considered and will not be introduced without prior consultation with and agreement of SMEC's staff and unions. Whacko! We are really going places in micro-economic reform. We are really going some steps down the track.

Consideration of the recent performance of the Corporation may help us understand why we are going at such a pace to sell it. SMEC has struggled financially for a number of years. Since 1985, revenue has dropped each year. It has had poor profit results and accumulated losses have needed to be funded by constant capital injections. For example, it received $6m in 1986-87 and $2m in 1987-88. I referred before to the fact that the paid up capital was a strange amount and that was the amount of the losses that were written off; that was what was left of all the money that has gone into the Corporation. I will come later to an analysis of the balance sheets.

Personnel numbers have been pruned back. Revenue per employee, however, has remained stagnant. This is quite a company. Return on equity in profits on sales only just reached positive figures, still well below the private sector performance. The current ratio, however, is very strong. It should be noted that SMEC is a consulting firm and, as such, its balance sheet displays some abnormal features. For example, the number of consulting assignments or projects drives the balance sheet. In this type of business there is usually no need to seek large ticket finance as the clients involved in the construction are responsible for raising the funds. Accordingly, SMEC liabilities and assets fluctuate according to the number of projects on its books. Revenue is largely derived from fees for professional services, while expenses reflect the costs associated with giving that particular advice. As the international market for consulting engineers seems very competitive, there would seem little scope to lift revenue through raising professional fees. Greater profitability will follow only if expenses can be further reduced. From the outside, more attention needs to be given to this aspect. I emphasise `from the outside' because from government statements on its corporate affairs, we never know exactly what is going on within these companies. I challenge anyone here to pick up a balance sheet, statement of assets and liabilities or statement of income flow of a government corporation or authority and try to ascertain from that the true position in a commercial sense. I will come to that with respect to this company later. There is a need to look for the inside.

It should be stressed that a large proportion of these expenses are a direct result of government ownership, including the required annual contribution of almost $1m to the Commonwealth superannuation scheme. All the same SMEC would not have survived in recent years without continual government payments to finance its accumulated losses. SMEC will never be commercially viable in its present form. It now requires a commitment to pruning back expenses; it needs to be released from the restrictions and costs associated with government ownership; it also needs the equity injection from its employees, as the proprietors who run the business are the only group with sufficient commitment to make it profitable. I just make those comments because it is most important that the House understand some of the problems associated with the Corporation.

I move on to look quickly at the annual report of the company in the last few years. The 1985-86 annual report showed a 42 per cent decrease in revenue, leading to a loss of $3.7m. It also showed the setting up of an external board of directors and the adoption of a three-year corporate plan. We heard from the Minister that this is one of the new remedies of the Government. He said the Government must bring about a new corporate plan; that it had done all these things to modernise such companies and that these reforms will lead us on to great things. Let us see what happened. The staff was reduced from 358 to 329. Seventy per cent of revenue was derived from overseas. Management believed its inability to put together financial packages for clients restricted its competitiveness. There have been declining work opportunities in Australia. SMEC was ranked 58 out of 200 top consulting firms in the world, yet was required to contribute at the same time almost $1m towards the Commonwealth superannuation scheme. In that particular year revenue was $64m, expenditure $66.9m, and the operating loss before tax was $3.7m. The capital position in that particular year was that SMEC received from the Commonwealth $8.6m. Its accumulated losses were $4.8m and it therefore had a remnant of $3.8m. Its total liabilities were $15m and its total assets $19m. Its revenue per employee was $180,000. Its return on equity was minus 100 per cent. That was an appalling performance.

We will see what happened in 1986 with this new corporate plan. Revenue was $37m; expenditure, $40m; and the operating loss before tax, $2.4m. The accumulated losses at that stage went up to $6.6m, leaving a carried forward capital of $2m, with liabilities climbing to $17.5m and total assets marginally improving to $19.5m. A quick look at what occurred in that year showed that revenues declined by 25 per cent over the previous year. The loss for the year was $2.4m, and to maintain the working capital, the Government injected $6m. There were further staff reductions, as the Government aimed to achieve a core staff. Seventy-five per cent of revenue was derived from overseas. So the story goes on.

In 1987 revenue again dropped to $27m; expenditure was $31m which, while a decline, was still significant; there was a loss of almost $6m. As a consequence of that, in that year we had to see what we could manage to carry forward for the future.

In 1988 revenue was down again, at $26.8m; expenditure was down to $26.9m, giving the Corporation a small marginal profit for the year. The notes that accompanied the 1987-88 annual report showed that a further $2m was made available from the Commonwealth for the deficiencies in working capital. Some of the prospects for major civil works in Australia in which SMEC could participate include the very fast train project and the Tully Hydropower Project in Queensland. The report also notes a far more professional staff. So the problems continue. We have come to a stage now where enlightenment hits the Government, which has decided it must do something about privatising the Corporation.

With great skill, the Government has avoided saying in the Bill what it proposes to do. But I will let the Government into a few secrets, because a truck that drove past dropped off a plan. What is envisaged under the scheme we are arranging? I will briefly outline what is proposed. The employees will be offered redeemable preference shares. Big deal! The Government is really going to do something about giving the employees a great hit! If the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation is to have any future, it will be governed by the ability of the staff and management to take over the Corporation. Then they will have the incentive to do something and to make the commitment necessary to this organisation to make it work. If one made an analysis of the balance sheet and asked, `What are we going to do with this?' One would have to come to the conclusion that it should be either shut down or made profitable. Members of the Opposition are determined that when we come to government this corporation will be sold and the first placement of shares will be among the employees and management of the firm. If they cannot make a go of it, there is no reason why the taxpayers of Australia should be called upon annually to contribute millions of dollars to keep going a consulting engineering company when there are hundreds of them in Australia that can do exactly the same job.

I go back to my proposition. Under the guise of this great micro-economic reform the Government is going to offer these employees some redeemable preference shares in order not to upset the left wing of the Australian Labor Party, but the employees are only to be allowed to have 20 per cent of the company. One cannot say too much. That is really quite enough of it. The minimum subscription would be not less than 15 per cent. On top of that, there would be a limit on the holding of each employee, related to a mixture derived from the period of service and salary level of each employee. How extraordinary. In most professional businesses of which I am aware salary levels are generally based on performance, particularly in private enterprise service industries, be they engineering, accounting or legal. All staff are paid some base figure and, as the corporation expands and does well, the profits are shared. The Government's proposal is a rather quaint way of going about allocating capital benefits in that regard.

There is no point in a government continuing to run a loss-making consulting engineering business in which it proposes to offer an insignificant shareholding to some of the employees and retain a vast contributing and controlling interest. This is particularly so if the shares issued to employees are to be redeemable preferences in which capital growth or future capital benefits generally do not accrue. Because of those factors alone, the prospect of the employees themselves becoming involved in the management of the company are slim and lack of interest will probably set in. I cannot be very enthusiastic about the Government's proposals.

The approach of the coalition to this matter is straightforward. It was outlined as early as 1987 in the housing construction policy and further put forward in a variety of statements on privatisation. We propose to convert SMEC to a private consulting firm and to give SMEC's management and staff first option to purchase the corporation outright. The objective is to have SMEC employees own and run the corporation as a private consulting company. The coalition is well down the track in the framework of such a buy-out. The advantages of employee share ownership of SMEC include improved employee motivation where commercial success of the organisation has a direct effect on the employee. This new order fosters productivity and efficiency gains and leads to a better climate for industrial relations.

The success of any management buy-out or employee share ownership scheme would rest on successful negotiation, with an acceptance by the management and unions before its implementation. The coalition proposals would involve the Commonwealth quitting the lot, not maintaining the majority control or owning all the ordinary shares and selling some number of redeemable preference shares to the employees, which would be no use whatever to them. The balance not taken up by the employees in such a float could well be offered outside to other consulting firms or to other employees or participants. Employee participation would have to succeed to a reasonable degree in terms of percentage of the scheme if the total buy-out is to be successful. The scheme would have to be totally non-discriminatory. Shares would be offered to the remaining employees upon leaving employment. It is possible in the early stages of such a scheme, in order to encourage the employment and development of the corporation, to give some incentive to employees to hold on to these shares while they remain with the corporation. These corporations which compete completely in the private sector, which are loss-making and call upon the taxpayers of Australia fairly regularly to replenish their funds, have no place in a competitive economy. They do not serve the national interest. They do not meet a professional judgment in terms of their worth. If they did, they would be making a profit. They do not meet any of the requirements of government. If they did, the Government ought to pay a fee to the organisation for the services that it performs. Having failed that test, the SMEC should be sold in total to its employees or to the public. I move:
That all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

`whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House is of the opinion that the Government should sell the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation to the private sector, with the first option to purchase being given to the Corporation's employees'.
