SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pratt Mr M.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday and today were historic days economically, with the debate on the Appropriation Bill and April statement, predictable as it was, of the Treasurer (Mr Keating). There is no doubt that families, the elderly and wage earners have suffered too long and will welcome the long-promised tax cuts that colleagues on both sides of this House have lobbied for. Unfortunate, and just as predictable, is the certainty that any benefits will soon be devoured by high interest rates and galloping inflation.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to speak about something that is seasonal rather than seasonally adjusted. It is an industry that started in 1897, is 92 years old, and cranks up again in Adelaide this Saturday, 15 April. On that afternoon, Mr Max Basheer and Mr Leigh Whicker, the executives of the South Australia National Football League (SANFL) will oversee the kick-off of the 1989 South Australian Aussie rules football season. On the eve of this social, cultural and economic event, I more than ever pay tribute to the executives, club directors and advisers who, through their wisdom, have continued to resist those modern-day pirates, the Victorian Football League (VFL).

I have spoken in this House before about the national league, which is nothing more than an expanded VFL competition with accrued losses spread around Australia of millions of dollars. It must be very reassuring to Messrs Hawke and Keating to learn that they are not the only ones who cannot balance the books. However for us to follow a national path in South Australia the very fibre and infrastructure of suburban football would be at risk and the flow chart shows a base from schools, country amateur and SAFA through to the league. The football industry supports employment, manufacturing, hospitality, food and beverage small business, finance, advertising, the media, clothing apparel and merchandising and provides a social exchange for millions of South Australians each year.

Aussie rules in South Australia underpins this industry and represents a financial turnover of $70m plus a year. No wonder the pirates and pillagers from the VFL want to absorb us into its competition. It has already abducted our best players for years at the expense of its own suburban and country competition. It has neglected its own players. These takeover merchants want to convince us to join them but for that privilege we have to pay them $2m. It is called `takeover in reverse'. The results of this plundering in other States speaks for itself. The VFL has the Brisbane Bears and the Sydney Swans. We now find that the once proud and strong Western Australian Football League is bereft of any credibility and we find the glamorous West Coast Eagles in $7m debt. Last Friday night, last year's premier teams in the South Australian competition, Port Adelaide and Glenelg, drew a crowd of 31,000 people. At the same time, in Perth, Subiaco and Claremont, last year's grand finalists, drew 5,000 people. That is an indictment of what the VFL has done.

I have a vested interest in the health and well being of the South Australian football industry. Before my election as the Federal member for Adelaide, I was employed by the world famous Red Legs, the Norwood Football Club, as the senior marketing executive working for and with young men and women and travelling the length and breadth of the State promoting South Australia. Now that I am working actively in my electorate for all grades of football, the wise decision to resist the VFL is fully reinforced. Several months ago, a mutual agreement was reached with Adelaide radio station 5DN which has employed me as its `around the ground' football commentator. This Saturday will see me joining its expert sporting panel headed by Ken (G.G.) Cunningham, Ray Fewings, David Hookes, Gary Bau, Andrew Pearce, David Wildy and Jenny Williams. I am proud to be part of the South Australian National Football League season and to start off at the historic and beautiful Adelaide Oval for the South Adelaide versus West Torrens clash.

Unfortunately, my speech must now be tempered with a negative point. A constituent of mine from Hampstead Gardens rang me to say that he had recently been approached by the Australian Labor Party candidate who was quick to point out that I, the elected member, would not be around much as I would be at the footy every Saturday afternoon. This cynical and cheap attack was an attempt to discredit my work in the community. What the candidate did not divulge to my constituent was that for the last twelve months I have not been in my electorate office for two hours every Friday either. Instead I have been selling badges for the charity of the day at that well known landmark in the Beehive Corner in Adelaide's Rundle Mall.

In keeping with this, my handshake deal with the management of Radio 5DN included an agreement that the fee for my football commentary would be donated to charity. My constituents and members of this House would be aware that I convened a drug forum in my electorate last year and uncovered a strong community law and order desire to fight against drugs. In keeping with this finding, I was happy to endorse the National Nine Australia-wide television appeal to aid the Learning for Life programs. I believe it is appropriate that the two charities will benefit from my work.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerr Mr D. J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the attention of honourable members to two recent events in the sorry history of public administration of the State of Tasmania by the Gray Liberal Government. The first of these events relates to an application to the Tasmanian Development Authority (TDA) from a Mr Michael Tatlow to obtain a mining licence to develop a peat moss company. Honourable members should be aware that the responsibility for the Tasmanian Development Authority rests directly with the Premier of Tasmania, Mr Robin Gray.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Tatlow's attempt to develop this enterprise was ultimately unsuccessful and I understand that he may now be seeking substantial compensation from the Tasmanian Government for loss of earnings suffered as a result of the mishandling of his application by the TDA. I also understand that Mr Tatlow has incurred considerable financial hardship to the extent of losing his family home in defending himself during legal proceedings brought against him by the Gray Government. All charges against Mr Tatlow have been dismissed.

This case is the subject of considerable and continuing controversy in Tasmania. Of particular note are the serious allegations that a Sydney based company had paid large bribes to the then head of the Tasmanian Premiers Department, Mr Andrew Tilt, and the then Chairman of the Tasmanian Development Authority, Mr James Rickard, in order to obtain the peat moss concession sought by Mr Tatlow at some $5m less than its apparent market value. Mr Rickard subsequently left his position as Chairman of the TDA following an inquiry into this affair which indicated substantial mismanagement by the TDA to the ultimate detriment of the people of Tasmania. It is significant that Mr Andrew Tilt has also left his position of Head of the Tasmanian Premiers Department amidst much speculation that he was synonymous with the centre of power in that State.

The second event I refer to, which occurred at much the same time, relates to the forced sale of the King Island Dairies Pty Ltd, to a company which is alleged to have claimed close connections with the former head of the Tasmanian Premiers Department, Mr Tilt. Honourable members may be aware of the remarkable transformation that has occurred in the King Island dairy enterprise in recent years due to the considerable entrepreneurial talents of the former directors, Bill and Robin Kirk. King Island cheeses are now much sought after in Australian and overseas markets.

In what must be a remarkable parallel to the affair to which I have just referred I understand that the Kirk family is also seeking compensation from the Tasmanian Government for losses it has suffered due to the actions of the Premiers Department and the TDA. I also understand that the Kirk family has been subject to legal action by the Premier, Mr Robin Gray, in order to suppress public discussion of the facts of this very similar case.

Serious allegations have been made to the effect that the sale of the King Island dairy was made as a result of a political decision and that the purchasing company acquired this prize at considerably less than its true market value, after being invited to tender by the former head of the Tasmanian Premiers Department at a time when the business had begun to realise significant profits.

It is clear from the circumstances of these cases that negotiations by the Tasmanian Premiers Department and the Tasmanian Development Authority for the furtherance of these enterprises have not been undertaken at arm's length, nor with the public interest in mind. Contrary to the intended purpose of a body such as the TDA, the obvious effect of actions taken by the executive government in Tasmania has been to deny the entrepreneurs in these enterprises rights of natural justice.

I believe that these cases give rise to a strong and compelling suspicion the Tasmanian Liberal Government used its executive powers, through the Tasmanian Development Authority where necessary, not only to deny entrepreneurs the legitimate rewards flowing from their efforts but to also strip them of accumulated assets for disposal to those with whom it finds favour. I condemn the Gray Government for the serious loss of confidence in government instrumentalities that these actions have produced. I believe that this situation demands an open and fully independent inquiry into the nature of the Tasmanian Government's handling of its affairs with the business community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —This week I have students visiting Canberra from my electorate who are here to see at first hand how the Parliament of Australia works and to see the new Parliament House and some of the sights of the national capital. They are Jocelyn Woods from Koorda, who attends the Wyalkatchem District High School as a year 11 student, and Jeremy Fisher from Geraldton, who attends the John Willcock Senior High School as a Year 12 student, and both are in the Speakers gallery tonight.

SPEECH.PARA: This is the thirteenth time and they are the twenty-fifth and twenty-sixth students that I have brought to Canberra since first introducing the scholarship scheme several years ago. I wish to thank Australian Airlines for its assistance this week. Jocelyn and Jeremy have prepared this speech which I am delivering in the Parliament tonight and Jocelyn has typed these speech notes. I welcome them to Canberra and the Australian Parliament.

Koorda and Wyalkatchem are rural centres in my electorate and that region, with a population of approximately 1,200, is a major wheat-sheep growing area although other livestock and grain are also produced. Geraldton is a large rural-urban centre with a regional population of approximately 25,000 people and is a major port for the export of primary produce. It is also a major fishing boat harbour and the centre of Western Australia's crayfishing industry. Koorda has the usual businesses associated with a small town, such as banks and shops, plus a State Energy Commission depot, a Co-operative Bulk Handling Ltd district office and a line terminal for Westrail wool transfer.

The youth of Koorda are trying to establish a club for entertainment purposes and are also active in the sporting and social entertainment fields. The secondary education facilities for Koorda students are situated in Wyalkatchem, 48 kilometres south of Koorda. Some students attend boarding schools in Perth. Wyalkatchem District High School, although being small, achieves many things competitively and educationally. It has 87 students in the high school. The Principal of Wyalkatchem is Mr Don Boyd and there are 12 teachers in the high school who teach lower and senior grades, sometimes teaching two to three subjects under the unit curriculum as well as tertiary entrance examination subjects. A student council, of which Jocelyn is a member, is active in the school. The student council is there to stress the students' views on different things that happen at school and also to raise money for camps and excursions. The school also has many sporting facilities and its own farm, where interested students learn to do everything that would be done in operating a farm. Medically, in Koorda, there is a first-aid post where a doctor visits twice a week. The hospital, like the high school, is situated 48 kilometres away in Wyalkatchem. For the pensioners, there are flats established in Koorda, plus a very appealing pensioner hostel adjacent to the hospital. Jocelyn has lived in Koorda all her life and enjoys the rural atmosphere.

The region of Geraldton was founded when Captain James Moresby completed a favourable report of the areas for the government of the day. Geraldton is situated on a large open coastal plain with the Moresby ranges taking up the eastern horizon. The Geraldton port handles many thousands of tonnes of wheat each year and this is all grown on the farms surrounding Geraldton. No doubt young Jeremy is interested in the debate so far. Most of the wheat is shipped straight to overseas countries, while the rest goes to Perth. Geraldton is now as much a crayfishing town as a wheat town, and therefore contributes millions of dollars to Australian export earnings. The Abrolhos Islands, which caused the wreckage and sinking of many of the early explorers' ships, is now one of the best spots for crayfishing and is located just west of Geraldton.

Geraldton has four major high schools, two government and two private. The newest and youngest of these schools is Jeremy's school, the John Willcock Senior High School, which is named after a Premier of Western Australia who was in office in 1893. The school has 800 students and a staff of 63. The Principal is Mr Tenant. The school was opened in 1971 as a junior high school and in 1984 was made a senior high school. John Willcock has a variety of different races and cultures within the student and staff population. The combination and interaction between these different cultures cause no problems at all and create a unique environment as well. The school has a good mix of both academic and athletic students, although most students who finish year 12 wish to further their studies at a university or another higher education authority.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charlesworth Dr R.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must congratulate the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) on his very interesting scheme. At Question Time today unfortunately I was unable to get the call but the question I intended to ask the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones) was: Has the Minister's attention been drawn to two recent reports suggesting that nuclear fusion experiments have taken place at room temperature using a relatively simple process? Can he advise whether such experiments have taken place or should the reports be treated with the same degree of scepticism as Joh Bjelke-Petersen's hydrogen powered car? We all remember that along with Milan Brych and many others. My interest is that energy is a very important and fundamental issue in this country, particularly with the focus that it has been given through the greenhouse effect and concerns about nuclear waste disposal.

SPEECH.PARA: Earlier this week I asked a question on geothermal energy and the possibility of that abundant source being used in Australia. According to the Minister, we do not have much of a future in that area but geothermal energy is environmentally sound. Perhaps it is the case that in Australia wind and sun may be a better chance for clean energy production. But let us get back to the question of fusion. It has always been considered a very difficult technology and one which required a massive amount of energy to produce the effect. Indeed, it was believed that the technology was beyond our reach in the next 50 years or that sort of time frame. So claims that cold fusion at room temperatures has been produced by two separate teams working in Utah are of interest. It was reported today that the division of mineral products of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation in Port Melbourne has carried out experimental work in this area.

The Utah experiment under Martin Fleischmann and Stanley Pons claims to have induced nuclear fusion in deuterium. Of course, deuterium is heavy hydrogen, as honourable members who are seated behind would know. The induction of nuclear fusion used electrical chemical methods. Deuterium occurs in 1 1/2 parts per 10,000 in ocean seawater. So there is potential for such a process. The second Utah group at Brigham Young University, led by Dr Stephen Jones, observed fusion at room temperature between dueterons. Deuterons are hydrogen atoms with one extra neutron, again as honourable members seated behind me would understand. During low voltage electrolytic infusion in metallic or palladium electrodes the group observed fusion at room temperatures. Indeed, the CSIRO's findings on the Brigham Young work are very promising. It has been confirmed that an effect has been identified and there is some concern that there may be another cause for this-possible alloy formation.

The importance of this research is critical to us. This evidence has major geophysical implications in volcanic eruptions. There is research in respect of that and continental drift forces also indicate that this sort of force may be operating. The CSIRO's work is a very valuable contribution to an exciting area of nuclear physics. This advance will require further confirmation, but we could be on the brink of a very outstanding area of scientific development. Tonight on PM I heard that these experiments had been confirmed in Moscow also. So it seems that the body of evidence suggesting that we are on the verge of a new step in energy production may have some substance. I commend these reports to all honourable members of this House. I hope that, in the future, we will pursue such advances.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wooldridge Dr M.R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —After Question Time today the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) added to one of his answers that he gave yesterday. In doing so he sought to attack me personally and, for some reason, professionally. Given that Question Time and personal explanations do not particularly allow a full discussion of the facts, I would like to do that now. When I asked the question yesterday I took heed of Madam Speaker's request and shortened my question; so some of the figures were left out. I was not attempting to be smart; I was simply trying to ask a question. I was somewhat surprised at the Prime Minister's nasty response this afternoon. But perhaps if one has developed a successful personal and public style one should not have to change it just because one is in this place.

SPEECH.PARA: My question was whether two million Australians were without access to health. The document I referred to was entitled `Health Insurance Survey, March 1983', produced by the Australian Bureau of Statistics. On the front page in the half-column headed `Executive Summary', which is all anyone seems to read, it is stated that 1,826,000 people did not have insurance cover and were not identified as having access to special Commonwealth benefits. I am prepared to accept the fudge factor of 10 per cent. But if people do not have Commonwealth medical benefits and they do not have health insurance it does not mean that they do not have access to health care.

If we look at a more detailed analysis of the figures we see that Queensland had over three times the average number of insured than the average of other Australian States. The reason for that is quite simple. In Queensland people have had access to shared public hospital wards for many years. While that is only hospital treatment, medical treatment has been available in outpatient departments or hospital casualty services. So even if people in Queensland do not have Commonwealth pensioner benefits, repatriation benefits or private health insurance they have still had full access to health cover for many years.

The second aspect is that in that survey 153,600 people who were eligible for health care cards, repatriation benefits or pensioner health benefits had not actually applied for those cards. Had they been sick they would have had full access to health services through those schemes. If we remove 13,300 from that number so we do not double count for Queensland, we get 140,300. I am talking about contribution units here. I will deal with that at the end.

The third thing in that survey is that 238,800 people said, `I am healthy enough. I do not need health cover,' and they were making a personal choice not to have it. If we remove those people in Queensland-114,900-we end up with 122,900. If one subtracts all of these one finds that 376,500 contributor units did not have access to health services. A contributor unit might be a single person or a family. The Australian Bureau of Statistics gets an average by multiplying the number by 1.770. By doing that one gets a figure of 666,400-that is, 666,400 Australians who did not have access to health cover. I am prepared to admit that that is a large number of people, but it is not two million. If we are to have honesty in this debate perhaps realistic figures should be used.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to talk about an event that occurred in this country about three years ago when the schooner Orionia touched at the port of Albany on its way to Vanuatu for revictualling. It had hardly been in port before the Commonwealth police descended on the boat and apprehended it, and the crew was stranded in Australia. This apprehension was carried out at the behest of the Israeli Government under extradition legislation. The event was drawn to my attention. I had a good look at the documentation and it occurred to me at the time that the act was well outside the provisions of the legislation, as that legislation applies only to criminal proceedings and not civil litigation. I could not see how what had occurred could possibly be anything other than civil litigation.

SPEECH.PARA: This saga dragged on for some time. I had a lot of correspondence with the responsible Minister about it. Eventually the matter went to court and, because of the way the extradition legislation is structured-and that is something which needs to be looked at-the people from the boat were deported. Because of the provisions of the extradition legislation they had to be incarcerated until their deportation. They were not the sort of people who would abscond. They could not do so because a large number of people were dependent upon them. Dr Hemple and Mr Etheridge spent 18 months in Australian gaols until they were finally deported. When they got to Israel the Israeli courts quickly granted them bail. The matter was dealt with by a judge in chambers, who said that there was no case to answer. He dismissed the whole case, confirming what was self-evident at the time; that is, extradition should not have been applied and there had been a mistake.

It is open to those two men to litigate in the Israeli courts to regain their property. As they were 12 months ahead in their payments on the property at the time it was confiscated, they would have a very good case. I feel very sad at the treatment those people received. Although I am sure that they do not have a case against the Australian Government for compensation for their incarceration, I believe that they have a case against us for unlawful seizure of their property. I hope that the Australian Government will be big enough to grant them re-entry visas to Australia so this matter can be pursued.

I want to mention an unforseen consequence of the statement made by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) last night. I think that the statement was an excellent document which will give a lot of hope to people in Australia. An item on page 54 passed without much notice, and that is that the Government is terminating a bounty on Australian agricultural tillage machinery. It is a bounty of 10 per cent, paid on the wholesale price. I accept that, by and large, that was a reasonable decision to make even though the agreement was supposed to run until 1991. However, in the town of Merredin in the electorate of O'Connor, there is a business in which I have had a longstanding interest. This business is now the biggest employer in Merredin. It makes a unique piece of machinery called a rotary harrow. This machine is absolutely vital if we are serious about combating soil erosion and salinity problems, which this Government is the first government to recognise are serious and must be tackled. The implement allows for very low impact tillage on the crop and ensures that the top cover is left on the ground. It also has very good export potential.

This company can reduce its costs still further, but it needs an injection of capital. I hope that a way can be found to solve this dilemma because, if this company is forced to loose the grant of approximately $360,000, it will simply cease to exist. That would be a great tragedy for a uniquely Australian machine which has worldwide implications for the coming battle against salinity and soil erosion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Downer Mr A.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the adjournment debate last night in the Senate, Senator Irina Dunn, an Independent senator, made some appalling and unsubstantiated allegations against two policemen, Detective Russell King and Detective Kevin Jenkins, who live in my electorate. Senator Dunn alleged, on the basis of information provided to her by an organisation called the Committee to Defend Black Rights, that those two policemen had been assaulting Aboriginal people. She went further and alleged that they had been involved in brutality against Aboriginal people. It is the normal practice in Australia, as it is in most Western democratic countries, for any such allegations to be dealt with in courts of law. In this case no-one has lodged an official complaint against either Detective King or Detective Jenkins, nor, for that matter, has Senator Dunn.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Dunn is probably proud of herself because she has managed to get her name into the newspaper, and that is, I suspect, the main objective of the exercise. She has made allegations against two men who have never been subject to official complaint either by those who were allegedly beaten or anybody else in the town of Murray Bridge. Senator Dunn has used the parliamentary privilege of the Senate to make allegations which have gained publicity.

Senator Dunn was elected to this Parliament on the basis of the peace platform. Our Senator Dunn is very self-righteous and pacific, but let me remind honourable members of the consequences of her actions. The mother of Detective Jenkins heard the allegations made by Senator Dunn on Radio 5AD today. That woman was so shocked that she is now in hospital. I wonder whether Senator Dunn thinks that is very funny. What is more, Mr Campbell-I suspect that he will be well known to the Minister for the Arts and Territories (Mr Holding), who is at the table-a well-known Aboriginal activist and friend of Michael Mansell, rushed to the media immediately. An Australian Associated Press report states that, according to Mr Campbell:
Aborigines in the South Australian town of Murray Bridge have threatened to retaliate against local police after allegations of police brutality were raised in the Senate.
That refers to the matter raised by Senator Dunn. Mr Campbell went on to say:
We're prepared to fight, how long can we bend? We want the police to treat us like human beings.

He warned of a violent protest if a call by Senator Dunn to charge two local detectives with assaulting Aborigines fell on deaf ears. Senator Dunn, elected on a platform of peace, is creating massive divisions in the relatively small community of Murray Bridge. She is calling for Detectives King and Jenkins to be immediately suspended from their duties at Murray Bridge and tried for assault before a court, yet she does not have the guts to say any of this outside the privilege of parliament. She does not care about the implications for the livelihoods of detectives King and Jenkins. They do not matter. It does not matter what happens to their families as long as wretched Senator Dunn can get her name in the newspapers. This is a pathetic commentary on the performance of Senator Dunn. She should resign from the Senate if she intends to continue behaving in that way. I know that I will get the sympathy of the Minister at the table, who is a former Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, because he knows about the activities of Mr Campbell. People such as Senator Dunn are really just hijacking the issue in order to get publicity.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Blunt Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Community Services and Health, upon notice, on 27 September 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What are the details of the Government's proposal to enable employers to apply for Commonwealth assistance in establishing and operating child care facilities for their staff.
(2) What financial contributions will be expected from each business in establishing and maintaining a work-based child care centre.
(3) What will be the financial contribution of the Government in establishing and maintaining each centre.
(4) Will the Government's financial contribution be conditional upon each business meeting certain requirements of entry; if so, what are those conditions.
(5) Will the employees of the centre be Government employees or employees of the particular business concerned.

(6) Have discussions taken place between Government officials and business leaders of the industries concerned, as part of the consultative process before the implementation of the program; if not, why not.
(7) If discussions have taken place, who were the business leaders involved.
(8) What was the response of those businesses to the proposal.
(9) Has the proposal been raised with trade unions; if not, why not.
(10) If the proposal has been raised with trade unions, which trade unions were involved and what were their responses.
(11) Will he provide copies of any correspondence on this matter between (a) trade unions and (b) business representatives, and the Government.
(12) What is the Government's estimates of the number of children in Australia who are currently on waiting lists for child care.
(13) How do the figures from each State compare with each other.
(14) What is the Government's estimate of the number of places needed but not presently provided for (a) out of school hours care, (b) child care and (c) long day care.
(15) Has the Government encountered any difficulties in finding appropriate sites for the establishment of those child care places; if so, what has caused those difficulties.
(16) If difficulties have not been encountered, what has caused the delay in the Government's approval of those child care places and in the subsequent establishment of them.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1), (2), (3) and (4) The attached booklet entitled ``Industry Initiative-Information and Guidelines'' provides full details on the Government's proposal to enable private sector employers to apply for Commonwealth assistance in establishing and operating child care facilities for their employees.
[The booklet provided by the honourable member is too lengthy to be published in Hansard. A copy of the booklet is filed in the Table Office of the House of Representatives, where it may be read.]

(5) The employees of centres established under this initiative will be employed by the management committee operating the centre (these committees are discussed in more detail in the attached booklet).
(6) Discussions have taken place between Government representatives.
(7) and (8) These discussions were held in confidence.
(9) Yes.
(10) The Australian Council of Trade Unions indicated strong support for the proposal.
(11) I am not prepared to make correspondence available at this stage of negotiations.
(12) and (13) Figures on the number of children on waiting lists for child care are not collected because waiting lists do not give an accurate measure of actual demand.

(14) Notional demand for outside school hours care is estimated to be 190,000 places, and for formal long day care for below school-age children is estimated to be 210,000 full time places. These estimates are based on the number of families where both parents or the sole parent have work-related needs for child care and have indicated a preference for formal care. Also included are women not presently in the labour force who have stated that they would like to work if child care was available.

(15) For the majority of centres, few difficulties were experienced in identifying suitable sites, due mainly to the high level of co-operation between the Federal, State and Local Governments. However problems have sometimes arisen in densely populated areas, due either to the lack of suitable land and/or the cost of purchasing land and building centres in these areas.

In some cases, delays occur until a site can be found which meets the Department's criteria of being close to transport routes, is in an environment suitable for a child care centre or has sufficient space for outdoor activities.

Delays have also occurred from long planning lead times caused by planning appeals, delays in getting planning approvals through councils, or a need to call for additional tenders or to negotiate with tenderers because the tender price was too high. Some are simply normal building industry delays.
(16) Not applicable.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Woods Dr R. L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 28 February 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the Government in 1987 sell a 8.16 ha site known as the Lidcombe Industrial Estate in Birnie Avenue Lidcombe, to a Sydney-based developer, Condux Corporation.
(2) Was the land sold to Condux Corporation for $6m.

(3) Is he able to say whether in 1988, after subdivision and the erection of some site works on the estate, Condux Corporation sold the land in 4 parcels for the sum of $13.77m, $7.77m more than the sum paid to the Government in the previous year.
(4) Is he able to say whether one of the existing tenants of almost 2 ha of the land, Hawker de Havilland Ltd, paid $2.4m for one of those parcels.
(5) What offers were made to the existing tenants to purchase parcels prior to the sale to Condux Corporation.
(6) What proposals were discussed to achieve maximum sale value of the land prior to the sale to Condux.
(7) Was subdivision of the land discussed prior to the sale to Condux Corporation.

(8) Aside from the boom in Sydney property values in 1988, is he able to explain the significant increase in the sale value achieved between the time of sale by the Government to Condux Corporation and the sale by Condux Corporation of the 4 parcels.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) The property was sold to Condux Corporation but whilst the terms of the sale included a payment of $6m there was also a condition that the largest building on the site be leased back to the Commonwealth rent free for 10 months.
(3) Yes.
(4) My Department was advised by the Australian Valuation Office that an area of 2 hectares was sold to AUSTAUR, a subsidiary company of Hawker de Havilland, for $2.4m.
(5) Hawker de Havilland, the only tenant on the property, was given the opportunity to tender for all or part of the site but no offer was received.

(6) In accordance with usual practice the Commonwealth sought advice from the Australian Valuation Office and a range of property consultants on the most effective method of marketing this property to achieve maximum revenue return. The advice received was that the property should be marketed as a large industrial complex.
(7) Subdivision was considered but would have required significant expenditure before sale.

(8) Tenders for the property closed on 15 December 1986. The purchaser, Condux Corporation, did not on-sell it until late 1988. During this two year period land prices in Sydney increased dramatically.

There were also conditions on the sale that affected the price received by the Commonwealth. These included the Commonwealth's requirement that Hawker de Havilland be retained on the site to carry out essential Defence work, and that the Commonwealth continue to have access to a large storage facility on the site at no charge. This would have represented a cost to the purchaser of about $1m.

In addition the substantial costs associated with subdivision, maintenance and development of the site, including demolition, relocation of services and the costs of constructing a sizeable factory building, would have amounted to some millions of dollars which would have significantly reduced the apparent profit received by Condux.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reith Mr P.K.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, upon notice, on 28 February 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Will the Minister identify each Senior Executive Service or equivalent position within the Minister's department or authorities responsible to him which has been reclassified since 1 July 1988 and to which the occupant has been reappointed, indicating in each case (a) resultant increases in salary and other entitlements and (b) whether or not the reappointment followed normal selection procedures.
(2) On what basis is it claimed that the reclassification conform with the national wage fixing principles.
(3) How many Senior Executive Service or equivalent positions are there within the Minister's portfolio.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The only authority within the portfolio to reclassify a Senior Executive Service or equivalent position since 1 July 1988 is the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation (ANSTO).
The position is that of Director, Advanced Materials Program which was reclassified from Chief of Division, Grade 2 to Chief of Division, Grade 3 with effect from 1 January 1989.
(a) The reclassification resulted in an increase of $6,202 in salary and $754 in expenses of office allowance.
(b) The promotion followed the approved procedures applicable to Chiefs of Division.
(2) The reclassification was approved on the basis of a significant net increase in work value.
(3) There are 249 Senior Executive Service or equivalent positions in the portfolio.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reith Mr P.K.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 28 February 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Will the Minister identify each Senior Executive Service or equivalent position within the Minister's department or authorities responsible to him which has been reclassified since 1 July 1988 and to which the occupant has been reappointed, indicating in each case (a) resultant increases in salary and other entitlements and (b) whether or not the reappointment followed normal selection procedures.
(2) On what basis is it claimed that the reclassifications conform with the national wage fixing principles.
(3) How many Senior Executive Service or equivalent positions are there within the Minister's portfolio.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Following approval from the Minister for Finance in April 1988, the top structure of my Department was reorganised, resulting in the reclassification of nineteen Senior Executive Service, or equivalent positions in 1988. However, the formal reclassification of six of these positions, those concerning the position of Deputy Secretary and the five First Assistant Secretaries, was completed prior to 1 July 1988. (In the event, with three of these positions-that of Deputy Secretary, and two of the First Assistant Secretary positions-the previous occupants were reappointed). The remaining thirteen positions were reclassified on 8 July 1988. Twelve of the occupants of these positions were reappointed following normal selection procedures (the thirteenth position being filled on a transfer basis). The twelve positions involved are as follows:
From Senior Executive Service Level 1 to Senior Executive Service Level 2; Executive Branch in Victorian State Office.
From Senior Executive Service Level 1 to Senior Executive Service Level 2; Economic Policy Branch, Migration and Ethnic Affairs Policy Division.
From Senior Executive Service Level 1 to Senior Executive Service Level 2, Social Policy Branch, Migration and Ethnic Affairs Policy Division.
From Senior Executive Service Level 1 to Senior Executive Service Level 2, Policy Secretariat Branch, Migration and Ethnic Affairs Policy Division.
From Senior Executive Service Level 1 to Senior Executive Service Level 2, Settlement Planning Branch, Migration and Ethnic Affairs Policy Division.
From Senior Executive Service Level 1 to Senior Executive Service Level 2, Legal Branch, Development and System Division.
From Senior Executive Service Level 1 to Senior Executive Service Level 2, Systems Planning and Management Branch, Development and Systems Division.
From Senior Executive Service Level 1 to Senior Executive Service Level 2, Systems Development and Facilities Branch, Development and Systems Division.
From Senior Executive Service Level 1 to Senior Executive Service Level 2, Regions and Overseas Operations Branch, Operations Management Division.
From Senior Executive Service Level 1 to Senior Executive Service Level 2, Government Relations Branch, Office of Local Government.
From Senior Executive Service Level 1 to Senior Executive Service Level 2, Resource Management Branch, Corporate Management Division.
From Senior Executive Service Level 1 to Senior Executive Service Level 2, Corporate Services Branch, Corporate Management Division.
The resultant salary increases in each case, at current salary rates, were from $52720 (for level 1) to $57775 (for level 2), an actual increase of $5055. There was no change to entitlements.

(2) All the reclassifications conform with national wage fixing principles. With the changes to the top structure of my Department, there was a reduction in the number of Divisions from six to five and an overall reduction in the number of Senior Executive Service positions in Central Office, which led to a significant net addition to work requirements for eighteen of the reclassified positions. For the other position identified, that of State Director, Victorian State Office, there was a similar net addition to work requirements arising from greater responsibility for the management of staff and resources and an increasingly complex migration program. The reclassifications were approved by the Minister for Finance on the basis of an overall decrease in the number of Senior Executive Service positions (below Deputy Secretary level) of 6.4%, with an associated reduction in Senior Executive Service salaries expenditure of 1.9%.
(3) There are thirty-nine Senior Executive Service or equivalent positions in my portfolio.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Racial Discrimination: Civil and Political Rights

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hollis Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 1 March 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Further to the answers to questions No. 475 (Hansard, 3 November 1983, page 2360), No. 94 (Hansard, 4 November 1987, page 2043), No. 95 (Hansard, 18 November 1987, page 2357), No. 248 (Hansard, 18 February 1988, page 369), on what occasions has the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General discussed the questions of (a) making a declaration under Article 14 of the 1965 International Convention on the Elimination of All forms of Racial Discrimination and (b) acceding to the Optional Protocol to the 1966 International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights.
(2) Which States agreed to Australia making a declaration under the Article and acceding to the Protocol.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) These matters were discussed at meetings of Ministers on Human Rights (which formerly were held as an adjunct to meetings of the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General (SCAG)) on a number of occasions including 14 December 1984, 2 May 1985 and 25 July 1985. Subsequently, human rights issues have formed a separate agenda item for the meetings of SCAG and these matters have been raised as part of that agenda item.
(2) New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr E.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 1 March 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is he able to say whether persons requesting current Acts and regulations from AGPS bookshops are often supplied with obsolete Acts and regulations which may endanger a person at court; if so, what protection is available to AGPS customers who are provided with material that is not up-to-date.
(2) Are the provisions of section 52a of the Trade Practices Act relevant.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Minister for Administrative Services has advised that he is aware of only one possible instance of obsolete legislation being sold to a customer requesting current legislation. He advises that procedures are in place for the replacement of obsolete legislation and the possibility of obsolete legislation being sold is negligible.

(2) Section 52a of the Trade Practices Act relates to conduct, which is, in all the circumstances, unconscionable. In the light of (1) above, s. 52a would not appear to be relevant, but its relevance could only be determined having regard to all of the circumstances in any particular case.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Smith Mr W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 4 April 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: Was Ms J. Hoskins, a media liaison officer, assigned by the Minister's Department to monitor and answer criticisms, which were published in the letters columns of newspapers, of the Prime Minister's citizenship campaign; if so, (a) how many newspapers did she write to in each State or Territory, (b) were any other officers in the Minister's Department or another Department assigned to assist her and (c) what costs were incurred by the Department in the performance of this task.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Mrs J. Hoskins, a Media Liaison Officer, was assigned by her Director as part of her routine media monitoring responsibilities to correct factual errors on citizenship appearing in news reports and letters to Editors columns; (a) ten, viz. The Australian, The Launceston Examiner, The Daily Telegraph, The Sun News-Pictorial, The Melbourne Herald, The Sydney Morning Herald, The Age, The Courier-Mail, The Advertiser, and The Canberra Times; (b) no; (c) no precise records were kept as media monitoring and the provision of factual material to the media is an ongoing responsibility. The best estimate that can be made is that the time taken to prepare and despatch the letters would not have exceeded four hours. Mrs Hoskins's current salary is $20.08 per hour.
